DOC.HEAD: Former Procurement Official Sentenced in Connecticut Contract Case
DOC.TEXT: A former Navy procurement official was sentenced to 15 months in prison Friday for conspiring to help a Connecticut contractor obtain a $100 million Marine Corps contract. The defendant, George W. Stone, pleaded guilty in May to charges of copnspiracy and conversion of government property. Stone, 46, formerly with the Space and Naval Warfare Systems Command, admitted passing confidential information about the contract for a communications system to a former boss, Mark C. Saunders, then a consultant. Stone told Saunders how Norden Systems Inc. was doing in the competition for the contract, and Saunders told the company. ``He stood to gain nothing, and in fact he gained nothing,'' Stone's lawyer, Brian P. Getting, told U.S. District Judge Claude M. Hilton. Saunders is awaiting sentencing in the case. Stone's case is one of more than 30 convictions resulting from the government's long-running ``Ill Wind'' investigastion into defense contracts.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Brennan Resigns
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 7th graf: ``The president,'' Bush calls Brennan
DOC.TEXT: Supreme Court Justice William J. Brennan resigned Friday after a 34-year career as a leading voice of liberalism on the nation's highest court. Brennan, 84, said his ``advancing age and medical condition'' led to his decision to step down. His departure gives President Bush his first chance to name a justice to the court, which has been deeply divided in recent years on such issues as a woman's right to an abortion, affirmative action and separation of church and state. Brennan has been a firm advocate of all three. Bush told reporters that Brennan's decision had taken him by surprise. ``Obviously, his resignation is accepted. I also thank him for his distinguished service to the United States,'' the president told reporters aboard Air Force One en route to Washington from Wyoming. Bush said he would meet with top aides Saturday morning to ``start the process of finding a successor,'' and already, outside groups were seeking to influence his decision. The president said that he wanted the best-qualified person for the post and was ``not afraid of starting a nomination fight.'' The president called Brennan during the flight, said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. Fitzwater declined to say what was said in the conversation. An anti-abortion group in Iowa looked forward to a new justice who opposes abortion, while Eleanor Smeal, former president of the National Organization of Women, said a potential justice's views on the subject ``will be the key political issue of the 1990 senatorial elections.'' Whatever the course of the confirmation process, Brennan's brethren on the court rushed to praise him. Justice Thurgood Marshall said Brennan has been a ``voice of caution and compassion in urging that this court not retreat from its constitutional mission to protect individuals' rights of freedom and expression, guarantee that minorities be free from discrimination and to assure the rights of those accused of crimes.'' Justice Byron R. White, a member of the high court since 1962, said, ``I enjoyed every day I spent with him. He is a great justice and he will be remembered for that.'' Sen. Edward M. Kennedy hailed Brennan _ appointed by President Eisenhower in 1956 _ as one of ``the greatest justices the country has ever had.'' Last April, just days before his 84th birthday, Brennan said he was not dismayed by the court's growing conservatism and said would not retire unless his health required it. ``I'm not discouraged to the point of giving up,'' he said. ``I'm not going to walk out and say the hell with it.'' But Brennan suffered a small stroke after the term ended, falling down in Newark Airport en route to a Scandinavian vacation, said court spokeswoman Toni House. His doctor advised Brennan to ``avoid stress and strain and consider retiring,'' Ms. House said. In his letter to Bush, Brennan said, ``Strenuous demands of court work and its related duties required or expected of a justice appear at this time to be incompatible with my advancing age and medical condition.'' ``I, therefore, retire effectively immediately as an associate justice of the Supreme Court of the United States.'' Brennan suffered a small stroke in 1979 that left his right arm and hand partially paralyzed and in 1978 underwent radiation treatments for a cancerous tumor in his throat. He had said he considered retiring in 1979, burdened also by the illness of his wife of 51 years. His wife, Marjorie, died of cancer in 1982, and Brennan subsequently married his secretary of 25, years, Mary Fowler. After his appointment by Eisenhower, Brennan quickly found a home among the liberal majority led by Chief Justice Earl Warren. Along with fellow liberal Justice Marshall, Brennan has maintained that the Constitution forbids the death penalty as cruel and unusual punishment. Among the more than 1,200 opinions authored by Brennan are landmarks that imposed a ``on-person, one-vote'' standard for electing state legislatures, created constitutional protections for libel lawsuit defendants and helped invent a legal definition of obscenity. He remains among four justices on the court who wholeheartedly support the court's 1973 ruling that legalized abortion nationwide. Brennan said in a statement Friday that his retirement is ``a very difficult decision after almost 34 years of service on the court.'' ``It is my hope that the court during my years of service has built a legacy of interpretation of the Constitution and federal laws to make them responsive to the needs of the people whom they were intended to benefit and protect. This legacy can and will withstand the test of time.'' Brennan served under eight presidents. His departure is bound to cause a dramatic change in the liberal-conservative balance at the court. Only one justice in the court's history, William O. Douglas, wrote more opinions. Only three served at a more advanced age: Oliver Wendell Holmes, 91; Roger Taney, 87, and Hugo Black, 85. For more than three decades, Brennan has been a leading exponent of liberalism and, by most accounts, a leading behind-the-scenes strategist in helping mold liberal rulings and in later years in preserving them on an increasingly conservative court. Although the court and its changing cast of justices grew more conservative over the years, he remained a powerful force. Conservatives have consolidated their power and in most cases command a 5-4 majority. But in several key areas liberals, led by Brennan, have been able to win important victories. Just last month, with Brennan wrote for a five-member majority that upheld the federal government's power to implement affirmative action. The court upheld policies of the Federal Communications Commission giving minorities special preference in the award of broadcast licenses. Brennan's health has generally appeared good, despite his advancing age. He was weakened badly by the flu this year but he appeared to have recovered by the end of the term last month. At the time of his appointment, he was a member of the New Jersey Supreme Court. He was confirmed by the Senate early in 1957 with only Sen. Joseph McCarthy, R-Wis., voting against him. McCarthy accused Brennan of being too soft on communism. A graduate of the University of Pennsylvania and Harvard Law School, he had practiced labor law in Newark before becoming a state judge in 1949 and rising through the judicial ranks.

DOC.HEAD: Bolshoi Dances Mixed Bill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs Planned
DOC.TEXT: On some of the Bolshoi Ballet's visits to the United States, the evening of excerpts from ballets was the program to avoid. Not this year. On Friday night, in a mixed bill at the New York State Theater, the Bolshoi shone. There was good dancing and a mix of dance styles plus variety in length of pieces presented. The most applause went to Nina Ananiashvili and Aleksei Fadeyechev in the bravura ``Grand Pas'' from ``Don Quixote,'' choreographed by Alexander Gorsky. When he lifted her over his head with one hand, the audience went wild. Yelena Borisova also was excellent in her solo variation. Another spectacular pas de deux, from Marius Petipa's ``Le Corsaire,'' was performed by Alla Mikhalchenko and Mark Peretokin. His work in the air looked fantastic but his landings weren't smooth. The much softer pas de deux from ``The Flower Festival at Genzano,'' danced by Natalia Arkhipova and Yuri Klevtsov, was programmed between the two flag wavers. Lyudmila Semenyaka and Yuri Posokhov danced the fairy and the Scot in a pas de deux from a Bournonville masterpiece, ``La Sylphide.'' Yuri Vasyuchenko starred in ``The Appian Way'' scene from ``Spartacus'' choreographed by Yuri Grigorovich. He and his shepherds and soldiers filled the stage with strong dancing and emphatic masculinity. The evening began and ended with longer pieces. In the opener, Mikhail Fokine's ``Petrushka,'' Mikhail Sharkov danced the title role, showing a bit too much spunk as the pitiable puppet. It ended with ``Paquita,'' choreographed by Petipa to showcase several ballerinas. The leading one in this performance, Nina Semizorova, doesn't make her movements flow. But ``Paquita,'' to gentle music by Leo Minkus, contained much beauty. Aleksandre Kopylov conducted the New York City Opera Orchestra, which has sounded marvelous through the two-week engagement. From here, the company will perform in Washington, Chicago, Los Angeles, San Diego, Honolulu and Boston.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Remembered as Voice of Compassion
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Subs 8th graf bgng The matter to fix wording, now sted not.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush thanked retiring Justice William J. Brennan on Friday for his ``distinguished service'' in 34 years on the bench and said he would meet with advisers Saturday to begin choosing a successor. Brennan's colleagues remembered him as ``a voice of caution and compassion'' whose decisions over 34 years fought to preserve the liberties of Americans. ``I greet the news of my brother Justice Brennan's departure from the court with deep regret,'' Justice Thurgood Marshall said in a statement. ``He is an eminent jurist whom no one can equal for his breadth of knowledge, integrity and commitment to justice for all humankind. ``Without doubt his opinions will go down in history as the greatest of the court's.'' Marshall was perhaps Brennan's closest collaborator on the court. Both, for example, opposed the death penalty in all circumstances. They voted to stop the execution of a Virginia man Thursday night, but were outweighed by their colleagues. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist said Brennan ``has made a major contribution to American constitutional law. I hope his retirement will enable him to relax from the cares of office and restore his health.'' Bush, who received a facsimile of Brennan's resignation as he boarded Air Force One in Wyoming, said the announcement came ``as a complete surprise.'' ``The matter is now official and we will now start the process of finding a successor,'' Bush said, adding that he would meet Saturday at the White House with Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, Chief of Staff John Sununu and White House Counsel C. Boyden Gray to discuss a successor. Asked what judicial philosophy he would seek, Bush said, ``It's too early to express anything of that nature. I've always said I want somebody who will be on there not to legislate from the bench but to faithfully interpret the Constitution, so that gives me a wide latitude.'' Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., a member of the Senate Judiciary Committee, ranked Brennan with Marshall and former justices Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr. and Louis Brandeis as ``the greatest justices this country ever had.'' Brennan at 84 was the oldest justice and with more than 33 years on the court was the senior in point of service. ``I am Justice Brennan's oldest colleague on the court and I enjoyed every day I spent with him,'' Justice Byron White said. Marshall called him a ``treasured colleage and a dear friend. I will miss his warm heart and kindred spirit.'' ``Justice Brennan consistently has been a voice of caution and compassion in urging that this court not retreat from its constitutional mission to protect individuals' rights,'' he added. American Civil Liberties Union President Norman Dorsen said Brennan's resignation would be ``an incalculable loss to the law and civil liberties and to every person whose rights are threatened in the United States. ``Justice Brennan has been a courageous, insightful and above all humane jurist. He will not be easily replaced.'' Brennan's replacement was the subject of immediate speculation and jockeying by interest groups Friday night. Kate Michelman, president of the National Abortion Rights Action League, said Friday was a ``very, very dark day.'' ``I've been saying for months that the threat to our right to choose is as close as the next Supreme Court appointment,'' she said in an interview. ``Clearly this is a very serious loss for all of us who value individual liberty and privacy rights.'' The Iowa Right to Life Committee, however, said, ``The appointment of one more justice who believes that all human life, both born and unborn, deserves protection, will be the beginning toward our country once again protecting preborn life.'' The court has been split 5-4 recently on such heated political issues as abortion and legal experts predicted the balance was about to shift. Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., a member of the Judiciary Committee, said that because of the frequent 5-4 votes, Brennan's resignation ``is a monumental change. It is important that President Bush make an appointment that will not polarize the nation.'' Susan Low Bloch, a law professor at Georgetown University, said, ``A lot of the 5-4 decisions that went the way Brennan voted are likely to switch because I think it's likely that President Bush is going to pick someone whose views differ from Brennan.''

DOC.HEAD: With PM-North, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a chronology of key events in the Oliver North Iran-Contra case: 1988= March 16 _ North, former Reagan National Security Adviser John M. Poindexter, former Maj. Gen. Richard Secord and Iranian-American businessman Albert Hakim are indicted. March 18 _ North announces his retirement from the Marine Corps, says he may subpoena ``the highest ranking officials in our government.'' June 6 _ U.S. District Judge Gerhard A. Gesell orders separate trials for the four defendants. Independent Counsel Lawrence E. Walsh says the next day that North will go first. Nov. 7 _ One of 16 criminal counts against North, fabricating a document, is dismissed. Nov. 21 _ Gesell says that if North stands trial, the court will have little control over the testimony of witnesses ``acquainted with high security matters.'' He appeals to President Reagan to decide whether the government will allow the trial to take place. Nov. 29 _ Another count against North is dismissed: wire fraud. Dec. 1 _ Reagan rules out a North pardon but says ``duty requires'' his administration to block release of secret documents North wants for his trial. Dec. 12 _ Gesell tells North he can't use 3,500 secret documents but can use more than 300, roughly the same number planned to be introduced by the prosecution. The decision removes a major obstacle to the trial going forward. Dec. 30 _ North subpoenas Reagan and President-elect Bush as defense witnesses. Gesell, after Bush is sworn as president the following month, rules he won't be called. 1989= Jan. 5 _ Prosecutors ask Gesell to dismiss conspiracy and theft charges, citing North's ``insistence on introducing classified information in his defense'' and the Reagan administration's refusal to release material the judge ruled North would need. Gesell later dismisses those counts. Twelve felony counts remain, including lying to Congress in 1985 and 1986 about his efforts on behalf of the Contras and lying to the attorney general about the National Security Council's role in diverting money from the Iran arms sales. North also is accused of illegally accepting a $13,800 security system at his home from co-defendant Secord, converting to his own use at least $4,300 in traveler's checks from Contra leader Adolfo Calero, and conspiring to defraud the government of tax revenue by using a tax-exempt foundation to funnel money to the Contras. Jan. 31 _ Jury selection begins. Feb. 21 _ The trial opens with prosecutor John Keker portraying North as a liar who ``places himself above the law.'' Defense lawyer Brendan Sullivan calls North a patriotic Marine who obeyed the orders of his commander-in-chief. March 21 _ Security consultant Glenn Robinette testifies that North let Secord pay for a security fence at his home and then tried to cover up the deal after he left the White House. March 23 _ Fawn Hall, North's secretary at the White House, tearfully testifies that he was a tireless and selfless boss and their shredding of Iran-Contra documents ``was no big deal.'' March 28 _ Former Attorney General Edwin Meese III testifies administration officials were worried about impeachment of Reagan after they discovered the Iran-Contra link. March 31 _ Gesell rejects North's request that he order Reagan to testify, saying there is no proof the former president authorized North to commit crimes. April 6 _ North takes the stand, saying he was merely a Marine following White House orders. April 7 _ North concedes he lied to the House Intelligence Committee at an Aug. 6, 1986, meeting at the White House at which he denied providing assistance to the Contras. April 12 _ North testifies he thought he was protecting Reagan when he altered Iran-Contra memos before investigators from the Justice Department could get a look at them. April 18 _ Prosecutor Keker, in a hard-hitting summation, says, ``North and McFarlane were following Adolf Hitler's old strategy, which is the victor will never be asked if he told the truth.'' April 19 _ In an emotional closing argument, Sullivan says North became a ``sacrificial lamb'' in the Reagan White House and was fired to spare the former president political harm. May 4 _ North is convicted of falsifying and destroying documents, accepting an illegal gratuity and aiding and abetting in the obstruction of Congress. He was acquitted of five other counts of lying to or obstructing Congress, of lying to Meese, of illegally converting traveler's checks to his own use and of conspiring to defraud the IRS. June 30 _ Gesell denies a mistrial motion filed by the defense on grounds that juror Tara Leigh King had falsely denied in a questionnaire that she or her relatives had ever been involved in a court proceeding or criminal investigation. July 5 _ Gesell sentences North to a suspended prison term and a $150,000 fine for his role in the Iran-Contra affair. North is placed on two years' probation and ordered to perform 1,200 hours of community service administering a new program to help inner-city youth avoid involvement in drugs. 1990= July 20, 1990 _ A federal appeals court sets aside North's convictions, reversing the one on destroying documents and ordering a hearing to see whether all three were impermissibly tainted by congressional testimony that he gave under a grant of immunity.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-North, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are excerpts from the U.S. Court of Appeals decision in the Oliver North case, and from the dissenting opinion by Chief Judge Patricia Wald. At trial, North was convicted on three of 12 counts: aiding and abetting the obstruction of Congress (count 6), altering and destroying National Security Council documents (count 9) and accepting an illegal gratuity (count 10). The ``Kastigar'' case referred to is a 1972 Supreme Court decision setting out safeguards to make sure that someone forced to testify under a grant of limited immunity is not convicted later as a result of his own testimony, directly or indirectly. The appeals court panel said: ``Because of the length and complexity of our disposition of North's appeal, we summarize our holdings. ``1. The District Court erred in failing to hold a full hearing ... to ensure that the IC (Independent Counsel) made no use of North's immunized congressional testimony. North's convictions on all three counts are therefore vacated and remanded to the District Court. ... ``2. The District Court's jury instructions on count 9 were erroneous in that they allowed the jury to convict without unanimously concluding that North committed any one of the criminal acts charged in count 9. ... This error mandates reversal of North's conviction on count 9. ``3. The District Court did not err in refusing to instruct the jury on the defense of authorization. ... The District Court did err, however, in limiting the jury's consideration of authorization evidence as that evidence was relevant to the issue of intent in count 9. North's conviction on count 9 is therefore reversed. ``4. The District Court did not err in quashing North's subpoena of former President Reagan, and the quashal did not violate North's Sixth Amendment rights. ``5. The District Court erred by instructing the jury that, as a matter of law, a congressional inquiry was `pending.' ... We conclude, however that this error was harmless. ``6. Although the prosecution made highly improper remarks during closing argument, the District Court did not err in refusing to grant a new trial on that basis. ``7. The District Court's rulings with regard to the Classified Information Procedures Act (`CIPA') did not violate the Due Process Clause and were not otherwise erroneous. ``8. The credit given by the District Court to a juror's denial of bias, even though the juror made false statements on the juror questionnaire, was not erroneous and in no way prevented North from exercising his peremptory challenges. ``9. The District Court did not err in declining to allow into evidence an edited videotape of the congressional testimony of Adm. John Poindexter, North's former superior at the NSC. ``10. The District Court did not violate the Jury Selection and Service Act. (`JSSA.') ``11. Although the District Court may have been better advised to use a different verdict form, the District Court did not improperly foreclose a general verdict of guilty or not guilty on counts 6 and 9. ``12. Other than with respect to the element of intent in count 9, the District Court committed no reversible error in its jury instructions concerning the critical elements of each offense. ``13. Venue in the District of Columbia was proper for count 10. ``14. The District Court committed no error in allowing North to be tried as an aider and abettor on count 6. ... ``The fact that a sizable number of grand jury witnesses, trial witnesses and their aides apparently immersed themselves in North's immunized testimony leads us to doubt whether what is in question here is simply `stimulation' of memory by `a bit' of compelled testimony. Whether the government's use of compelled testimony occurs in the natural course of events or results from an unprecedented aberration is irrelevant to a citizen's Fifth Amendment right. ... ``From a prosecutor's standpoint, an unhappy byproduct of the Fifth Amendment is that Kastigar may very well require a trial within a trial (or a trial before, during or after the trial) if such a proceeding is necessary for the court to determine whether or not the government has in any fashion used compelled testimony to indict or convict a defendant. ``We readily understand how court and counsel might sigh prior to such an undertaking. Such a Kastigar proceeding could consume substantial amounts of time, personnel and money, only to lead to the conclusion that a defendant _ perhaps a guilty defendant _ cannot be prosecuted. Yet the very purpose of the Fifth Amendment under these circumstances is to prevent the prosecutor from transmogrifying into the inquisitor, complete with that officer's most pernicious tool _ the power of the state to force a person to incriminate himself. ... ``On remand, if the prosecution is to continue, the District Court must hold a full Kastigar hearing that will inquire into the content as well as the sources of the grand jury and trial witnesses' testimony. That inquiry must proceed witness-by-witness; if necessary, it will proceed line-by-line and item-by-item. For each grand jury and trial witness, the prosecution must show by a preponderance of the evidence that no use whatsoever was made of any of the immunized testimony either by the witness or by the Office of Independent Counsel in questioning the witness.''

``Wald, Chief Judge, dissenting ... ``Oliver North's was a case of epic proportions, massively publicized, for many weeks engaging the rapt attention and emotions of the nation. The panel today reverses his convictions on three separate grounds, including a remand for an `item-by-item, line-by-line' hearing on whether any bit of evidence, as yet unidentified, may have reflected exposure to North's immunized testimony before Congress. ``After studying for months the thousands of pages of transcripts and hundreds of documents produced for the grand jury and trial, I, on the other hand, am satisfied that North received a fair trial _ not a perfect one but a competently managed and a fair one. As in all trials of this magnitude, a few errors were made, but in analyzing and researching North's claims, including the three grounds on which the Per Curiam (court majority) reverses, I do not find, singly or cumulatively, that any of them rose to the status of reversible error. I am convinced that the essentials of a fair trial were accorded North, and that his conviction on the three counts of which the jury found him guilty should be affirmed.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Fast-Food Icon Dazzles the Workers' State
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MOSB3 of July 20
DOC.TEXT: Even McDonald's couldn't bring fast food to Moscow. Hundreds of young Soviets are selling ``Beeg Maks'' as fast as their hands can move, ricocheting off each other in the crush behind the counter at the McDonald's less than a mile from the Kremlin. But even 5,000 sandwiches an hour is not enough to satisfy Soviet hunger for a taste of the West. The lunchtime line is 90 minutes and 1,200 people long. Six months after opening, the Golden Arches have eclipsed the popularity of even Lenin's tomb, where a recent wait to see the preserved body of the Soviet founder took only 20 minutes. ```Fee-lay-oh-feesh.' What's that?'' asked a grandmother as she sounded out the Russian transliteration of a ``filet-o'-fish'' sandwich on a McDonald's brochure. A fresh-faced young McDonald's staffer had given her the brochure when she joined the end of the three-block line curling around the fountain and wrought-iron lampposts of Pushkin Square. Entrepreneurs hawked their wares along the line. One ruble for a Latvian humor newspaper, just 25 times the price of Pravda. Or 25 rubles for an application to immigrate to the United States. The stack of blank paperwork is available free to anyone willing to stand in another line at the Embassy. Inside, the sheer volume has taken its toll. A milkshake is served melted, and the Big Mac is a bit flat because iceberg lettuce doesn't curl quite the same when grown under glass in these northern latitudes. But the fries were salty and golden, a straw stood in a second shake and Soviets found lettuce wondrous enough, without worrying about its ability to fluff up a sandwich. Four hours into their day, few of the 250 young people cooking and manning 27 cash registers managed obligatory McDonald's smiles, but all were unfailingly polite. For Soviets accustomed to snarling clerks slopping out cafeteria hash, this is nothing short of unbelievable. ``We really like the service,'' said a smiling Irina Borunova, who came to Moscow from the town of Murom, 150 miles to the east, with her husband and small son. ``It's so clean! Not like a Soviet restaurant,'' marveled Nina Balitskaya, a student teacher who admitted to having braved the line 15 times. For Galina Voyevodkina of Moscow, the queue and the prices were just too much. ``For this kind of money, I could sit in a real restaurant and be served,'' she pointed out. ``And it's not fast. I had to stand in line for an hour and a half.'' A Big Mac costs 3.75 rubles, or a little over two hours' pay for the average Soviet. Restaurants in state hotels charge two to three rubles for a entree, while private Soviet restaurants may demand 10 to 50 rubles. Already, McDonald's has spawned a Soviet clone. Across town on Taganka Square, the same yellow and red colors spell out ``Gamburger Kafe.'' That is the Russian transliteration of hamburger, because the language has no letter ``H.'' The small cafe abandons the usual Soviet restaurant gloom in favor of its competitor's idea of allowing sunlight to stream through the windows. The decor is typically Soviet with five clashing patterns of ceramic tile. The ``gamburgers'' arrive in unusually fresh and crusty buns, served with white cheese, onions, green pepper and cucumber _ Soviet approximations of the cheddar cheese, onions, lettuce and pickles that McDonald's found only by building its own $50 million Moscow food factory. ``Gamburgers'' are fairly fast, served to a line of five people in just minutes. But they're stone cold. McDonald's figured the demand would be overwhelming when it opened Moscow's first taste of the West six months ago. But managers were stunned when the volume hit 30,000 meals a day. Now, it's more than 50,000. The restaurant is the chain's biggest and busiest. To deal with it, the staff has nearly doubled from 630 to 1,100, said operations supervisor Glenn Steeves from McDonald's of Canada, which operates the restaurant in a joint venture with the city of Moscow. The crush and resulting staff expansion also created dozens of unexpected openings for front-line supervisors and an unforseen boon. Suddenly, McDonald's promise of fast promotion for peak performance was a reality _ and a marvelous incentive to stay working hard and honestly. Karina Pogosova, 21, said she had been hired as a regular crew member for the opening in January and in six months had been promoted to shift supervisor on the counter, overseeing 40 to 45 staffers. Her salary has more than doubled, from the 250 rubles a month McDonald's starting wage _ about average for Soviet workers _ to 550 rubles. Even Soviet staffers had expressed worry when McDonald's opened that it would lose a fortune to staff theft, considered by many Soviets a more important benefit than salary. But Steeves said clear warnings of prosecution and strict accounting have worked. ``We count every bun, every patty, every pickle,'' he said. ``It's not a problem.''

DOC.HEAD: Business Slow at Russian Fast-Food Eatery in U.S.
With PM-Soviet-McDonald's
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: While Muscovites waited in long lines at the Red Square McDonald's, Americans were able to belly up to the counter and order piroshkis without waiting at the first Soviet fast-food eatery in the United States. The Friday lunch-hour crowd at Piroshkis in the Waterside Festival Marketplace was slow. While many of the fast-food franchises in the development's food court were moderately busy, there was no waiting for service at the eatery, which opened in April. Its owners said last week that business has been ``gratifying,'' but the joint Soviet-American firm does not release sales figures. A piroshki is a deep-fried pastry stuffed with potatoes and mushrooms, beef and rice, or fish. The counter, which opened in April, also serves Russian varieties of pancakes, donuts, coffee and tea.

DOC.HEAD: Turin Concert Canceled; Crew Delayed By Quarrel In Other Town
DOC.TEXT: Rock star Prince has canceled a concert in Turin after his manager said the tour's crew was delayed at an earlier show in southern Italy, where local promoters parked forklifts in their way because of a quarrel. A police official said the argument was over money. Prince's manager, Randy Phillips of Stiefel-Phillips Entertainment, said the Friday concert in Turin was canceled because he claimed the crew was threatened and roughed up by local promoters after a show in Cava de' Tirreni, 150 miles south of Rome. Police denied there was violence. ``Acts of physical abuse were committed'' against the crew after the Wednesday night concert at a stadium, Phillips said in a statement distributed by Prince's Paisley Park studios of Minneapolis. He did not elaborate. In addition, forklifts were moved in front of the stadium's exits to restrict the crew's movement, he was quoted as saying, preventing the crew to get to Turin in northern Italy in time for the Friday show. But the police superintendent in Cava de' Tirreni, Giuseppe Fortunato, said no violence took place after the concert Wednesday night and only an argument occurred Thursday morning, when the crew was leaving. ``It was resolved tranquilly, and that was it,'' he said in a telephone interview. He added that the argument was over ``a question of money'' but said he had no details, and Philipps could not be reached fo comment. The home telephone of the local organizer was unlisted and efforts to reach him Friday evening were unsuccessful. Prince, on his Nude Tour of Europe, is known for his hits that include Purple Rain, Controversy, and Little Red Corvette.

DOC.HEAD: House Was Hiding Log Cabin
DOC.TEXT: Calvin Hostetler had long suspected his home was hiding a historical secret. This summer, he began tearing the building down and discovered he was right. Hidden within the thick walls of the condemned house about 18 miles west of South Bend was a small log cabin in near-perfect condition. The cabin has one tiny main room and two even smaller side rooms. Underneath is a cellar lined with stones that Hostetler estimates weigh 20 to 25 tons. A preliminary search by Fern Schultz, president of the LaPorte County Historical Society, revealed the land was purchased by a Tobias Miller on Aug. 12, 1833. Settlers began building cabins and clearing land in the area in the late 1820s, but Mrs. Schultz said records do not indicate when the cabin might have been built. ``There's no way of proving that Miller built the cabin,'' she said Thursday. ``Whether he was a land speculator or a farmer, I don't know.'' Hostetler lived in the house in the mid-1970s. He suspected that a log cabin was inside the thick walls because he had seen the uncovered logs in an entry way in the house. After the county condemned the building, he began dismantling it. Finding a cabin within a home is unusual as most log structures were destroyed in the construction of newer homes, Mrs. Schultz said. Hostetler said he plans to ``probably show it to the public. We've had a lot of interest in it, with people asking to look over it.'' Mrs. Schultz said the historical society would continue to examine its records seeking clues to the cabin's history.

DOC.HEAD: Prince Charles' Plaster Cast Is Boost For Church
DOC.TEXT: Prince Charles has donated the plaster cast from his broken arm to help raise cash to repair the roof of a country church damaged in storms, a church official said. The Prince of Wales broke his arm June 28 in a fall during a polo match. ``After the accident, I woke up in the middle of the night and decided to ask the prince if he would give us the cast,'' said Reg Little. He is warden of the Church of St. Thomas of Canterbury in Kingswear, Devon, which suffered $25,000 worth of damage in February's storms. ``I wrote a letter and went to the gate of Highgrove (the prince's Gloucestershire residence), but there was no letterbox and no one about. So I threw the letter over the gate,'' he said. The prince's private secretary got in touch a week later, saying Charles agreed to donate the cast, Little said. He said the cast will either be auctioned or put up as a prize in a drawing.

DOC.HEAD: Yellow Submarine Brings Undersea World Up Close
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BX5 of July 20
DOC.TEXT: As the yellow submersible Delta slips beneath the Gulf of Maine 22 miles off Massachusetts, bubbles form outside the portholes and the craft enters a different world. The tiny, two-person sub skims the sea floor, scattering fish and moving noiselessly through rocky canyons. This once-in-a-lifetime experience 200 feet underwater is part of a program for high school students, designed to bring the reality of the ocean and the environment up close. ``Don't be scared!'' the pilot barks at a reporter as the sub hits the edge of a sharp ledge and bounces off backwards into a murky crevasse. ``It sounds bad but nothing's gonna break.'' As the sub meanders along the bottom, a new kingdom slowly comes to life. Vivid pink and red stems of algae rising from the rough sand flutter eerily like lone, long-stemmed roses. Ivory-colored sponges decorate black craggy rocks. Flounder swim lazily by the portholes. An enormous skate, lying flat along the bottom like a gray throw rug, heaves awake under the bright flood lights of the sub and circles the craft in apparent irritation. The High School Aquanaut program is an opportunity for high school students and their teachers to participate in real undersea research in the Gulf of Maine, the waters off southern New England, the mid-Atlantic Bight and the Laurentian Great Lakes. ``I couldn't believe what I was seeing,'' said Mary Wohlleber, 17, who will be a freshman at Eastern Connecticut State University next year, and has made two dives. ``It makes you appreciate the ocean more. You're there doing the work firsthand and until you do it firsthand you don't respect the animals or their environment.'' The program is sponsored by the federally-funded National Undersea Foundation at the University of Connecticut. At present, the students are from southeastern Connecticut high schools but there are plans to bring in inner-city students from New York next year. ``There's no better way to get youngsters excited about the ocean and the environment than to make them diving scientists,'' said Richard A. Cooper, director of the National Undersea Research Center. It's safe, too. The Delta has made 1,969 dives with no accidents. The sub is made of reinforced steel equipped with the same type of battery in a golf cart. It can go to 1,200 feet maximum without pressurized air. Students in the program, now in its third year, take part in ongoing research experiments. They are selected on a competitive basis from their schools and plan their individual projects with their teachers and program coordinators before they go to sea. ``It was the experience of a lifetime,'' 17-year-old Brad Martin said. ``The views, the crew, being in a place that not many others are able to travel and explore. The program has been a dream come true.'' In the so-called Pigeon Hill area at Jeffrey's Ledge off Gloucester, students help marine biologists measure the pollution content in scallops, which in turn determines the contaminant level in surface sediments. They deploy scallop cages on certain dives and later retrieve them with the aid of the mechanical arm of the Delta. ``We want to make them see that it takes only a short time to pollute the planet and several thousand years to reverse the process,'' said Cooper. The data gleaned from the scallop samples also has a larger significance, according to Bill Robinson, a marine biologist with the New England Aquarium and a program coordinator. ``We know more about corn in the Midwest than we do about fish in the ocean,'' he said. ``That's why we can harvest corn so well. We don't know anything about scallops but once we know about their reproduction cycles, it'll make all the difference.'' Performer Richie Havens was aboard the research vessel J.W. Powell this week as it left Gloucester with a group of scientists and teachers to discover firsthand how the program works. Havens, 49, who grew up in Brooklyn, works with underprivileged students in New York City in addition to his singing career. He helped found the Northwind Undersea Institute for children on City Island in the Bronx. He also heads the Natural Guard, based in Washington, D.C., a program which offers inner-city youth a chance to experience other environments. ``I was a city kid and city kids need a place to go away from the concrete,'' said Havens, who will be bringing students into the program next year. ``We're trying to raise their consciousness about their environment by showing them something they wouldn't otherwise see.'' Coordinators from the National Undersea Foundation hope the program will expand nationwide.

DOC.HEAD: Dutch Prosecutor Says Man Drove Wife To Suicide
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors have brought a man to trial on charges he incited his wife to commit suicide. William Mijssen, spokesman for Amsterdam district court, told The Associated Press Friday that the defendant allegedly abused his wife physically and psychologically for two years before her April 1988 suicide. The trial began Thursday and is based on an 1884 law which prohibits giving assistance in a suicide attempt. According to press reports, the 31-year-old defendant, a Surinamese-born Hindu, whipped, kicked and stomped on his wife during the period before she committed suicide at age 23 by drinking high-strength cooking vinegar. Mijssen refused to disclose the names of the defendant or victim in accordance with Dutch court practice. If convicted, the defendant could face a maximum three-year prison sentence.

DOC.HEAD: Swiss Jogs Up, Down Mont Blanc in Record Time
DOC.TEXT: Swiss marathon runner Pierre-Andre Gobet has broken the record for the fastest conquest of Mont Blanc, jogging up and down Western Europe's highest peak in 5 hours, 10 minutes. Gobet, 35, needed only 3 hours, 38 minutes on Friday to reach the top of the 15,400-foot mountain, then immediately headed back down to Chamonix. The old record of 5 hours, 29 minutes was set by Laurent Smagghe of France in July 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Says Eastwood Can Press On With $20 Million Lawsuit
DOC.TEXT: Clint Eastwood can press forward with a $20 million lawsuit against a Florida-based tabloid newspaper that reported he was threatened by neo-Nazis, a judge has ruled. Eastwood contends a Jan. 2 article in The Globe was false and caused him mental anguish by making him fear for his life. The lawsuit also alleges ``false-light invasion of privacy,'' meaning the article portrayed the actor falsely, said Anthony Glassman, an attorney for the tabloid. Superior Court Judge Dion Morrow on Friday turned down a request by Glassman to dismiss the lawsuit, and gave the defendants 20 days to respond to the allegations. The Globe stands by the story's accuracy, Glassman said. ``Our position was simply that to be the enemy of American Nazis is not a bad thing. It's not offensive,'' Glassman said. It could be a year before the case goes to trial, he said. The Globe reported under a headline ``Nazi Thugs Put Bounty on Clint _ But Dirty Harry Won't Lay Low'' that Eastwood had received death threats and that a $100,000 bounty was placed on his life after he refused to speak at a convention of the Aryan Nations, a white supremacy group.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Gene Kelly and his girlfriend of five years were married during a private ceremony and plan a European honeymoon later this summer, says a spokeswoman for the legendary song and dance man. Kelly, 77, and Patricia Ward, 36, married Friday, spokeswoman Beebe Kline said. Only family and close friends attended, she said. ``I really don't know anything more,'' Kline said. ``Gene's a very private person and that's all they've really told me.'' The couple met in Washington while Kelly taped a television special for the Smithsonian Institution, Kline said. Ward had written for Smithsonian magazine, the spokeswoman said. It's the third marriage for Kelly, star of such film classics as ``For Me and My Gal,'' ``An American in Paris'' and ``Singin' in the Rain.'' He has three children.

Baseball Hall of Famer Catfish Hunter is a pitcher of a different sort these days, traveling the country with hope for fellow diabetics. ``When I first was told I had diabetes I thought I was going to die,'' Hunter said Thursday. ``A week later I was convinced that despite the diabetes I could do anything I wanted.'' The former pitcher for the Oakland Athletics and the New York Yankees travels as a spokesman for The Upjohn Co., which makes Micronase, a treatment for a type of diabetes that doesn't require insulin shots. The all-star was diagnosed with diabetes in 1977 and takes insulin shots twice a day. He pitched for the Yankees for three years after he was diagnosed, retiring at age 33.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also moving on some sports circuits.
DOC.TEXT: The Rev. Jesse Jackson opened an exchange center at the Goodwill Games with an order to his audience to hug the nearest Soviet. ``I hugged a Russian and I hugged an American,'' Jackson said. ``I found that each had a heartbeat and a soul and humanity.'' Jackson was joined Friday, the first day of the games, by Soviet sports minister Nikolai Rusak and Mayor Norm Rice. Together, they opened a Soviet-American exchange center. ``Today, the whole world gets the word,'' Jackson said. ``The cold war is over, peace is upon us.'' Jackson kicked off by urging the audience to hug Soviets in the crowd. Members of a Seattle girls choir and a singing group from Kiev exchanged hugs while the crowd applauded. ``The whole world must be a part of the Goodwill Games and the goodwill family,'' Jackson said.

Actress Blythe Danner is catching up on the news in coastal South Carolina during filming of ``The Prince of Tides.'' ``People have been wonderful, inviting me to a number of social activities and dinners but the bottom line is, I'm here to work and the hours have been very demanding,'' she said Wednesday. Danner, 46, spent time in the region in 1979 during filming of ``The Great Santini,'' based on a Pat Conroy novel, as ``Tides'' is. ``This trip has been very different from my first stay, mainly because my children haven't been with me,'' Danner said. The movie chronicles the life of a shrimping family. Danner portrays Sallie Wingo, wife of Tom Wingo, played by Nick Nolte.

DOC.HEAD: Swiss Teen-Agers Steal Hammer and Sickle
DOC.TEXT: Two Swiss teen-agers on vacation waded across an Arctic river to enter the Soviet Union and steal a hammer-and-sickle emblem from a border marker, but were caught and fined, police said. The national news agency NTB said Friday that police returned the emblem to Soviet guards along with coffee and pastry. Acting police chief Tom Gjestvang of Kirkenes, a border district, said the youths waded the Grense Jakobselv river into Soviet territory Thursday and dashed back to Norway with the emblem from a border marker. Gjestvang said Norwegian police, alerted by the Soviets, stopped the youths' car. ``This happens from time to time,'' he said by telephone. ``We assume they wanted a souvenir.'' Gjestvang said the young men, ages 18 and 19, were each fined about $1,600. They were being held by police until a guarantee for the money was posted.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Brennan Resigns
DOC.TEXT: Here is a brief biographical sketch of Justice William Joseph Brennan Jr. Born: March 25, 1906, Newark, N.J., son of an Irish immigrant. Education: University of Pennsylvania, B.S., 1928; Harvard Law School, LL.B., 1931. Marriage: Marjorie Leonard (deceased), 1928; Mary Fowler, 1983. Children: William Joseph, Hugh Leonard, Nancy. Career: Member of the New Jersey bar, 1931. Practiced law in Newark from 1931 to 1949, member of Pitney, Hardin Ward & Brennan. Superior Court Judge, 1949-1950; Appellate Division Judge, 1950-1952; New Jersey Supreme Court Justice, 1952-1956. Appointed Associate Justice U.S. Supreme Court by President Eisenhower in 1956. Confirmed March 1957 with one dissenting vote: Sen. Joseph McCarthy, R-Wis. Military: Served with the U.S. Army general staff corps in World War II. Decorated Legion of Merit.

DOC.HEAD: GOP Seeks Clear Position on Tax Increases
DOC.TEXT: House Republicans are scrambling to find a clear position on tax increases as congressional Democrats and President Bush duel over who is to blame for swelling budget deficits. Minority Leader Robert Michel, R-Ill., said Friday that he is unsure how many Republicans will ultimately support a deficit-reduction package that includes tax increases. ``I don't know that anything is clearly definitive. We haven't come up with a package yet,'' Michel told reporters. In more than two months of bargaining, administration and congressional budget negotiators have been unable to agree to $50 billion in tax increases and spending cuts for the 1991 fiscal year that begins Oct. 1. Their talks were rocked Wednesday when the House's 176-member GOP caucus voted informally to oppose ``new taxes and all tax rate increases as a means of reducing the federal budget deficit.'' But the next day, the No. 2 House Republican, Minority Whip Newt Gingrich of Georgia _ who supported the GOP resolution _ told fellow budget negotiators that he could ``sponsor and support'' a compromise that includes spending cuts and tax increases. Gingrich and Rep. Richard Armey, R-Texas, who sponsored the GOP resolution, said there was nothing inconsistent about their positions. Gingrich said he voted for Armey's resolution. ``I presented the resolution as our policy position, and I didn't present it as one that bound any individual member's vote,'' Armey said. ``I'd not expect to agree to a budget package that wouldn't get a substantial number of House Republican votes,'' Gingrich said. But Democrats said they do not know where Republicans stand on the question of taxes. ``They ought to resolve that and let us know who's in charge,'' said Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee. Bentsen, his party's 1988 vice presidential candidate, was one of several Democrats who criticized Bush on Friday for pointing his finger at them for causing the deficit problem. ``That's incredible,'' Bentsen said when told that Bush had blamed the Democratic ``stranglehold on Congress'' for continuing budget shortfalls. Rep. William Gray of Pennsylvania, who is No. 3 in the House Democratic leadership, said Bush's comments at a GOP fund-raising breakfast Friday were an example of ``usual election-year hyperbole.'' He said the president was ignoring a national debt that has grown from less than $1 trillion when Bush became vice president in 1981 to more than $3.1 trillion today. ``It's tantamount to the captain of the Titanic saying, `Don't blame me, blame the crew, I just happen to be here,''' Gray said. Foley called Bush's remarks ``a partisan speech for a partisan audience for a partisan purpose.'' Bentsen accused the Bush and Reagan administrations of ``eight years of $200 billion hot checks,'' a reference to budget gaps that have surpassed $200 billion annually in some recent years. ``Some of us have been saying this should be turned around, and the administration has not done so,'' he said. In his remarks in Billings, Mont., Bush said Democratic control of Congress _ which has lasted 29 of the last 35 years _ has gone on long enough. ``We must end this `deficits don't matter' mentality,'' he said. The fiscal 1991 deficit is expected to be $169 billion, not counting the tens of billions of dollars it will cost to rescue the savings and loan industry.

DOC.HEAD: Mexicans Demand Extradition of U.S. Agent in Abduction
DOC.TEXT: The Mexican government wants a U.S. drug agent arrested and extradited to Mexico to face charges that he kidnapped a Mexican doctor wanted in the 1985 slaying of Drug Enforcement Administration agent Enrique Camarena. The Mexican Embassy delivered two diplomatic notes to the State Department on Friday seeking the arrest of DEA agent Hector Berrellez and DEA informant and former Mexican police officer Antonio Garate, said spokesman Antonio Ocaranza. Ocaranza said his government wants the two extradited to face charges that they kidnapped Dr. Humberto Alvarez Machain, who was taken from his Guadalajara office and delivered to El Paso, Texas, where he was arrested by DEA agents April 3. The U.S. government has denied that any laws were broken in the arrest of Alvarez, one of 19 Mexicans indicted in Los Angeles on charges of kidnapping, torturing and killing Camarena in February 1985. There was no immediate response to the request, Ocaranza said. DEA spokesman Bill Ruzzamenti said, ``This is somewhat of a unique situation, so we don't have a lot of precedent to deal with.'' The State Department will study the request and determine what should be done, Ruzzamenti said. The State and Justice departments had no immediate comment on how the government plans to respond to the Mexican request. Alvarez is accused of administering drugs to Camarena after the DEA was kidnapped in Mexico in 1985. The delivery of Alvarez has caused tension between the U.S. and Mexican governments. Mexico has demanded his return, claiming the incident violated Mexican sovereignty. However, Justice Department officials said there are no plans to return Alvarez to Mexico. Alvarez, a gynecologist, testified in Los Angeles in May that he was brought to the United States against his will and that he was tortured with electronic equipment and hit in the stomach while being abducted. Garate testified in Los Angeles that he arranged for friends in Mexico to spirit Alvarez across the border, and that the plan was approved by Berrellez, his DEA supervisor. He said he told his friends that he would pay all their expenses, although no money would be provided up front and no assistance from the DEA. In addition, Garate testified that he specified that Alvarez should not be harmed during the operation. The U.S. government initially denied that it had paid any money for the delivery of Alvarez to U.S. soil. But in late May, the government acknowledged that it paid at least $20,000 to the people who brought Alvarez to El Paso. Berrellez testified that up to $50,000 in reward money had been authorized by DEA headquarters in Washington. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said in May he was not concerned about the circumstances of Alvarez's delivery to U.S. territory and he invited Mexican authorities to turn over more people wanted in the Camarena case in the same way.

DOC.HEAD: Government Report Doubts Plant Should Ever Be Restarted
DOC.TEXT: The future of a plutonium processing plant in Washington state is in new doubt with a report that questions whether the government facility should ever be restarted in view of safety concerns and changing defense policy. The General Accounting Office said in a report made public Friday that the Department of Energy has failed to prove that the PUREX plant at the Hanford Nuclear Reservation is needed to produce plutonium or assist in the management of radioactive wastes. ``DOE has not demonstrated that a need exists for the remaining weapons-grade plutonium that could be extracted, and it has not fully compared PUREX with other waste processing alternatives to determine whether PUREX is the best approach,'' the congressional investigative agency said. The plant was shut in December 1988 because of recurring safety problems. ``DOE's plans for restarting PUREX are inadequate,'' said the report requested by Rep. Mike Synar, D-Okla., chairman of the House Government Operations subcommittee on environment, energy and natural resources. ``A more important question is whether PUREX should be restarted at all given the costs to operate PUREX, in combination with the costs to prepare a supplemental environmental statement, the time and costs associated with correcting identified safety and training deficiencies ... and the possibility that a better alternative exists to dispose the fuel-grade plutonium,'' the study said. DOE spokesman Tim Tomastik said Energy Secretary James D. Watkins had not seen the GAO report and would have no immediate comment. However, Tomastik said there appeared to be some false assumptions in the recommendations. ``It makes the assumption that DOE has made a decision about restarting PUREX. The DOE has not made a decision at this time with respect to whether or not to restart PUREX,'' Tomastik said. Synar said Friday his subcommittee estimates that putting the plant in mothballs would save the government more than $750 million over the next 15 years. ``Given the Bush administration's decision to cancel the Special Isotope Separation plant in Idaho, which was expected to use the plutonium produced by the PUREX plant, the long-term plutonium production mission at PUREX has disappeared,'' Synar said. The DOE-owned, contractor-operated facility near Richland, Wash., formally known as the Plutonium-Uranium Extraction plant began operation in 1956. Its main function has been to reprocess spent uranium fuel rods from Hanford's now-closed nuclear materials production reactor, the N-reactor. The process involves dissolving the rods in acid and extracting plutonium that can be used in making nuclear weapons.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Links Prosecution Witness to Drug Lord
DOC.TEXT: One of the government's chief witnesses in Mayor Marion Barry's drug and perjury trial has ties to the family of a convicted Washington drug lord, Barry's chief lawyer says. Attorney R. Kenneth Mundy contended Friday that Charles Lewis was far from the small-time drug peddler he claimed to be. Instead, Lewis, a twice-convicted drug dealer, ``was trying to strike a bargain and connection for a much larger drug enterprise'' with Rayful Edmond. The confusion began there. Did Mundy mean Rayful Edmond Jr., or Rayful Edmond III? The distinction is important. Rayful Edmond III is serving two consecutive life terms in prison, plus an additional sentence of 99 years, for convictions on a host of drug-related charges. Prosecutors said the younger Edmond was responsible for distributing between 20 percent and 30 percent of the cocaine in the nation's capital during the height of his operation. Witnesses testified in the younger Edmond's trial that the elder Edmond was also involved with drugs, but he has never been charged with a crime. The ties between Lewis and Edmond's family came out as Mundy questioned an FBI agent about notes he had taken during interrogations of Lewis last summer. Lewis, a key government witness against Barry, has described himself as a drug user who was only marginally involved in drug dealing. But Mundy said the notes from the interview show that Lewis had once brought his drug cohorts together with Rayful Edmond Jr. Did his notes mention anything about ``He (Lewis) and Sonny (Whatley) and (James) McWilliams hooking up with a very notorious D.C. drug dealer?'' Mundy asked FBI agent Michael Mason. Before Mason could answer, U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson ordered the jury and the witness out of the courtroom. After the courtroom was cleared, Mundy zeroed in on the notes, without making clear which Edmond he believed Lewis had been referring to. ``Charles Lewis said (to the FBI agents) that he hooked up with Rayful Edmond,'' Mundy said. Mundy also brought up notes from a party in which one Rayful Edmond had brought cocaine for Lewis and his friends to sample. But in a bench conference, Assistant U.S. Attorney Judith Retchin stressed that the man referred to in the notes was the father of the convicted drug dealer. Retchin also insisted that in another interview, Lewis had said he knew of the younger Edmond ``only through the newspapers.'' The confusion was exacerbated by Barry, who said outside court that his attorney had meant Rayful Edmond III. ``He was talking about the one who had a long trial,'' Barry said with a smile. Mundy said he brought up the subject to impeach the testimony of Lewis. But after a lengthy debate, Jackson ruled that Mundy could only do so if he called Lewis as a witness. Mundy then said he expected the government to make Lewis available for questioning. Earlier, one of Barry's security guards testified that he never saw Barry use drugs during a 1988 trip to the Virgin Islands. Lewis has testified that he, Barry and others smoked $300 worth of crack cocaine during the mayor's four-day stay. However, the guard, Ulysses Walltower, acknowledged under cross-examination that he was not around Barry during the times Lewis has testified drugs were used. Barry, 54, is being tried on 10 misdemeanor cocaine possession charges, one misdemeanor cocaine conspiracy charge and three felony counts of lying to a grand jury about his alleged drug use.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Moves to Stop Shipment to Iraq
DOC.TEXT: The administration is moving to make sure an industrial furnace capable of casting metal parts for nuclear weapons is not delivered to the government of Iraq, officials say. The Commerce Department has asked the New Jersey furnace manufacturer to apply for a special export license for ``items that have some sort of nuclear application,'' a State Department official said Friday. ``This license would be very difficult to get,'' said the official, who is familiar with interagency discussions on the furnace export and spoke on condition of anonymity. One of the furnaces has been detained by U.S. Customs officials at Philadelphia since June 26 at the Pentagon's request. The Iraqi government said it was purchasing the furnace to cast lightweight titanium for artificial hip and knee joints for victims of the Iran-Iraq war. However, U.S. officials fear it could use the furnace for weapons production. ``Certain furnaces can be used for casting components for weapons and missiles,'' State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said Friday, noting she was prohibited from discussing details of the case. Raymond J. Roberts, president of Consarc Corp. of Rancocas, N.J., said earlier this week that the Commerce Department advised the company more than a year ago that only a general license was necessary for the export of the furnaces. He was reported out of the office and unavailable Friday. One White House official who spoke on condition of anonymity said it appeared the so-called validated export license would not be granted. He said he believed the license decision was made through an interagency review involving the Commerce, State and Defense departments and the National Security Council staffs, but not any senior White House officials. British and American officials have seized other cargoes this year suspected of containing weapons components for Iraq. In March, British customs officials stopped American-made electronic devices they said would be used by the Iraqis as nuclear weapons triggers. The following month, British officials stopped an Iraq-bound shipment of parts they suspected would be used for a giant gun.

DOC.HEAD: Frank Accepts Reprimand Call; House Debate Set For Next Week
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Barney Frank, D-Mass., is accepting an ethics committee recommendation that he be reprimanded for his relationship with a male prostitute as the House girds for a debate next week on Frank's fate. The panel unanimously reported Friday that aspects of Frank's relationship with Stephen L. Gobie ``reflected discredit upon the House'' and recommended he be reprimanded before the full House next week. A short time later, Frank told reporters in Newton, Mass.: ``I accept the judgment of the committee report.'' It will be up to the House to decide whether to accept the committee report or impose a more severe punishment, such as censure or even expulsion. House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., promised a public debate by next week but predicted Frank would survive the storm. ``I think this matter will be soon put behind us,'' Foley said. ``Barney Frank remains one of the most effective and, I think throughout the House, highly regarded members here.'' Rep. William Dannemeyer, R-Calif., is expected to try to force expulsion of Frank, a daunting task because it would require a two-thirds vote by the Democratic-controlled House. But the conservative lawmaker would not concede that point. ``Who knows?'' Dannemeyer responded when asked about his chances. ``Every member is going to have to vote his or her conscience.'' At least two Republicans say Frank should face a censure, which is a more severe punishment than reprimand because it would require Frank to stand before his colleagues while a resolution condemning his activities is read. Rep. Henry Hyde, R-Ill., said he expected that Republicans would push for censure. And Rep. Tom Petri, R-Wis., a member of the ethics panel, said he would argue for a sterner punishment. Petri said he agreed to the committee recommendation for a reprimand to preserve the panel's tradition of making its decisions unanimously. Rep. Julian Dixon, D-Calif., the ethics committee chairman, defended the recommendation. ``Barney Frank will certainly not consider it a slap on the wrist,'' he said. ``The committee certainly does not consider it a slap on the wrist.'' Frank, one of two acknowledged homosexuals in the House, rejected the notion that he had received lenient treatment from the committee. ``I don't think they'd say they're being soft on me,'' Frank said. Gobie, meanwhile, told Boston radio station WEEI he was pleased the committee was not harder on Frank. Frank paid Gobie $80 for sex and then hired him in July 1985 as a housekeeper and driver, paying him with personal funds. Frank says he ended the relationship in August 1987 after learning that Gobie was operating a sex-for-hire ring out of the lawmaker's Capitol Hill apartment. The ethics committee, which has been investigating the case since last Sept. 11, concluded that Frank improperly fixed parking tickets _ some of them accumulated by Gobie using Frank's car on personal business. And the panel said Frank ``set in motion'' a memo containing misleading information about Gobie sent to a Virginia prosecutor and ``which could have affected Mr. Gobie's probation'' after prior felony convictions.

DOC.HEAD: Military Chief Sees Orderly Soviet Pullout
DOC.TEXT: Post-communist Czechoslovakia's military chief, concluding a U.S. visit, says withdrawal of Soviet forces from his country will be completed by the end of March 1991. Withdrawal of Red Army units in Czechoslovakia since the 1968 Warsaw Pact invasion is a complex process but is on schedule and is being monitored by the democratically elected parliament, Lt. Gen. Anton Slimak told a news conference Friday. He was summarizing information he said he provided Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and other officials at a series of Pentagon meetings. Slimak became chief of the Czechoslovak general staff after last December's peaceful revolution ended four decades of communist rule in his homeland. A graduate of the Soviet Union's Voroshilov General Staff Academy, he is also deputy defense minister in the post-election government. During a week-long tour of major bases on the Atlantic seaboard, Slimak said, he and his aides learned much about U.S. military spirit _ from democratic principles to pride of command _ that ``we will be trying to apply in the reorganization of our armed forces.'' U.S. Army units are based in neighboring West Germany, and now ``we think of them as our neighbors,'' Slimak said. He described as ``an optimal solution'' the new agreement between West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev for reunited Germany to belong to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. ``The Warsaw Pact still has a purpose for the near future, and we believe that after its demise and with the new security arrangements in place, (Czechoslovak) membership in NATO would make no sense,'' Slimak said. He and his staff visited MacDill Air Force Base, Florida; Fort Bragg and Camp LeJeune Marine Base in North Carolina, and Langley Air Force Base in Virginia. They plan to tour Canadian military bases next week.

DOC.HEAD: President Welcomes Ruling on Iran-Contra Figure
With PM-North Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush welcomed the reversal of one of Oliver North's Iran-Contra convictions, calling it ``good news.'' ``I just feel good about it,'' Bush said of the court victory for the former Reagan administration National Security Council aide. Bush made his first comment on the appeals court ruling Friday night as he flew back to Washington from Cheyenne, Wyo. ``I think this is good news. I have not wanted to see the North matter go any further,'' the president said. ``My view is Ollie North _ I've said I don't want to comment while it's in the (court) system, so maybe I ought to get back to that _ but I felt a certain sense of pleasure that he has been in some sense relieved of one of these charges. I just feel good about it,'' he said. The divided appeals court panel reversed one of North's convictions and ordered a lower court to determine whether North's trial was tainted by congressional testimony he gave under a grant of immunity. North was convicted in May 1989 on three of 12 counts stemming from the Reagan administration's clandestine effort to sell arms to Iran and aid the Nicaraguan Contra rebels. The divided three-judge panel reversed North's conviction on the charge of altering and destroying sensitive NSC documents, finding that U.S. District Judge Gerhard Gesell gave erroneous instructions to the jury. North also was convicted of accepting an illegal gratuity and aiding and abetting the obstruction of Congress.

DOC.HEAD: Study Concludes Space Station May Require Up To 10 Space Walks A Week
DOC.TEXT: Up to 10 spacewalks a week will be needed to maintain outside components of the proposed Space Station Freedom unless there are major design changes, a study says. The study, by astronaut Bill Fisher and Johnson Space Center engineer Charles Price and released Friday, showed that in peak maintenance years with the present space station design, two astronauts working together would have to spend up to 6,462 hours a year in space suits repairing and replacing parts. Other years, the maintenance would require fewer space walks, the study said, but over the 35-year lifetime of the station the time spent on repair space walks would average about 3,276 astronaut-hours a year. This would amount to 273 two-person space walks a year, or 5.3 a week. Each space walk takes about six hours. Fisher and Price said that the number space walks could be reduced by up to half if more work can be done by robots that could be controlled from inside the space station or from the ground. Simplifying repair tasks and making all parts replaceable by robots could drop the total annual space walk hours to 507, a number that Fisher said would be manageable. NASA has been criticized by Congress for designing a space station that would require so much maintenance, so much so that much of the time of at least two astronauts on board would be spent on repairs and parts replacement. The current plan calls for eight-member crews. Richard Kohrs, director of the space station program, said that design of the station is now undergoing a major review and that each of the recommendations in the Fisher-Price study will be evaluated. He said changes are being made that will cut down on the weight, power use and maintenance of the station. Reducing the number of space walks, he said, is a major goal. ``We're going to build the space station for science research,'' Kohrs said at a news conference Friday. ``If you are spending a major part of your time on EVA (extra vehicular activity or space walks), then you are taking that away from science.'' NASA executives had ordered the space walk study to coincide with the space station design review. Kohrs said the purpose of the study was to spot problems so that corrections can be made before construction of station parts begins. Assembly of the space station is expected to begin in about three years and it is expected to be permanently occupied by 1996. The station is expected to cost about $30 billion and last about 35 years. NASA has said the station is critical to the agency's future plans to explore the moon and to voyage to Mars. The Fisher-Price report said that a major problem to overcome is the number of hours of space walking required to maintain the station while it is being assembled. The station will be put together with a series of 18 flights by the space shuttle, and parts of the station will spend months in orbit before it is permanently occupied by astronauts. During that 30-month assembly period, the report said, there will be a need for 6,267 hours of maintenance by spacewalking astronauts. This equals about four two-man spacewalks a week. ``All of these would have to be done from the space shuttle,'' said Fisher. Another study, started after the Fisher-Price team made a preliminary report in the spring, concluded with estimates close to those of Fisher and Price. The study, led by William Simon of the Johnson Space Center, said, however, that with changes in design, the spacewalks required to maintain the station could be reduced to about 485 man-hours a year.

DOC.HEAD: Women's, Homosexual Groups praise D.C. Family Leave Law
DOC.TEXT: Women's and homosexual rights organizations praised a liberal District of Columbia law that provides employees with up to four months unpaid family and medical leave. Meanwhile, the business community vowed to lobby against the bill in Congress, saying it would severely hurt the city's small business community. ``This is a very compassionate piece of legislation designed to protect those who are often most vulnerable _ working women, gays, children, the elderly,'' said Ivy Young, spokeswoman for the National Gay and Lesbian Task Force. Claudia Withers, spokeswoman for the Women's Legal Defense Fund, a public policy advocacy group that monitors laws dealing with family and women's issues, said although ``paid leave is best ... we think it'll be the best in the nation.'' The legislation would apply to full-time and part-time workers who want leave to care for a ``family member,'' including newborns, ill relatives or partners in ``committed relationships.'' It would also provide up to 16 weeks of unpaid leave if the employee is suffering from a serious health condition.
DOC.HEAD: House Adopts Bill To Help States Meet Education Goals
DOC.TEXT: The House is agreeing to help states meet national education goals set by President Bush and the governors. The bill, approved on Friday 350-25, authorizes $1 billion in new federal education spending in fiscal 1991 and a total of $5.3 billion over the next five years for education initiatives. The House also voted overwhelmingly, 315-59, to adopt an amendment requiring suspension of federal student financial aid for any student convicted of a drug offense. Rep. Peter Smith, R-Vt., also won support for an amendment to allow states and the Education Department to pool resources for special projects targeted at specific needs in a district. The projects could be exempt from a wide range of federal and state requirements. ``I think it is a major opening, major reform initiative to encourage schools to reinvent themselves for sure-fire performance for all students,'' said Smith, noting he had won endorsements from the National Governors Association and the president's education advisory council. The bill arose from the education summit Bush and the nation's governors held in Charlottesville, Va., in September 1989. It includes several of the statements of education policy goals requested by Bush as well as broader Democratic plans for spending programs. Bush's original version called for an estimated $400 million in 1991 spending. The House version increases authorization for remedial assistance to disadvantaged children. It would authorize $280 million for awards to exemplary schools, and includes money for Bush's proposed National Science Scholars Program and programs to fight illiteracy. It authorizes more money for financial assistance to college students willing to enter the teaching profession and for professional development of teachers. The Senate has passed a more limited version of the bill, and differences will have to be resolved in a conference committee.
DOC.HEAD: FCC Fines Indianapolis Station for Sexually Explicit Broadcasts
DOC.TEXT: An Indianapolis radio station has been fined $10,000 for broadcasting sexually explicit material in violation of federal indecency rules, the Federal Communications Commission says. The action announced Friday against WFBQ-FM, owned by Great American Television and Radio Co. in Cincinnati, was the latest in a spate of moves in the past year by a newly constituted FCC bent on cracking down on disc jockeys often called ``shock jocks.'' The FCC, led by new chairman Alfred Sikes, has issued a number of warnings and fines against stations, most recently a $20,000 fine in June against a San Jose, Calif., radio station, KSJO-FM. In all cases, the commission cited ``indecent'' material involving sexual innuendo or descriptions of sexual organs broadcast between 6 a.m. and 8 p.m. The commission earlier this month repeated its intention to try to extend the ban on indecent broadcast material to 24 hours a day. A court ruling on a 24-hour ban is pending. The FCC warned Great American officials a year ago that material broadcast in 1987 on a show featuring disc jockeys Bob Kevoian and Tom Griswold on WFBQ-FM and its sister station, WNDE-AM, may have violated the FCC's indecency rules. Those rules prohibit the broadcast during daylight hours of ``language or material that ... depicts or describes, in terms patently offensive as measured by contemporary community standards for the broadcast medium, sexual or excretory activities or organs.'' The commission also reviewed material the station broadcast in 1989 and considered the company's arguments. In a letter to Great American officials dated Thursday, the FCC agreed with the company's assertion that two skits in question were not indecent. But the commission said that material in several other programs ``fit squarely within our definition of indecency.'' Station manager Chris Wheat said the company had not decided whether to appeal. The fines stem from a complaint filed by John R. Price, a Carmel, Ind., lawyer who founded Decency in Broadcasting.

DOC.HEAD: Brief Biography of Liberia's Samuel Doe
With PM-Liberia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a brief profile of Liberian leader Samuel K. Doe:

Samuel K. Doe was born on May 6, 1950, in Tuzon, Grand Gedeh County. He attended R.E.B. Richardson Baptist Junior High School and the Ministry of National Defense Radio and Communication School in Monrovia. Doe joined the Liberian Army in 1969. As a master sergeant, he led the bloody coup on April 12, 1980, that ended the rule of President William Tolbert, who was killed. Doe's presidency has been characterized by numerous coup attempts, murders and detentions of opposition leaders and suppression of the country's press. He permitted elections in October 1985. When opposition parties appeared to have won the voting, Doe's men burned and destroyed ballots. The election commission Doe had appointed declared him the winner. The election rigging triggered the worst violence yet under Doe's rule. At least 1,500 people were estimated to have died, including Brig. Gen. Thomas Quiwonkpa, who led a coup attempt.
