Quiwonkpa had been a popular commander from Nimba County and his killing made his home area a fertile base for the Dec. 24, 1989, invasion of Liberia by rebel leader Charles Taylor.

DOC.HEAD: Brief Biography of Liberian Rebel Leader Charles Taylor
With PM-Liberia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a brief profile of Liberian rebel leader Charles Taylor.

Charles Taylor, 42, received a bachelor's degree in economics from Bentley College in Waltham, Mass. He returned to Liberia from the United States, where he worked as a factory mechanic, after Samuel Doe took power in a 1980 military coup. Doe named Taylor head of the General Services Administration. Taylor fled to the United States in 1983 to escape charges of embezzlement. He was arrested in the United States but escaped before he could be extradited. Taylor's revolt began Dec. 24, 1989, when he crossed the Ivory Coast border into Liberia with a small band of men. They accused Doe of corruption, mismanagement and human rights abuses. Taylor based his men in Nimba County, an area hostile to Doe. Doe's foces responded with savage attacks on tribal groups that supported Taylor. International agencies say hundreds were killed, and the atrocities appeared to have increased support for Taylor. As a civilian, however, Taylor insists he is different from Doe, who made his career in the military. He said he was leading ``a grass-roots civilian uprising to get rid of a dictator'' but that he harbored no dictatorial ambitions himself.

DOC.HEAD: Liberia at-a-Glance
With PM-Liberia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are some facts and figures on Liberia:

THE LAND: The West African nation is bordered by Ivory Coast, Guinea and Sierra Leone and covers 42,900 square miles _ about the size of Ohio. The coastal plain gives way to rocky cliffs, and strong tides make access to the Atlantic Ocean difficult. The highest elevations are in the northern highlands, which rise up to 4,500 feet. The capital is Monrovia.

THE PEOPLE: The population is estimated at about 2.5 million, including 16 principal tribal groups and about 50,000 descendants of freed American slaves who founded the country. English is the official language. The vast majority of the country practices traditional African religions.

THE ECONOMY: Even before the rebel insurgency began, the economy was near collapse, although Liberia possesses some of the richest iron ore in the world. The country has been unable to pay its foreign debt, and it has been suspended by the International Monetary Fund. Mining has earned more than 64 percent of Liberia's foreign exchange but agriculture has remained the main employer.

THE HISTORY: In 1822, freed American slaves visited Liberia and began settlements. They declared Liberia an independent republic in 1847. Descendants of the freed slaves, called Americo-Liberians, dominated the country until then-Master Sgt. Samuel K. Doe led a military coup on April 12, 1979. He was popular with the majority of Liberians, who resented the dominance of the Americo-Liberians. Doe headed a military government until October 1985, when elections were held. He claimed victory, but opposition parties and independent observers said the vote was rigged. On Dec. 24, 1989, former Doe aide Charles Taylor invaded with a small band of men from Ivory Coast. Taylor said he intended to topple Doe's government.

DOC.HEAD: Teen-Age Assault Victim Fights Back With Self-Defense Book
LaserPhoto MP3
DOC.TEXT: A teen-age girl roughed up by a man who pulled her from her bicycle and dragged her into woods is fighting back with a self-defense book for her peers. At first, Amber Erling couldn't bear to stay home alone after the 1989 attack, when she was 14.She enrolled in karate to help regain her confidence and before long was holding self-defense workshops with her karate instructor and mother. Prevention is the main lesson of the book, called ``Safe & Sound: A Parent's Guide on Self-Protection for Kids.'' ``I figure if I can save one person, it will work,'' said Amber, now 15 and a high school sophomore. Amber's mother, Susan Erling, said her 90-pound, 4-foot-11 daughter was wearing ballet practice clothes when a man in a car pulled alongside her as she rode her bicycle on a Brooklyn Park street near her home. The man grabbed Amber's moving bike and dragged her into the car as she kicked, screamed and bit him. He drove to a nearby park and dragged her out of the car and into the woods, where her screams attracted residents. The attacker fled when a man came running to her aid. ``Since we can't always take the bad guys off the streets, we need to make their disgusting job of attacking kids much tougher,'' Amber said in a statement promoting the book. ``We need to teach kids how to be imperfect victims, the kind of victims that child attackers hate.'' In many cases, efforts to ward off an attacker are just what experts advocate. Allen Garber, an FBI supervisory special agent in Minneapolis, advises parents to instruct their children to create attention by making noise if they're attacked. ``Child abductors don't want attention,'' Garber said. Mrs. Erling and Amber's karate teacher, E. Gordon Franks, suggest in the book that children should jab or bite attackers if they can't flee immediately, unless the attacker is armed. As law enforcement officials recommend, the book advocates submission in the face of weapons. ``Although martial arts schools may teach a kid how to directly defend against a particular weapon, we feel that it's wiser and safer for a child not to directly resist at all,'' the book says. ``Instead, a child should resist in an indirect way by looking for an opportunity to escape when the attacker is distracted or slightly off-guard.'' The book also warns against the danger of only a little knowledge of self-defense for children. ``Unfortunately, there are drawbacks to giving children just a brief education in self-defense, especially if the child somehow gets an over-confident or invincible attitude as a result,'' the book says. The mother, daughter and karate teacher had the book published themselves. The first printing of 5,000 books has nearly sold out. Mrs. Erling said they are planning a second run. Mrs. Erling and Franks spent about $7,500 each on the endeavor, Mrs. Erling said. The book sells for $5.95. A videotape, book and curriculum guide cost $100 and have been ordered by about 10 Minnesota school districts.

DOC.HEAD: Marchers Protest Mohawk Bridge Blockade
DOC.TEXT: Canadians landlocked by Mohawk Indians blockading a commuter bridge have staged an impromptu march that ended in a brief but tense confrontation with police in riot gear. About 2,000 people marched on foot for two miles Friday night through town, said Chateauguay police constable Raymond Picard. There were no injuries. Chateauguay is on the southwestern border of the Kahnawake reserve, where Mohawks have blocked the Mercier bridge over the St. Lawrence River to Montreal for more than a week. About 150 Indian chiefs from across the nation Friday called on Prime Minister Brian Mulroney to reconvene Parliament to deal with the ``national crisis.'' They also called on police to withdraw from barricades in Oka, a town 18 miles west of Montreal, where authorities are locked in an armed standoff with Mohawks who claim land there as ancestral territory. The Indians are trying to block a plan by municipal officials to build a golf course addition on the disputed land. A shootout between Indians and Canadian police at Oka on July 11 left one police officer dead, though it was not clear whether the officer died from police or Mohawk gunfire. Mohawks in Chateauguay blockaded the Mercier bridge in support of the Indians in Oka. The protest started at 9:30 p.m. with 300 marchers at the border of Chateauguay and the Mohawk reserve, where police have manned barricades to keep people away from the Indian blockade 100 yards down the road. Others joined the march as it wound through town and returned to the barricades. Protesters toppled a 100-yard length of metal barricades set up by police. About 150 officers from the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, and the town and provincial police forces, formed a line to keep marchers off the reservation. The police wore riot helmets and carried billy clubs. Chateauguay residents are angry over the bridge blockade, which forces a detour of up to two hours for workers who commute to Montreal. ``Close the Mercier, open the 30 highway!'' the marchers chanted in French. They referred to plans for a new commuter highway, Route 30, which would bypass the reservation. Marchers complained that provincial and local leaders have failed to act on the proposed highway. If that road were built, future clashes with Mohawks would not disrupt traffic, protesters said. The marchers were escorted by half a dozen police cars, and traffic was blocked as the marchers filled several main roads. About 100 cars joined the procession. One woman rushed from her house in bare feet and a white bath robe to join the march. The protesters went to Chateauguay Mayor Jean-Bosco Bourcier's home to complain about local leaders' inaction over the transportation problem. Bourcier was not home. Most of the protesters had dispersed by 1 a.m., officials said. Earlier this week, crowds tried to push their way through police barricades, burned effigies of Mohawks and taunted the Indians with war whoops.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Returns Sealed Verdict in McMartin Child Molestation Case
DOC.TEXT: A jury deliberating the fate of the only remaining defendant in the 7-year-old McMartin Pre-School molestation case has returned its first sealed verdict and resumed consideration of seven other charges. ``It's almost like waiting to wonder if you're going to get the electric chair or if they're going to let you go,'' Raymond Buckey told reporters Friday after the first verdict was delivered. Jurors in Buckey's second trial heard nearly three months of testimony and have been discussing the case for two weeks. The jury appeared to be following the same procedure used by the jury in Buckey's first trial, which ended earlier this year. That jury submitted separate verdicts in sealed envelopes, but none was announced until all of the verdicts were reached. A clerk in the court of Superior Court Judge Stanley Weisberg said the first verdict was sealed and would remain that way for the time being. Jurors were told to continue their talks. Buckey, 32, is charged with molesting three young girls at his family's now-defunct Manhattan Beach nursery school in the early 1980s. He and his mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, 63, were acquitted of 52 molestation charges on Jan. 18 after a trial lasting nearly three years. The jury in that trial deadlocked on 13 counts against Buckey alone, and District Attorney Ira Reiner decided to retry him on eight of those charges. In the second trial, the prosecution relied heavily on the testimony of the three girls, now in adolescence, who had trouble remembering events alleged to have occurred when they were toddlers. However, they said Buckey molested them. Buckey took the witness stand and swore he never molested any children. The case is the nation's longest criminal court proceeding.

DOC.HEAD: `Household Managers' Trained To Make Life a Little Less Complex
DOC.TEXT: Move over Alfred, Mr. French and Lurch. Take a hike Jeeves. A new breed of butler is standing at the door, ready to take the sting out of daily life. But, please. Sweep the word butler under the rug. Now it's ``household manager,'' thank you very much. From a Victorian mansion where there's nary a speck of dust, the Starkey Institute for Household Management began cranking out the next generation of helpers in January. They're a far cry from the crusty, pursed-lipped Englishman good at answering the front door and serving tea. Mary Starkey, the institute's president and founder, says her graduates are trained to perform myriad tasks in today's complicated world, from balancing the family checkbook to knowing when the water heater needs maintenance. ``This business is not about cleaning someone's home. It's about helping to run their daily lives,'' she says. The institute was conceived on the basis of studies that American households, especially those with two incomes, require specialized management, Starkey says. Her students, about 50 so far, agree. And they don't have much in common with stereotypical butlers popularized by television's Mr. French of ``Family Affair,'' Lurch of ``The Addams Family,'' Alfred of ``Batman,'' or Jeeves from the Bertie Wooster books by P.G. Wodehouse. Ginny Spencer was a successful real estate agent who dabbled in catering. She heard about the institute from Sandy Wischmeyer, a caterer and the school's director of curriculum. Spencer liked the idea so much that at 53, she decided to change careers. ``The program is just wonderful,'' Spencer says. ``There's a definite need for this kind of industry. I feel lucky to be in on the ground floor.'' The institute is housed in a 10,000-square-foot Victorian mansion that is impeccably decorated with antiques. The mansion gives the students hands-on experience, Starkey says. Starkey acknowledges the household manager idea is not widely popular in the United States, but she says it's catching on. Tuition for the eight-week program is $4,000, which covers 300 hours of education. The price may seem a bit steep to some, but Starkey has a decisive defense. ``Where else would you train household managers but in their workplace? And where else can you go to school for two months and come out qualified for a job that pays $18,000 a year? It's a perfect setup,'' Starkey says. Students cover seven general areas during the eight-week program _ organization, cleaning and maintenance of the household; fine dining; entertaining; clothing and travel; art; security and finance; and, perhaps most important of all, finding themselves jobs. ``We want them to leave with a repertoire of management, organization skills, recipes _ overall knowledge of anything and everything that can happen in a household,'' Starkey says. Graduates with no prior experience in a service-oriented profession can expect to earn between $18,000 and $30,000 a year plus living expenses, Starkey says. If a student has experience, say in a hotel or restaurant, $24,000 to $40,000 is a reasonable salary. Starkey runs her own placement agency, which she began nine years ago. She started the agency mainly to place nannies and baby sitters. Starkey receives 30 to 40 telephone calls a week from people needing one of her students and 150 calls a week from prospective students. She's currently trying to assemble a staff of 20 to help a wealthy entrepreneur run his island estate. ``We may have to hurry this current class along a little,'' Starkey joked.

DOC.HEAD: Ship That Caused Nation's Worst Oil Spill Afloat Again
LaserPhoto GO3 of July 20
DOC.TEXT: The former Exxon Valdez is afloat again after a $30 million repair job to its hull, which was mangled when the tanker struck a reef and caused the nation's worst oil spill. The vessel, renamed the Exxon Mediterranean, was maneuvered Friday night from the dry dock where it spent 11 months being rebuilt to a shipyard pier a quarter-mile away in San Diego Bay. Its engines, pumps and other machinery will be tested before two weeks of sea trials. ``They'll make sure everything runs and there's no leaks in any of the systems. It's basic operating _ like idling a car,'' shipyard spokesman Fred Hallett said. ``At sea, they'll go full speed ... putting her through her maximum paces and making sure not only that she works, but that she works to the (specifications) she's supposed to.'' Repairs on the ship began last August after it was towed 2,500 miles from Alaska to the dry dock where it was built and launched in 1986. Workers replaced the single-hulled ship's mangled steel with 3,000 tons of new, inch-thick steel. The 24-hour process of flooding the dry dock and ballasting the ship began late Thursday. Robert Weatherford, a business and planning manager for Exxon Shipping Co., said at a news conference aboard the tanker that ``the refloating is a big milestone in returning this vessel to service.'' The 987-foot-long ship, the largest tanker in Exxon's 13-ship fleet, will be thoroughly tested 100 to 150 miles offshore, away from ``shipping traffic lanes that run up and down the California coast,'' said its captain, Mike Stalzer. The testing also will determine whether the vessel obtains certification as a seaworthy vessel, said Coast Guard inspector Lt. Bill Uberti, who will be aboard the ship during the trial run. Exxon denies that the renaming of the ship and its relocation to Middle East oil routes were related to last year's spill. Fully loaded, the vessel is too big for any U.S. Pacific ports and declining oil production in Alaska has reduced the need for such large tankers on the West Coast. The ship spilled almost 11 million gallons of oil after it struck a reef in Alaska's Prince William Sound on March 24, 1989, fouling hundreds of miles of coastline and killing untold numbers wildlife. After the seaworthiness tests are finished next month, the ship and its 20-member crew are to return to San Diego for supplies before heading for its new base of operations, Stalzer said. The tanker, which holds nearly 1.4 million barrels of crude, will stop in Singapore en route to ports in Egypt and Turkey where it will be loaded. The tanker will continue to carry U.S. registry and an American crew.

DOC.HEAD: Nobility Gives a Lift to High Fashion Showings
By DANIELA PETROFF
DOC.TEXT: A dinner-fashion show given by Roman prince-designer Giovanni Torlonia, the famed Spanish Steps as a runway and a gala hosted by Princess Marina Doria of Savoia combined to ennoble the sagging image of Italian couture. With all the partying and aristocratic elbow-rubbing it was more of a high society than high fashion week, with almost as many elegant clothes seen off the runway as on. The weeklong showings for next fall and winter ended Friday. Talk of the town was the descent on Rome by Marina Doria, wife of Victor Emmanuel IV, son of the last king of Italy. The royal family was exiled from Italy when the country became a republic in 1946, and the male heirs banned from returning even for a visit. However, judging from the scramble for invitations to the blue-blooded event in honor of Italian designers, monarchic nostalgia still lingers in the Italian capital. Despite the show of strength on the Spanish Steps and the top drawer guest lists, Italian couture is having problems. Whereas Milan, home of Italy's ready-to-wear, has given Paris a run for its money, Italian couture with headquarters in Rome, has maintained its clients at home, but lost a good chunk of the international market to Paris in the past several years. The greatest blow to its image was the desertion at the beginning of the year by Valentino, who now shows both his ready-to-wear and high fashion collections in Paris. Several years ago Milanese designer Gianfranco Ferre brought new blood to Rome by showing his couture collection in the city, but he too has abandoned Rome for Paris where he designs couture for Dior. Another of this week's most sought-after events was the presentation of his evening wear collection by Prince Giovanni Torlonia. It was the first couture collection of the young designer, sole heir to the vast Torlonia fortune, and also first member of the age-old dynasty to go to work. To best set off his sumptuous gowns, Torlonia chose young ladies of Roman aristocracy as models, who looked like they stepped out of gilt-framed ancestral paintings as they walked through the halls of the family's Renaissance palace in downtown Rome. A stone's throw from the Torlonia homestead are the Spanish Steps which for the past five years have served as backdrop for the grand finale of the Rome fashion week, with couture and ready-to-wear designers alike parading their wares for next year's winter fashion. Thursday night 18 of Italy's top designers, including Armani, Valentino, Versace, Fendi and Ferre showed the best of their evening wear on the moonlit steps. For the mega production which was televised around the world each designer chose a celebrity to accompany the collection. Thus actress Johanna Pakula made her way down the steps in a gray chiffon sequined gown for Armani, while Anthony Quinn lent a supporting arm to a red cashmere clad model for Laura Biagiotti. Anthony Delon, son of French actor Alain Delon, was all too happy to escort his lady down the stairs, as she flashed her legs in a super-mini brown silk sequined dress by Pino Lancetti. Valentino preferred to let his lady stand alone, sending a stunning Ornella Muti in a 1965 red chiffon Valentino floor-length gown down the spectacular runway. Hollywood favorite Gianni Versace stole the show when he sent top model Jennifer Flavin in an ultra-tight sequined jump suit slowly down the steps and into the arms of current boyfriend Sylvester Stallone. In general the high fashion look for next year's chillier weather is either super short and sexy or long flouncy and elegant. Sequins and elaborate detailing abound. Heels are very high _ the models who tottered down the Spanish Steps could tell a tale _ and jewelry is discreet playing heavily on the earring. Makeup is demure. Boyish haircuts are out, long loose and softly curled is in. Aside from the traditional black evening gown, brightend by spangles (the best were seen at Mila Schoen) favorite colors are electric shades of red, blue, green and purple.

DOC.HEAD: In S&L Frauds, Many Headed to Jail, Thornburgh Says
DOC.TEXT: Imposing jail sentences on people convicted in major savings and loan fraud cases is often more important than the amount of time they eventually serve, the nation's top prosecutor says. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said 78 percent of the people convicted of large-scale fraud during the last two years landed in prison, and they received prison terms ranging from 30 days to 30 years. ``In the white-collar cases, it's the imposition of the jail time, often more than the length of the jail time, that's important,'' Thornburgh said Friday. White-collar criminals are less accustomed to hearing a jail door slam behind them than drug traffickers or violent criminals, Thornburgh told a law enforcement group that coordinates financial institution fraud investigations in the area. A study completed by Thornburgh's office this week found that 329 people have been indicted and 213 convicted. ``We are seeking jail time in every case a major fraud has occurred,'' Thornburgh said. ``We're going to be busy in this area for the foreseeable future.'' The savings and loan crisis should remain a high priority for at least the next five years because 530 thrifts remain under investigation, he said. Thornburgh reiterated that there is no need for a special prosecutor to investigate President Bush's son, Neil, a former director of the failed Silverado Savings & Loan in Denver. ``I'm not aware of evidence of any allegations from a credible source that Mr. Bush has committed any criminal wrongdoing,'' he said. Earlier Friday, Thornburgh criticized a major civil rights bill passed this week by the U.S. Senate. The measure, which is intended to protect women and minorities from job discrimination, is opposed by the president. ``The bill cannot be one that promotes the notion of quotas,'' Thornburgh said at an 8th Circuit judicial conference. ``Workers should not have to anticipate that employment decisions will be made by numbers.''

``It is my hope that the court during my years of service has built a legacy of interpretation of the Constitution and federal laws to make them responsive to the needs of the people whom they were intended to benefit and protect. This legacy can and will withstand the test of time.'' _ Justice William J. Brennan in a statement on his resignation.

``I hugged a Russian and I hugged an American ... I found that each had a heartbeat and a soul and humanity.'' _ The Rev. Jesse Jackson during the opening of a Soviet-American exchange center at the Goodwill Games in Seattle.

``It has been, as you might imagine, a day of great exhilaration and excitement for me and my family ... It has been what we believe to be a major step in the right direction and what has been a long and difficult ordeal.'' _ Former Marine Lt. Col. Oliver North after learning a federal appeals court overturned one of his Iran-Contra convictions and ordered the review of two others.

DOC.HEAD: Driver Arrested in Crash of Bus Carrying American Students
DOC.TEXT: The driver of a bus that overturned, killing two American teen-agers studying at Oxford University, has been arrested on reckless driving charges, police said. All of the 59 others on board, most of them also American students, were injured in the accident Thursday. John Radcliffe Hospital in Oxford reported Friday that 16 people were still hospitalized. One was in intensive care. The driver of the double-decker bus, Gan Sharma, 40, was taken into custody Thursday night and charged with causing death by reckless driving, police said. They said alcohol was not a factor in the accident. Sharma was slightly injured. He was released on bail Friday pending further investigation, said Chief Inspector Laurie Fray of the Thames Valley police. The bus was carrying gifted U.S. students who were taking a four-week summer school course at Oxford University's Magdalen College. The vehicle toppled as it turned off a highway near Wheatley, six miles east of Oxford, police said. They identified the dead as students Lawrence Levine, 16, of Chappaqua, N.Y., and Autumn Dubose, 18, of Lilburn, Ga. Fray said police will question Marilyn Whiteman, who said Thursday the bus had passed her traveling 80 to 85 mph just before the crash. The British highway speed limit is 70 mph. She said it suddenly turned left at the Wheatley turnoff without signaling and went out of control. At Radcliffe Hospital, U.S. Ambassador Henry Catto spoke to the injured and to parents who flew in from the United States. Brad Becker, 16, of Piedmont, Calif., told the ambassador there was panic on the bus when it went out of control. ``I said, `Oh my God!' and people started screaming. The bus just made it onto the grass and fell over. If it had fallen into the freeway, we'd all have plummeted into the path of cars. We'd have been killed _ all of us,'' he said. Becker suffered a broken vertebra. Diedre Walsh, a spokeswoman for the Oxford Advanced Studies Program in New York, said talks were under way at Magdalen College to decide whether the course should continue. The Advanced Studies Program in New York organized the trip.

DOC.HEAD: United Auto Workers Union Plans to Stick to Past Bargaining Strategy
DOC.TEXT: The United Auto Workers will not give Chrysler Corp. a contract that varies from pacts reached with others in the Big Three, the union's president says. The union's president, Owen Bieber, made the promise Friday, shortly after talks opened with Chrysler. Negotiations began Wednesday with General Motors Corp. and Thursday with Ford Motor Co. The union will not divert from its past strategy of ``pattern bargaining'' with all three companies until sometime around Labor Day, then selecting a strike target. Talks at the other two companies would be suspended. A contract reached at the target then would be taken to the other two companies. Published reports have speculated that Chrysler may break the pattern because of its financial problems. ``Abandoning the pattern concept will not solve problems,'' Bieber said. ``It will create even more. Chrysler would gain nothing, but lose a great deal of morale.'' Chrysler, the nation's No. 3 automaker behind GM and Ford, faces the toughest financial tests at the start of talks. Contracts expire Sept. 14. Chrysler Vice President Anthony St. John, the company's lead negotiator, was the only one among company and union officials to talk about proposals. Among three proposals St. John mentioned Friday was one that would establish a multi-employer health-care trust. Such a proposal has drawn cool receptions at GM and Ford. The UAW had no reaction Friday. ``We are not constrained from establishing, with union agreement, a multi-employer trust with (companies) other than Ford and GM ... although I would hope that they would have an interest as well,'' St. John said. ``It could be a supplier or series of suppliers.'' Negotiators from each of the Big Three have said containing health-care costs is a high priority in the talks. In 1989, GM said it spent about $3 billion in health-care costs, Ford spent about $813 million and Chrysler shelled out $684 million. St. John said under a multi-employer program, the size of the group covered by the plan could be huge, which would drive down costs. Also, he said, the companies could avoid increased costs anticipated in 1993 when new Financial Accounting Standards Board regulations could take effect. Chrysler says it currently funds health-care and pension costs on a pay-as-you-go basis. The new regulations would require companies to set aside money for anticipated costs, which Chrysler figures to be about $7 per hour per employee. That works out to just less than $200 million annually. Chrysler is expected to report by the end of the month that its second-quarter earnings were about half of the $341 million it made during the period last year.

DOC.HEAD: Black Man Hit By Truck After White Man Chases Him
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS to raise reference to Howard Beach attack; edits throughout. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: In a case with echoes of the Howard Beach racial attack, a black man walking with his white girlfriend was critically injured when a white man chased him into the path of an oncoming truck. Herbert Jennings, 38, of Baltimore, was in a coma today with a severe head injury at the University of Maryland Shock Trauma Center after Thursday night's attack, the hospital said. Daniel Porter, 21, of Baltimore, was charged with assault and reckless endangerment for chasing Jennings on a street near the girlfriend's home. Porter was released Friday on $25,000 bail. Jennings' 32-year-old girlfriend, whom police would not identify, and several other people were questioned, and others may be charged, police said. The attack occurred in the mostly white, working-class neighborhood of Highlandtown, a southeast Baltimore enclave ringed by predominantly black, working-class districts, police spokesman Dennis Hill said. The incident bore similarities to a 1986 attack by a group of whites on three black men in the Howard Beach section of Queens in New York City. One of the blacks was struck by a car and killed as he fled across a highway. Three of the whites were convicted of manslaughter, assault and conspiracy. In Baltimore, two white men in a pickup truck taunted Jennings and his girlfriend as they walked along the street, police said. Porter and two other white men approached the couple moments later, police said. Porter yelled to the men in the truck, asking if they wanted him to attack Jennings, whom he called by a racial epithet, police said. A man in the truck yelled, ``Yes,'' and Jennings ran, with Porter in pursuit. Jennings slipped and fell after running a short distance and was accidentally struck by another pickup truck, Hill said. The driver of that truck was not charged. The girlfriend was not injured. The first truck, whose occupants started the incident, sped away, Hill said. He said police don't believe the whites knew Jennings or his girlfriend. Mayor Kurt Schmoke said race relations have improved since the riots of the 1960s in Baltimore, whose population is roughly 60 percent black. ``I can point to more harmony among races in Baltimore now than I could let's say 20 or 30 years ago,'' said Schmoke, the city's first black mayor. Police said Highlandtown has no history of racial confrontation. In a separate incident several miles away early Wednesday, a black man was stabbed to death when he and a friend were attacked by a group of white men. Police had no clear evidence that the incident was racially motivated, Hill said, but he added, ``We are treating it as if it were.''

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper: City Opera to Keep Nude Characters in Fall Production
DOC.TEXT: The general director of the New York City Opera says three naked virgins will remain in a fall production, despite internal fears that a federal grant could be jeopardized, a newspaper reported today. The company will not change its plans for ``Moses und Aron,'' the official, Christopher Keene, was quoted as saying in The New York Times. Questions about the virgins surfaced in an internal memorandum from Marc A. Dorfman, who handles foundation and government gifts to the opera company. He wondered in the memo whether the virgins' presence could violate new obscenity guidelines issued last week by the National Endowment for the Arts, which gave the opera company a special grant for the production. NEA spokesman Virginia Falck said it was unlikely the virgins will lead to problems. The guidelines, based on U.S. Supreme Court precedent, say an obscene work is one which the average person would find ``appeals to the prurient interests,'' which ``depicts or describes sexual conduct in a patently offensive way,'' and which ``lacks serious literary, artistic, political or scientific value.'' Keene said Friday that ``Moses und Aron'' doesn't qualify. ``We do not think that `Moses und Aron' or any other production we are doing is obscene in term's of the Supreme Court's definition.'' ``Moses und Aron'' is set to debut Sept. 22. The unfinished opera by Austrian composer Arnold Schoenberg is considered one of the 20th century's masterpieces.

DOC.HEAD: Case Of Art Imitating Life: Rock Concert With Styrofoam Berlin Wall
DOC.TEXT: A huge styrofoam wall at the site of the shattered Berlin Wall is the setting for a concert by ex-Pink Floyd guitarist Roger Waters, Joni Mitchell, Van Morrison, Sinead O'Connor and others. About 180,000 fans were expected at tonight's outdoor spectacle that is raising money for victims of disasters, and whose centerpiece is a performance of Pink Floyd's 11-year-old rock epic, ``The Wall.'' Waters, who composed ``The Wall'' but has since left the group for a solo career, is headlining the extravaganza. The celebrated record, which was made into a movie in 1982, is about alienation and the manipulation of the minds of individuals by governments, but not specifically about the Berlin Wall. A giant 600-foot-long and 60-foot-high structure made of 2,500 styrofoam bricks will come crashing down at the concert's climax. The concert also will feature a six-story inflatable pig and an equally large teacher, two characters in Pink Floyd's atmospheric, other-worldly music. Workers for weeks have been building the gigantic stage on 35 acres of Potsdamer Platz, the historic square of old Berlin that was converted into a desolate no-man's land by the building of the Berlin Wall. All of the Berlin Wall at Potsdamer Platz has been torn down in the last few months in anticipation of the unification of the German states in December. The stretch of land between the two sections of wall, where East Germans were once shot and killed while fleeing to the West, was expected to hold about 180,000 concertgoers for tonight's show. More than 160,000 tickets have been sold at $30 each and 20,000 additional tickets were to go on sale today, said spokeswoman Emma Jenks. ``The stage crew alone is literally hundreds and hundreds of people,'' she said Friday. Others slated to perform tonight included Cindy Lauper, James Galway, Thomas Dolby, Albert Finney, model Jerry Hall, the Chieftains, the Scorpions, the Hooters and the East Berlin Rundfunk Symphony Orchestra and Radio Choir. The concert cost $8 million to stage and profits from the show, as well as a planned album and video, are to go to the Memorial Fund for Disaster Relief, Jenks said. The London-based fund was set up last year to create a permanent reservoir of cash for disaster relief. The European Community on Friday said it would donate $378,000 to the concert. Jenks said organizers would not know until after the concert how much of the proceeds, expected to approach $10 million, would go to the disaster relief fund after expenses.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Cosmonauts Nearly Ran Out of Oxygen
DOC.TEXT: Two cosmonauts nearly ran out of oxygen when a sticky hatch prevented them from re-entering their space station, but they will take another space walk next week to repair the door, according to a newspaper report. The trouble occurred Tuesday while the cosmonauts were outside their space station making repairs, said the Communist Party newspaper Pravda. Pravda, in its Friday editions, quoted Yuri Isaulov, a ground controller at the Soviet Mission Control Center in Kaliningrad, as saying cosmonauts Anatoly Solovyev and Alexander Balandin will make another space walk Thursday ``to put things in order.'' The sticky hatch was the latest in a series of problems the cosmonauts have faced during their six-month mission. Solovyev and Balandin went outside the Mir space station to fix thermal insulation that was damaged during the launch of the Soyuz TM-9 capsule they must use to return to Earth. The strenuous space walk took two hours longer than planned, and the cosmonauts could not re-enter the spacecraft because of the sticky hatch, Soviet media reported. Their oxygen was running dangerously low and they were forced to use an emergency porthole on another part of the space station complex to get back inside, seven hours after their exit. Once inside, the cosmonauts apparently closed an inner hatch to seal one end of the airlock compartment that leads to the troublesome outside hatch. Isaulov told Pravda that the outside hatch is ``slightly ajar,'' leaving the airlock compartment unsealed. ``This is not a normal situation and we would not like it to continue,'' he said. ``So, we have informed the crew that they would have to make another space walk on July 26 to put things in order.'' In their rush to get back into the space station, the cosmonauts also left behind some ladders on a work platform where they were fixing the insulation on the outside of the Soyuz capsule. Ground controllers were studying videotapes of the exterior of the space complex to see if that would cause a problem, Pravda said. The ladders and work platform attached to the Soyuz might hinder the capsule when it separates from the Mir complex, said James Oberg, author of several books on the Soviet space program, in an interview from his Texas home. The thermal insulation protects the capsule while in space and is separate from the shield that deflects heat during re-entry. The cosmonauts have been in space since Feb. 11. The ground controllers plan to bring them home in the Soyuz capsule on Aug. 9. They originally were scheduled to return July 30. A replacement crew is to be launched Aug. 1.

DOC.HEAD: T-Shirts an Issue Between Israeli Soldiers, Palestinians
DOC.TEXT: A new T-shirt emblazoned with the words ``Black Sunday'' is the latest source of friction between Palestinian youths and Israeli soldiers. The shirt is meant as a silent protest over the massacre of seven Arab laborers by an Israeli gunman on Sunday, May 20. The design includes drawings of seven bullet holes across the chest. Israel says the gunman was deranged. Israeli, Ami Popper, 21, is on trial for the slayings. Soldiers and border police have confiscated T-shirts from stores and in one case ordered two youths in the West Bank city of Bethlehem to take off the shirts and hand them over, Palestinian reporters say. A Palestinian youth was jailed after soldiers found him carrying a bag containing 40 ``Black Sunday'' shirts. He was released the next morning, but without the shirts.

DOC.HEAD: Rain Scattered East of the Mississippi
DOC.TEXT: Rain was scattered in the East early today and skies were mostly dry and clear in the West. A few showers and thunderstoms dampened the Midwest. Today's forecast called for heavy thunderstorms from the mid-Atlantic region across the Appalachians and mid-Mississippi Valley into the western Plains. Rain fell early today in Pittsburgh and Cincinnati, a harbinger of possible flash floods. Thunderstorms were scattered early today in the South. Rain fell in Chattanooga, Tenn., St. Louis and Charleston, S.C. Rain also fell early today in Iowa and Nebraska, and was likely to cover a wide swath of the central Plains and move into the central Rockies. The nation's high temperature Friday was 120 degrees at Death Valley, Calif. DOC.HEAD: Little Headway In First Day of Salvadoran Peace Talks
DOC.BYLINE: Leads with 4 grafs to move up Salvadoran reference. Pickup 5th graf `The talks...' ^By CARLOS SANDI
DOC.TEXT: A new round of Salvadoran peace talks between the U.S.-backed government and leftist rebels got off to a slow start, and they were overshadowed by reports of heavy fighting in El Salvador. U.N. mediator Alvaro de Soto said negotiators only scratched the surface of their agenda when the five days of talks opened Friday. ``They got into specific themes, but without going very deep into the negotiations process,'' he told a news conference. The Salvadoran army reported that six rebels were killed and seven wounded Thursday in heavy fighting with soldiers near Jucuapa, 68 miles east of the capital San Salvador. It said another rebel was wounded in fighting near Lolotique, 75 miles east of the capital. The talks are the third round of negotiations this year aimed at reaching a cease-fire in the 10-year-old Salvadoran civil war, which has claimed and estimated 72,000 lives. The rebels have promised to stage an all-out offensive if the negotiations fail to meet their expectations. The armed forces said in a statement that military patrols seized about 20 rebel anti-personnel mines Thursday in a raid at Tecoluca, 45 miles southeast of San Salvador. Guerrillas dynamited five power line towers, briefly blacking out eastern regions of the nation, the statement said. In Washington, State Department deputy spokesman Richard Boucher deplored the threat of a renewed offensive. He accused the rebel Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front of carrying out ``brutal assassinations'' directed at Salvadoran military personnel and their families. ``The purpose ... seems to be to polarize the situation further and to elicit a reaction from extremists on the right,'' he said, citing the recent killings of an off-duty officer and of an army major on his way to law school. The United States has been providing President Alfredo Cristiani's rightist government with more than $1 million a day in military and economic aid to keep the government and country running. Many U.S. lawmakers have accused the government of human rights violations and say the aid should be reduced or eliminated. Boucher said the left ``should put aside its tactics of assassination and violence and go to the table committed to a just peace.'' The left is demanding reform of the military and elimination of rightist death squads connected to the army as a prerequisite to a negotiated cease-fire. ``We demand that army members guilty of political crimes be purged,'' rebel negotiator Shafik Handal said. The army has maintained it will clean its house with no help from the rebels. The last round of talks in Mexico in June produced no accords after discussions got hung up on the subject. But army Col. Mauricio Vargas, head of the 3rd Infantry Brigade, expressed hopes that this round of talks will produce results. ``If there is the political will on both sides, we expect to reach accords. Even if they're not spectacular this will bring us closer to peace,'' Vargas said. Handal said the rebels plan to press for a reduction in El Salvador's 54,000-man military force and demand that the military be purged of officers who have violated human rights. The rebels also seek the dismantling of rightist death squads and elimination of compulsory military service, Handal said. Rights groups estimate more than 72,000 people have been killed since the war began in October 1979, most of them civilians slain by death squads. De Soto, a personal representative of U.N. secretary-general Javier Perez de Cuellar, is mediating this round of talks.

DOC.HEAD: Nine More Cubans Enter Spanish Embassy, Agency Reports, Doubling Total
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with news agency reporting nine more Cubans entering Spanish Embassy. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Cuba-Spain, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Nine more Cubans sought refuge in the Spanish Embassy in Havana before dawn today, bringing to 18 the number of asylum-seekers in the mission, the Spanish news agency EFE reported. The development comes a day after five Cubans entered the embassy. Four Cubans have taken refuge at the residence of the Italian ambassador, and other similar cases this month have caused friction between diplomats and the Communist government of Fidel Castro. Four Cubans today entered the Spanish Embassy grounds at about 1 a.m. ( 2 a.m. EDT), and five more gained access at about 3 a.m., EFE said in a dispatch from Havana. Officials at the Spanish Foreign Ministry in Madrid could not confirm the EFE report. The first group today crossed a neighboring property and entered the embassy by way of a terrace, while the second group scaled the embassy facade and broke a balcony while trying to enter the building, EFE said. All nine asylum-seekers were men who appeared to be between the ages of 25 and 40, EFE said. The new arrivals came two days after Spain suspended its entire $2.5 million 1990 aid package to Cuba Thursday to express its displeasure over Cuba's unusually harsh criticism of Spanish Foreign Minister Francisco Fernandez Ordonez. On Wednesday the Cuban Foreign Ministry blasted Ordonez in a three-page official statement, calling him a ``frustrated colonial administrator'' and a victim of ``historical amnesia.'' It threatened to send all the island's undesirable inhabitants to the 12-nation European Economic Community. Fernandez Ordonez had previously suggested that Castro would be cautious about allowing Cubans to leave because he new their departure would cause his regime to crumble. The first of the 18 refugees holed up in the Spanish embassy arrived July 11. Spain has said it would not turn over the Cubans in its embassy to Cuban authorites and would try to negotiate their departure outside Cuba. Five Cubans who spent a week in a Czechoslovak diplomat's apartment gave up their bid for asylum Thursday after receiving assurances they would not be prosecuted, according to reports from Havana. Diplomats accused Cuban police of violating diplomatic territory to make arrests, and a bitter dispute developed between Spain and its former colony after Cuban police seized one refugee on Spanish Embassy grounds. In Washington, Michael Kozak, a deputy assistant secretary of state, called in a Cuban diplomat on Friday to protest the Communist nation's claims that the United States encouraged Cubans to seek asylum in embassies. The State Department has called such allegations ``outrageous.'' The official Mexican news agency Notimex said U.S. and West German officials in Havana have denied Cuban allegations their countries were involved in a plot. The U.S. statement said Cuban agents tried several times to compromise U.S. officials in past months. The Cuban refugee problem has attracted widespread attention because it is reminiscent of the East German refugees who sought passage to the West at embassies in Eastern Europe last year. Their exodus helped precipitate the fall of East Germany's rigid Communist government. Albania, which like Cuba has refused to follow the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe in adopting democratic reforms, last week allowed hundreds of people who had entered embassies in its capital to leave for new lives in the West. In April 1980, thousands of disaffected Cubans jammed the Peruvian Embassy in Havana. Shortly thereafter, many joined what became the Mariel boat lift, which eventually took 125,000 Cubans to Florida.

DOC.HEAD: Nobel Peace Prize Committee Chairman Dies
DOC.TEXT: Nobel Peace Prize committee chairman Egil Aarvik, who used the Nobel Peace Prize to encourage human rights, has died. He was 77. Aarvik died Thursday at Norway's national hospital in Oslo. The cause of death was not disclosed. A retired journalist and Christian People's Party politician, Aarvik was appointed by Parliament to the Norwegian Nobel Committee in 1974 and became its chairman in 1982. Under his influence, the committee began to use the peace prize to encourage pro-democracy efforts and human rights. Some awards angered governments. Most recently, China criticized Aarvik when the Nobel Committee awarded the 1989 peace prize to the Dali Lama, Tibet's exiled leader. South African Bishop Desmond Tutu, the 1984 Nobel laureate, told newspapers today that the prize to Poland's Lech Welesa in 1983 ``and the recognition of the church's battle against apartheid were brave decisions that Aarvik has a great deal of the credit for.'' Aarvik was born on Dec. 12, 1912, in the central Norway town of Borsa. The son of laborer Juiius and Louise Aarvik wanted to be an auto mechanic as a youth, but went to work as a farmhand. His higher education was limited to a year at college and three months at Bible school. His journalism career began in 1946 with the Christian newspaper Dagsavisa, in Trondheim near his hometown. He also published a number of books. Aarvik was elected to Parliament in 1961 and served until 1977. He was minister of social affairs from 1965 to 1971 in a non-socialist coalition government. Aarvik is survived by his wife, Anna Cathrine, three sons, a daughter and 11 grandchildren. News reports said Norwegian writer Gidske Anderson is expected to succeed Aarvik. She would be the second woman to head the Nobel committee.

DOC.HEAD: Suspension of Grants Underscores Spain's Push for Change in Cuba
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `Last week...from Cuba.' with 2 to UPDATE with nine more Cubans entering Spanish Embassy; pickup 4th graf pvs, `Cuba calls...'
DOC.TEXT: Madrid's suspension of aid to Cuba underscores pressure for democratic change in the former Spanish colony and further isolates Fidel Castro at a time when his main benefactor, Moscow, is getting stingier. ``It's an abrupt and historic decision,'' said political scientist Manuel Alcantara, a professor of Latin American affairs at Madrid's Complutense University. ``Because of the events in Eastern Europe, Spain feels some kind of responsibility about Cuba, to work for change there.'' As of today, 18 Cubans were in the Spanish mission in Havana, the Spanish news agency EFE reported. Nine sought refuge today, it said, and on Friday five entered the embassy. The four others sought refuge last week. Spain says it will not expel the asylum-seekers and will try to negotiate their departure from Cuba. Cuba calls all those who have sought refuge in the Spanish, Czech and Italian missions ``scum'' and habitual vagrants. Spain's secretary of state for international cooperation, Luis Yanez, told reporters in Brussels on Thursday that Spain was suspending $2.5 million in direct grants-in-aid to Cuba, the country's total this year to the island that was a Spanish colony for 406 years until 1898. While the sum is not substantial, another Spanish Foreign Ministry official hinted Friday that the move probably would not be the last to try to pressure the government of President Fidel Castro to grant more freedom to Cubans. ``More measures will be necessary,'' said Yago Pico de Coana, director general for Latin American affairs. He said it would be imprudent to elaborate. Spain has also recalled its ambassador in Havana for consultations. Cuba already has had to cope with a trade embargo by the United States and a loss of support from the Soviet Union and from East European countries that shed their Communist governments since last year. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, whose reforms Castro has criticized, is not as forthcoming on aid as in the past. Castro repeatedly has rejected Western-style balloting and said his country has no need for Soviet-style reform _ despite pressure from Gorbachev. As criticism of Cuba has appeared in official Soviet media, Castro has called on Cubans to brace for possible cuts in the Soviets' $5 billion in yearly aid. U.S. sources last year said there had been substantial reductions already, as evidenced in the marked decline in the purchase of sugar, which the Soviet Union buys from Cuba at prices substantially higher than world market levels as a form of subsidy. Castro also has lost his two closest Caribbean allies _ Panama's Manuel Antonio Noriega, who was toppled in a U.S. invasion in December, and Nicaragua's leftist Sandinistas, who were defeated by a U.S.-backed opposition coalition in elections Feb. 25. Yanez said the Spanish aid cutoff effectively severed Cuba's ``umbilical cord'' with Spain that afforded access to the European Community. He said resumption of the aid was contingent on ``the resolution of problems through political channels.'' Cuba has been attempting to reach some kind of aid agreement with the 12-nation West European trading bloc but without success. A Spanish government spokesman, who is customarily not identified, denied that the decision to suspend aid represented a major shift in policy toward Cuba. He said the action was in keeping with remarks Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez made to Castro in March about the need for the Marxist nation to move toward democracy. Spain has maintained cordial ties throughout its own authoritarian and democratic administrations with the former colony. Both Gen. Francisco Franco and the democratically elected administrations that have governed Spain since his death in 1975 have assured Castro easy credit to purchase Spanish goods and finance long-term projects. Cuba's total commercial debt with Madrid is estimated at about $900 million, making Spain Cuba's second-most important creditor after the Soviet Union, to which Cuba owes an estimated $3 billion. The conservative Madrid daily ABC, an outspoken opponent of both the Castro and Gonzalez governments, pointed out that Yanez's annoucement didn't affect Spain's soft-loan program to Cuba, for which $11 million are earmarked this year _ nor its commercial credit and guarantee program designed to back up Spanish exports to Cuba. The Spanish Export Credit Insurance Co. held about $780 million in debts on exports to Cuba last year. Cuba consumes 15 percent of Spain's trade to Latin America, according to Economy Ministry figures.

DOC.HEAD: PLO Guerrillas, Syrian-Backed Militia Storm Hezbollah Stronghold
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs with casualty figures, attack on village near Jarjou; pickup 11th graf pvs, `At least...'
DOC.TEXT: Palestinian guerrillas and Syrian-supported Shiite Moslems today stormed southern positions of Iranian-backed Shiite fundamentalists behind a barrage of artillery and rocket fire. Police said at least 30 people, most believed to be fighters, were killed and 72 wounded in the battles. One Palestinian commander reported by radio from the embattled hilltop village of Jarjou that fighting was ``hand-to-hand and house-to-house.'' Jarjou was captured by the Shiite Moslem Amal militia's rival, Hezbollah _ or Party of God _ in fierce fighting Monday. The village is five miles north of Nabatiyeh, the Amal stronghold in southern Lebanon. The assault on Jarjou came on the sixth day of a battle between the Shiite factions in which more than 100 people have been killed and more than 300 wounded. The first attack began at 3 a.m. when about 300 Amal fighters and 250 Palestinian Liberation Organization guerrillas began fighting their way toward the hilltop village of Jarjou. It lies on the southwestern tip of an enclave controlled by the Shiite fundamentalist Hezbollah, or Party of God. The enclave is bordered to the east by Israel's self-designated ``security zone,'' an occupied strip of south Lebanon from which the Israelis frequently attack guerrilla groups. The escalating clashes so close to Israeli-held territory raised fears that it could provoke Israeli military action. Fighters belonging to the Palestine Liberation Organization had been trying to stop the fighting between the two Shiite groups and apparently to halt the Hezbollah advance toward Sidon, a southern port where PLO guerrillas are based. The Syrian-backed militia and the Palestinian guerrillas also have been enemies but they joined together to storm the Hezbollah positions. Reporters close to the battle zone said 40 PLO rocket launchers, each with 40 barrels, and dozens of Amal mortar batteries blasted Jarjou and five nearby Hezbollah-held hamlets for two hours before the first assault was launched. Another PLO-Amal force attacked Hezbollah positions along the northwestern flank of the fundamentalists' enclave. Police said the attackers were advancing into the village of Kfar Milki ``in savage fighting.'' That village, five miles northwest of Jarjou, was occupied by Hezbollah last January. At least 12 wounded Amal men were evacuated from Jarjou to hospitals in the market town of Nabatiyeh. One wounded militiamen told reporters as he was carried from an ambulance: ``It's hell in there. There are dozens of bodies scattered in the alleyways.'' In Beirut, an Amal communique said the assault force had taken half of Jarjou by midmorning. But an Hezbollah statement said the attackers were beaten back, ``leaving scores of dead behind.'' Black clouds of smoke hung over Jarjou as the Palestinian and Amal gunners pounded Hezbollah positions to prevent its fighters from moving up reinforcements through Jarjou's northern edge. PLO commanders estimated Hezbollah has about 300 fighters in Jarjou. A 600-man PLO force, drawn mainly from PLO chief Yasser Arafat's Fatah faction, deployed around Jarjou and other villages Tuesday ostensibly to stop the fighting. But their prime objective was to block Hezbollah's advance after it seized Jarjou. The PLO's main bases are in Sidon, 10 miles northwest of Jarjou, and Arafat does not want the Iranian-backed guerrillas threatening them or linking up with anti-Arafat radicals in the region. Hezbollah and Amal have been fighting off and on for three years for control of Lebanon's 1.2 million Shiites, the country's largest sect. More than 1,100 people have been killed and some 3,400 wounded in the inconclusive showdown between the Shiite rivals.

DOC.HEAD: Protesters Leave U.S. Consulate Building
DOC.TEXT: Seventeen blacks ended a sit-in demonstration today after spending the night outside the U.S. Consulate to protest alleged harrassment by South African police. The blacks accused police of harassing and intimidating residents in Tumahole, a township about 60 miles southwest of Johannesburg. The demonstrators asked the U.S. government to pressure South African authorities to stop the alleged intimidation. A police spokesman, Maj. Mike Lombard, said authorities had received no complaints about police actions in Tumahole. There have been no recent reports of major confrontations in Tumahole between police and residents. U.S. officials accepted a petition from the demonstrators Friday afternoon but refused to let them stay at the consulate on the 11th floor of a downtown Johannesburg office building. The demonstrators spent the night in a hallway outside the consulate offices and left the building today singing and dancing. Two years ago, three anti-apartheid activists escaped police detention and stayed at the consulate for more than a month. They left after the South African government promised the trio they would not be arrested again.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Isolate Jaffna from Rest of Sri Lanka
DOC.TEXT: Tamil rebels blew up the Elephant Pass causeway, cutting off the northern Jaffna peninsula from the rest of the island, military officials said today. The rebels control the entire peninsula with the exception of four beseiged military installations that remain under government control. The government sent trucks carrying food and medicine to Jaffna peninsula last week, but the Red Cross-escorted convoy is now stranded south of the demolished causeway, 30 miles south of Jaffna town, officials said. Military officials said the only other road leading to the peninsula is too small for heavy traffic. About 1 million people live on the 830 square mile peninsula. Jaffna is the stronghold of the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam militia, and has been the scene of some of the heaviest fighting since a new round of the civil war broke out on June 11. About 2,730 combatants have been killed since the rebels violated a 13-month cease-fire in June and renewed fighting. Tamil rebels took up arms in 1983 to fight alleged discrimination by the Sinhalese majority. At least 13,700 people have been killed in their drive to establish an independent homeland in the island's north and east. Tamils, who are mostly Hindu, make up 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people. Sinhalese, who are mostly Buddhist, control the government and the military and make up about 75 percent of the population. Tamil militants are seeking an independent homeland in the eastern and northern districts of Sri Lanka. On Friday, 17 Tamil rebels were killed. Residents of a mainly Tamil town said three civilians were also killed. Ten of the rebels were killed when their boat was blown up by a helicopter gunship near Vellavelli village south of Batticaloa, 135 miles east of Colombo. In Kalmunai, also near Batticaloa, troops ambushed and killed seven rebels, officials said. Batticaloa residents, contacted by telephone, said troops shot to death a Tamil woman, her son and another young Tamil man on Friday when they tried to escape a search operation. The residents, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the dead were known Tiger sympathizers.

DOC.HEAD: Sounds Beneath Rubble Raise Hopes Victims Still Alive; Toll Over 700
LaserPhoto MLA3
Ed: Leads with 10 grafs to UPDATE death toll. Pickup 11th, `Officials said...
DOC.TEXT: Filipino miners said they heard tapping sounds today beneath a hotel destroyed by an earthquake, raising hopes some victims may be alive five days after the temblor. The death toll rose to 767. More aftershocks rattled Baguio and Manila, 130 miles to the south, delaying rescue efforts and cracking walls of the Baguio cathedral. Seismologists said one measured 2 on the Richter scale in Manila and may have been stronger elsewhere. The official death toll from Monday's quake was 767. But officials said it may approach 1,000 because hundreds were feared dead in an industrial park and a remote farming area of Nueva Vizcaya province. Also today, Communist rebels declared a unilateral cease-fire in Manila and the quake-ravaged north. Right-wing military dissidents offered to do the same on Friday if the government suspended efforts to capture them. Miner Quilino Bagimbin said he crawled through a tunnel beneath the wrecked Hyatt Hotel and knocked four times against debris blocking access to the basement gymnasium, where about 10 people were believed trapped. Bagimbin said he heard four distinctive knocks in response. About 40 people remain unaccounted for at the Hyatt, whose terraced front collapsed during the quake. Another miner, John Dilla, said workers had been hearing the knocks since Friday night but that they were growing fainter. Recovery efforts were suspended early today so miners could strengthen the tunnel after strong aftershocks rocked the area. Five days after the earthquake, officials said reports of damage and deaths were still coming in from remote areas. Jose de Jesus, presidential relief coordinator, said 135 people were believed dead inside eight factories in Baguio but rescuers had not entered the buildings. De Jesus said 108 others were believed killed in landslides in one village in Nueva Vizcaya. The official tally showed 83 dead in Nueva Vizcaya. Officials said more than 900 people were feared stranded in a mountain pass along the border of Nueva Vizcaya and Nueva Ecija provinces. In Manila, President Corazon Aquino defended her government against criticism that it had been slow and ineffective in aiding victims, but the complaints persisted. Gangs of armed robbers and looters roamed Baguio after sundown. ``There's no sanitation,'' said Australian John Pike, 44, who was evacuated to Manila today. ``The situation is horrible and not much is being done. In a week there might be an outbreak of typhoid.'' Pike said the government's information network had collapsed and most people ``don't know where to get information on where to get relief goods or help.'' In a statement today to news organizations, the general command of the communist New People's Army promised to suspend attacks in Manila and central Luzon ``during this time of national tragedy.'' Rebel soldiers who tried to topple Mrs. Aquino in December made the same offer on Friday. Many leaders of the rebel movement are graduates of the Philippine Military Academy located in Baguio.

DOC.HEAD: Cambodia Government Calls on Khmer Rouge to Return to Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Restores dropped words in 3rd graf, `The radio... Pickup 4th, `The official...'
DOC.TEXT: Cambodia's Vietnamese-installed government today urged the Communist Khmer Rouge guerrilla group and its main supporter, China, to return to talks on arranging a cease-fire. But Khmer Rouge radio said today the guerrillas were preparing for a renewed attack on Kompong Thom, capital of the central province of the same name, 75 miles north of the national capital, Phnom Penh. The radio said hundreds of civilian supporters _ including children _ were voluntarily carrying supplies, weapons and ammunition to the guerrillas readying for the strike. The Khmer Rouge has been known to press civilians into service as porters to carry their supplies through the jungle. The official Cambodian news agency made the appeal for a return to talks while hailing this week's U.S. policy shift away from the Khmer Rouge and their non-Communist allies. The United States said Wednesday it was withdrawing its recognition of a guerrilla coalition's seat at the United Nations. At the same time, Washington will open talks with Vietnam on ending the Cambodian war. Cambodia's government in Phnom Penh has long rejected any settlement that would allow Pol Pot's Khmer Rouge to return to power. The Khmer Rouge killed hundreds of thousands of people in nearly four years of rule until Vietnam's 1978 invasion installed the current government. ``We hope the Khmer Rouge and their patron in Beijing will return to the negotiating table to resolve the Cambodian problem by peaceful means,'' the Cambodian news agency SPK said. ``As immediate steps,'' it said, they should cooperate in last month's agreement in Tokyo to begin a truce, stop receiving foreign military aid and participate in free elections under U.N. supervision. That agreement was signed by Cambodia's prime minister, Hun Sen, and Prince Norodom Sihanouk, whose non-Communist guerrilla group is allied in the coalition with the Khmer Rouge. But the Khmer Rouge boycotted the Tokyo talks because it said it was not being treated as an equal. China later said it did not support the agreement either. The agreement was to form a ``supreme national council'' to meet by July 31 to arrange a truce. The government of Hun Sen, Sihanouk and Son Sann, the leader of the third guerrilla party, all have appointed representatives to the council. The Khmer Rouge have not. ``The problem with the Tokyo agreement was that the Khmer Rouge was not involved. If they are not involved, there is no political solution,'' a spokesman in Sihanouk's Bangkok office, Roland Eng, said today. The guerrillas have significantly escalated their attacks, and some of their officials said a truce without an overall political settlement would only benefit the beleaguered Cambodian government. The government also has been weakened by internal dissent and a drastic loss of aid from the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Gain In Capital; U.S. Refuses Govt Request For Troops
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to UPDATE with State Department comment from today on Doe. Pickup 6th graf pvs, `Spokeswoman Margaret...'
DOC.TEXT: EDITORS: The following is based on a pool report from journalists in Monrovia, among them Associated Press correspondent Michael Goldsmith.

Rebels have tightened their noose around President Samuel Doe's mansion, seizing much of the capital and its port. Washington turned down a desperate appeal by government officials for U.S. troops to halt the fighting. Rebels in this West African country overran most of northern Monrovia on Friday, capturing the city's 2-square-mile port area in the northern suburb of Bushrod Island. They advanced toward the two bridges linking the island to the center of the city. Witnesses reported heavy government casualties but no precise figures. Shipping sources said two Liberian coast guard cutters were sunk in the port by gunfire. The rebels, led by ex-Doe aide Charles Taylor, accuse Doe's government of corruption and human rights abuses. They have seized most of this Ohio-sized country of 2.4 million people since they began fighting in December. In Washington, a State Department official said today that U.S. officials could not say whether Doe has left Liberia. ``We've heard various rumors, but I'm not in a position to tell you it's true,'' said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``There are a lot of rumors coming out of Liberia.'' A day earlier, the State Department said the United States had no plans to dispatch a U.S. peacekeeping force as requested by some Liberian officials. Spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler confirmed President Bush had received an appeal from Foreign Minister J. Rudolph Johnson and eight other prominent Liberians for a temporary U.S. force. Most Liberians would welcome U.S. help in ``averting massive plunder and tribal revenge'' and in having Doe evacuated from the country, said one of the Liberian signers, former U.N. Ambassador Winston Tubman. But Nelson Taylor, the rebel leader's brother, said the appeal for U.S. help ``is just one of the scams that Doe is using to involve the U.S. in a battle with the citizens of Liberia.'' When asked if the rebels were prepared to fight U.S. forces he said: ``We will fight until the U.S. can kill every one of us.'' He spoke from his home in Providence, R.I., and said he represented the rebel forces. In downtown Monrovia, every shop and office was closed Friday. Nervous troops ordered civilians off the streets in an unofficial daytime curfew. The curfew was in effect throughout the government-controlled areas and has prevented refugees from reaching Spriggs Payne Airport to catch the last few flights out of the country. Soldiers set up makeshift roadblocks at downtown intersections, firing wildly into the air to clear terrified civilians off the streets. Hundreds of frightened Monrovians gathered at the gates of the U.S. Embassy hoping to seek refuge, while scores of others broke into a U.S. Marine compound demanding food and shelter. Representatives of the government and the rebels have met intermittently for peace talks in neighboring Sierra Leone, but the negotiations have failed to make any progress. The rebels have refused to compromise on their demand that Doe resign before any cease-fire can be implemented. The rebels have accused Doe, who took power in a 1980 coup, of corruption, mismanagement and widespread human rights abuses. Taylor has promised to maintain close U.S. ties if he comes to power, but he has ruled out immediate elections. U.S. Ambassador Peter De Vos went in a well-guarded convoy to the president's mansion Friday morning. An embassy spokesman said he was received by acting Foreign Minister George Wallace but did not see Doe. The spokesman said he couldn't tell reporters what was said during the meeting. Diplomatic sources said Doe was surrounded by bodyguards from his Krahn tribe. The guards were unwilling to let Doe leave the capital without them. There have been extensive discussions on the issue of giving the Krahn _ who form the bulk of Doe's remaining troops _ a safe passage through rebel-held areas to their stronghold in Grand Gedeh county. Taylor is reported to have rejected any such safe conduct, which has contributed to the present stalemate. Random killings have been reported on both sides as the insurgency degenerated into tribal warfare. Most rebels come from the Gio and Mano tribes, while government supporters are mostly Krahns and Mandingos. The African nation, founded by freed American slaves 150 years ago, has traditionally had close ties with the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Police: Rebel Firebombs Damage or Destroy Two Stores Near Lima
LaserPhoto LIM1
DOC.TEXT: Two separate firebomb attacks by leftist guerrillas destroyed a four-story department store, severely damaged an office supplies company and left four people injured, police said. Two suspects were arrested carrying containers of gasoline near the fire-gutted Hogar department store in the suburb of San Isidro after the firebomb attacks Friday night, police said. They said four people were injured in the blaze at the department store, which is owned by one of the country's largest department store chains. Police did not identify the injured or give their conditions. The main floor of the two-story Lau Chun office supply store also was destroyed by a blaze caused by firebombs. Police said nearly all of the capital's firefighting units were called out to fight the fires. A police bomb squad spokesman said 15 unexploded incendiary bombs were found in a clothing store in the nearby port of Callao. A bomb squad unit was able to safely deactivate the bombs. There was no claim of responsibility, but police blamed the attacks and fires on the Shining Path, a Maoist guerrilla group. The Shining Path has been fighting Peru's elected government since 1980. Officials say more than 18,500 people have died in the last decade, including police, soldiers, rebels, government officials and civilians.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanian Prime Minister Says Talks Could Start Next Week
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania's prime minister said negotiations between the breakaway republic and the Kremlin could begin next week, a report said today. Meanwhile, Lithuania and its independence-minded Baltic neighbors, Latvia and Estonia, today marked the 50th anniversary of their annexation into the Soviet Union. The Interfax news agency, which is affiliated with Radio Moscow, said the Lithuanian prime minister, Kazimiera Prunskiene, met briefly Friday with Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev. It quoted her as saying the Lithuanian side is prepared to begin the talks next week and ``the Soviet side is ready for this.'' She said both sides wanted ``to start negotiations and strive for a convergence of positions in order to sign an agreement,'' the report said. The way for the talks was cleared when Lithuania agreed on June 29 to place a 100-day moratorium on its March 11 declaration of independenc as soon as the negotiations formally begin with Soviet officials. After the Lithuanians agreed to the freeze on their declaration, the Kremlin lifted an economic embargo that had shut off oil shipments, most natural gas and many other manufactured goods and raw materials. Mrs. Prunskiene said the two sides have been in contact in advance of the talks. ``I would say that our dialogue now is taking place in a very calm tone,'' she told Interfax. The leader of the Soviet negotiators is Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov. A 10-member Lithuanian team, led by two deputy prime ministers, has already worked out the republic's general stance in the negotiations. The Soviet Union's parliamentary leadership, in observation of the anniversary of the annexation of the Baltics, called on the republics to use ``responsibility and good sense'' in dealings with Moscow. The appeal, carried by the official Tass news agency, said Gorbachev's reforms have given the Baltics and the Soviet Union as a whole a chance to revamp their relations. ``For the first time we have the chance to build our joint coexistence, in a democratic and good-neighborly way, so that every nation can take full advantage of the benefits of cooperation, integration and stable security,'' said the message from Presidium of the Supreme Soviet. Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia were independent countries between the world wars. But they fell into a Soviet sphere of influence through a secret deal between Hitler and Stalin in 1939, then were absorbed into the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Aquino Aplogizes For Laughing After Quake
DOC.TEXT: President Corazon Aquino apologized Saturday for laughing in public while hundreds of her countrymen were dying in a devastating earthquake. Last Monday, TV crews filmed Mrs. Aquino and several government officials laughing and joking in the aftermath of the quake, which shook Manila and surrounding Luzon island. Later, Filipinos watched the footage of their president laughing spliced amid horrifying scenes of crushed victims, frantic survivors and shattered buildings. ``If I offended any of our countrymen because of what happened, I am asking apology because I did not mean to laugh at this unfortunate situation,'' Mrs. Aquino said in her weekly radio program. She said she had been meeting with some senators when the quake struck, and they all dived under a table. ``I want to explain to you that my laughter was because I was alive along with my colleagues,'' she said. The quake, which measured 7.7 on the Richter Scale, caused relatively little damage in Manila but killed more than 700 people and damaged thousands of buildings elsewhere in Luzon.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Film Director Dead
DOC.TEXT: Soviet film director Sergei Paradzhanov has died after a lengthy illness, the Tass news agency announced Saturday. He was 66. Paradzhanov, an ethnic Armenian, was well known in the Soviet Union as the director of films such as ``The Shadows of Forgotten Ancestors'' and the ``Legend of Suram Fortress.'' His death was announced at a session of the Supreme Soviet of Armenia in Yerevan, the republic's capital. Paradzhanov died overnight, Tass reported. It did not say what the cause of death was or give other details.

DOC.HEAD: China, Soviet Union Sign Trade, Economic Agreements
DOC.TEXT: Chinese and Soviet officials on Saturday signed agreements to protect investment in each other's countries and avoid double taxation for their nationals, the official Xinhua News Agency reported. The agreements were signed at the end of a six-day meeting of the Sino-Soviet Economic, Trade, Scientific and Technological Cooperation Committee. Chinese Vice Premier Yao Yilin and his Soviet counterpart, U.D. Maslukov, signed a memorandum for the session, Xinhua said. Its contents were not disclosed, nor were details of the other agreements. It was the committee's fifth session. Premier Li Peng also met with Maslukov, and told him China is conducting political reform simultaneously with its economic reform. He said political reform for China means strengthening contacts between the ruling Communist Party and the people, and improving consultation with the eight non-Communist parties that are allowed to exist under Communist control. He also called for growth in Sino-Soviet trade, which totaled about $3.2 billion last year, and establishment of more joint ventures.
