So far, about 20 Sino-Soviet joint ventures have been established.
Congress Considers Trade Cutoff With Iraq

U.S.-Iraq relations could take another turn for the worse if members of Congress are successful in their drive to cut off virtually all commerce between the two countries. The Senate Banking Committee last week unanimously approved legislation that would deny agricultural and Export-Import Bank credits to Iraq as well as bar the sale of technological items that could be used by the military. ``It sailed right through committee,'' said Sen. Nancy Kassebaum, R-Kan., sponsor of the amendment. ``I frankly was amazed.'' Kassebaum is concerned about Iraq's human rights record, particularly reports that children have been tortured and murdered as a way of punishing their parents. There have been other reports that Iraq has used chemical weapons against its own people and is developing nuclear weapons. Iraq, a country with 17 million people and the second-largest proven oil reserves in the world, denies many of the charges, including those that it used chemical weapons specifically against its Kurdish minority. Mohammed Al-Mashat, Iraq's ambassador in Washington, claims accusations against Iraq are ``simply planned, organized propaganda by the Israeli machinery in the United States.'' Kassebaum's measure _ an amendment to the Export Administration Act _ is likely to be brought to the Senate floor before the August recess because lawmakers must meet a deadline to extend the export act. Rep. Howard Berman, D-Calif., a major player in trying to isolate Iraq, said sanctions are the only way the United States can force Hussein to change his ``despotic, tyrannical, deplorable conduct.'' ``Iraq is a country where meaningful sanctions could deter its conduct,'' he said. In an interview, Al-Mashat rejected that argument. He said cutting off credits as well as ending trade would end up hurting the United States. ``We think this is against the U.S. national interest,'' he said. ``We can buy it (goods) from other countries _ and cheaper.'' Passage of the legislation in committee coincides with increasingly bellicose rhetoric from Iraqi President Saddam Hussein and other developments that have soured ties between the United States and Iraq. John Kelly, assistant secretary of State for Near Eastern affairs, said recently the Bush administration is weighing whether to place Iraq back on the list of countries that sponsor terrorism, a designation that halts shipments of technology to Baghdad. Iraq was taken off the list in 1985. Iraq has drawn the ire of U.S. officials for harboring alleged terrorists, including Abu Abbas, a member of the Palestine Liberation Organization's executive committee who claimed responsibility for an aborted, ship-launched attack on Israel in May. The Iraqi ambassador said his government has no intention of acting against Abu Abbas. ``We support the PLO with all the means possible,'' he said. Meantime, Hussein's threats against neighboring Kuwait prompted a response from Defense Secretary Dick Cheney that the United States was committed to come to Kuwait's defense if the country were attacked by force. And the White House moved to block the shipment of three advanced industrial furnaces because officials were worried they would be used for projects relating to nuclear weapons. Sen. Arlen Specter, R-Pa., said he urged President Bush to block the sale at a meeting at the White House on Wednesday. Specter said he told Bush ``we should not do anything to help Iraq.'' While the Bush administration says relations with Iraq are not particularly cordial, it opposes congressional efforts to impose sanctions. ``We want to do it our way,'' said a State Department official, speaking on condition he not be named. Specter, who has met with Hussein this year, agrees congressional action should only be taken as a last resort. He advocates ending credits _ Iraq receives about $20 million annually in credits from the Ex-Im Bank and has about $500 million in credits from the Agriculture Department _ but wants the administration to take the action. At the same time, Specter said Iraq is too important a country to ignore. ``They are an emerging major player and tensions are high, particularly with Israel, he said. ``We should establish a dialogue.''

DOC.HEAD: More Than 48,000 East Europeans Seek Entry
DOC.TEXT: More than 48,000 residents of Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union have inquired about immigrating to South Africa so far this year, government-run radio said Saturday. A total of 375 immigrants from Poland, Yugoslavia, Hungary and the Soviet Union arrived in South Africa during the first five months of 1990, the South African Broadcasting Corp. added. South Africa does not have diplomatic relations with any Eastern European nations. But since the collapse of Communist governments in Eastern Europe, thousands of their citizens have been visiting South African Embassies in Western Europe to apply for immigration, the Department of Foreign Affairs said. About 7,000 Soviet citizens have written, phoned or visited the South African Embassy in Finland this year, and inquires are running at about 100 a day, officials said. With its year-round sunny weather and the strongest economy on the continent, South Africa long has attracted immigrants from Western Europe. The government encourages immigration by skilled professionals, saying they are needed to help develop the economy. However, anti-apartheid groups oppose the recruitment of whites from abroad, saying the government should do more to train blacks. Under South Africa's apartheid system, the 5 million whites dominate politics and the economy and the 30 million blacks have no voice in national affairs. Residential areas, schools and politics are the main institutions that remain legally segregated. Many other facilities have been integrated in recent years.

DOC.HEAD: Government Tougher Environmental Crime Than Job Safety, Report Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For Release at Noon EDT
DOC.TEXT: The federal government is far more aggressive in prosecuting employers who violate environmental laws than those who jeopardize their workers' safety, a study released Saturday says. ``The federal establishment cares much more about water polluters than workplace killers,'' said Joseph Kinney, executive director of the National Safe Workplace Institute, which conducted the study. He said the nation's 20-year-old Occupational Safety and Health Administration act is ``more dream than reality.'' Since 1970, the Labor and Justice departments have put only one employer behind bars for safety violations that caused the death of a worker, the report said. But during a four-year period, the federal government has won environmental jail terms totaling 271 years, said the Chicago group, a private organization that calls itself a government accountability institute. ``There has been an outrageous neglect of worker safety issues by the federal government,'' said Kinney, who helped found the institute three years ago after his brother was killed in an on-the-job accident. Spokesmen for both the Labor and Justice departments noted that courts, not the federal government, control what kind of sentences are given to defendants once they are convicted. Justice Department spokesman Doug Tillett said that since the OSHA law was passed in 1970, his agency has received referrals of about 40 cases from the Labor Department for criminal prosecution. The Justice Department has handled about one-third of those cases, he said. Johanna Schneider, a spokeswoman for Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole, noted that Mrs. Dole pushed for and obtained an additional 177 inspectors for OSHA during her first year at the department. She also has backed stiffer penalties for employers who violate OSHA laws, Ms. Schneider said. ``It shows that we are committed to health and safety for American workers,'' Ms. Schneider said. ``We feel we've made a great effort to enforce the law, including criminal prosecution and increased criminal sanctions.'' In the past, OSHA has come under fire for issuing large fines against employers but then settling for small sums. The agency has defended the process, saying OSHA's purpose is to ensure that employers comply with laws, rather than collect large amounts of money for the government. Kinney said that in OSHA's 20-year history, only one employer has been incarcerated, and that was the owner of a South Dakota plumbing company who received a 45-day jail term for violations involving a 1988 trench cave-in that killed two workers. In contrast, in 1989 alone, there were 51 individuals convicted of environmental crimes and they were sentenced to an average of 6.4 months in jail with an additional probation period of 20.5 months, the study said. In 1986, the first person convicted and incarcerated for Clean Water Act violations was the manager of a yeast plant in Sumner, Wash., who received a one-year term for dumping yeast in a waterway, the study said. Earlier this year, a Pennsylvania man was sentenced to three years for dumping sludge in a wetlands area, Kinney said. ``It's absolutely outrageous. OSHA is the only agency where you have to have a dead body to prosecute,'' Kinney said. The group called for the Labor Department to back a bill pending in Congress to strengthen the jail terms for OSHA violators. Mrs. Dole has agreed to support stiffer fines, but has given only limited support to the tougher jail terms. The Labor Department has said in the past it believes courts should have discretion in sentencing violators. The AFL-CIO, which represents about 14.2 million unionized workers, estimates 10,000 workers are killed on the job each year while another 70,000 are permanently disabled.

DOC.HEAD: Two Ex-Mayors of Palermo Convicted
DOC.TEXT: Two former mayors of Palermo were sentenced to prison terms Saturday for abuse of public office and improperly awarding government contracts. One of the convicted men, Vito Ciancimino, has been dubbed ``Don Vito' by the Italian press for his alleged ties to the Palermo-area based Corleone crime family. The Christian Democrat was sentenced to three years and two months in prison. Another former mayor, Carmelo Scoma, received the same sentence for abuse of office. The two men were convicted Friday along with three other people who worked for the city and a sixth defendant who administered the company that held the city's street cleaning and sewer maintainance contracts for decades. Three defendants were acquitted after the court heard evidence gathered in a 10-year investigation of the city's granting of public service contracts. Palermo has some of Italy's worst slums. In a separate case, Ciancimino was charged in June with embezzlement, conflict of interest in awarding a public works contract, and having criminal ties.

DOC.HEAD: Capital's Buses Opened to All Races
DOC.TEXT: City buses in the South African administrative capital were opened to all races Saturday. Local municipal buses had previously been reserved for whites in Pretoria. Bus service in other major cities, such as Cape Town, Johannesburg and Durban, already have been desegregated. Non-racial transportation in the rest of the country is expected to be introduced in October, when the Separate Amenities Act is repealed. The law from the 1950s allows local governments to set aside public facilities for certain races. In June, the National Party government passed a bill repealing the Separate Amenities Act. The bill becomes effective in October to give people time to adjust, the government has said.

DOC.HEAD: Yale Library Commemorates Lassie's Literary Birth 50 Years Ago
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ``Lassie Come-Home,'' hyphenated, is cq.
DOC.TEXT: Yale University's rare book library is taking advantage of the dog days of summer to honor one of literature's most famous canine characters, the cunning collie, Lassie. The Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, a grand marble-and-granite building, is celebrating the 50th anniversary of the publication of ``Lassie Come-Home'' with an exhibit drawn from the papers of author Eric Knight. The ``Lassie at 50'' display includes the first printing of a shorter version of the story in The Saturday Evening Post; the original manuscript of the 1940 novel; Lassie fan mail; and photographs from the 1943 movie version of the book. ``In the summer we look for something a little lighter,'' said Christa Sammons, a library curator. ``It surprises people. You come in here and expect to see old books and esoteric things and here's something everyone can identify with.'' ``What they like about it most is they recognize the dog,'' said Nancy LeRoy, the research assistant who prepared the exhibit. Lassie came home to Yale in 1948, when Knight's widow, Jere Knight Lindter, donated a 10-foot-thick collection of her husband's papers to the university. An Englishman who spent most of his life in the United States, Knight became a U.S. citizen in 1942, and was commissioned a captain in the Special Services Division. He was killed in 1943 when his transport plane crashed in Dutch Guiana (now Suriname). Knight wrote six novels, a novella, a collection of short stories, newspaper and magazine articles, drama and movie reviews, and had an unsuccessful stint in the mid-1930s as a Hollywood scriptwriter. He also did cartoons and sketches, including a self-portrait featured in the Yale exhibit. He first wrote about Lassie in a story that appeared Dec. 17, 1938, in The Saturday Evening Post. A marked-up copy of the magazine article that Knight transformed into a novel is prominently featured in the exhibit. Impoverished Yorkshire, where Knight was raised by an uncle and aunt after his father died, was the setting for ``Lassie Come-Home.'' In the novel, Sam Carraclough, a poor Yorkshire miner, is forced to sell Lassie to the Duke of Rudley. But forever faithful to Sam's son, Joe, Lassie flees Rudley's Scotland estate and travels by himself hundreds of miles back to Yorkshire. Rudley pursues the dog, but when he finds the collie reunited with the Carracloughs, he lets them keep their dog. In the television series that ran from 1954 to 1971, the setting and the storyline were changed. Knight had insisted the book, which was translated into 13 languages, was written for both adults and children. But schoolchildren were the novel's greatest fans, and hundreds wrote to him in appreciation. In the Yale exhibit, a sampling of the fan mail is displayed on a lower shelf so children can see them. ``I am not a crying type over books but in some parts of your book as I was reading along I found myself really tightening up and almost crying over some of Lassie's adventures,'' a girl from Kalamazoo, Mich., wrote to Knight in 1941. Photographs include a still of Roddy McDowall, who played Joe in the original movie, lying on the crest of a hill with his arm draped over Pal _ the male collie who played Lassie. There is also a shot of Knight with his collie, whose name was Toots. Knight was very pleased with the dog they chose for the movie, LeRoy said. Some of the translations of ``Lassie Come-Home'' also are in the exhibit, which runs through the end of September, as well as copies of other Knight works, including his 1938 novella, ``The Flying Yorkshireman,'' his first success as an author, and his last novel, ``This Above All.'' ``This Above All,'' a love story set during the Battle of Britain, was a best seller in both the United States and Britain and was made into a 1942 movie starring Joan Fontaine and Tyrone Power.

DOC.HEAD: North Grateful to be `A Man Who Can Once Again Vote'
Precede BATON ROUGE, La.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to update with appearance today, picking up at the 6th graf previous, ``In Washington.'' Changes byline.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BT1
DOC.TEXT: A day after a federal appeals court set aside one of his Iran-Contra convictions, Oliver North stumped Louisiana for a Republican Senate candidate and lambasted Washington politics. ``I am indeed grateful _ grateful to stand here as a man who can once again vote,'' North said at a rally today for Senate candidate Ben Bagert. It was one of the few references he made to Friday's legal victory. North launched into his standard anti-Washington rhetoric, calling Washington ``the swamp on the Potomac,'' while he praised Bagert. Bagert is the state Republican party's endorsed candidate, running against 18-year Democratic incumbent J. Bennett Johnston, who has a strong lead in all recent polls. Running second is David Duke, under constant fire for his past as a former Ku Klux Klan grand wizard with ties to neo-Nazis. The three face off in the state's Oct. 6 open primary. North never mentioned Duke by name. But, in an apparent reference to Duke, North said there was no place in the country for ``the politics of hate.'' After leaving this Shreveport suburb, North planned appearances in Monroe, Alexandria and New Orleans on Bagert's behalf. Bagert said he is paying North for his appearances but wouldn't say how much except to say it was not very much. The appeals court panel voted 2-1 Friday to reverse one of North's convictions and ordered a judge to review the evidence to determine whether all three convictions were tainted by ties to testimony he gave Congress under immunity. ``It has been what we believe to be a major step in the right direction and what has been a long and difficult ordeal,'' the former Marine lieutenant colonel and White House aide said in a speech Friday night in Baton Rouge. In Washington, the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals panel suggested that North's Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination may have been violated. The ruling also could spell trouble for the Iran-Contra case against John Poindexter, who was convicted of five felonies in April. Like North, the former national security adviser had given immunized public testimony to Congress in 1987. Congress offered the grants of immunity as it tried to quickly determine what happened in the Iran-Contra affair, the Reagan administration's sale of arms to Iran and diversion of some of the proceeds to rebels fighting Nicaragua's Marxist government. In six days of compelled, nationally televised testimony in July 1987, North admitted to many of the activities for which he was later charged with crimes. A jury convicted North on May 4, 1989, of three of the 12 charges he faced: _Aiding and abetting an obstruction of Congress in connection with a November 1985 shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran. _Altering and destroying National Security Council documents detailing his efforts to provide military assistance to the Contras. _Accepting an illegal gratuity, a $13,800 home security system, from retired Air Force Maj. Gen. Richard Secord, whom North had enlisted to get arms to the Contras and assist the Reagan administration's initiative toward Iran. ``I certainly hope the special prosecutor ends it now,'' North said. ``We've been under a virtual siege.'' The special prosecutor, Lawrence Walsh, who is supervising the continuing Iran-Contra investigation, said only, ``Everyone familiar with these proceedings has recognized the difficulties presented by the grant of immunity by Congress.'' President Bush told reporters: ``I think this is good news. I have not wanted to see the North matter go any further.'' Walsh could seek review of the ruling by all 12 members of the appeals court or he could go directly to the Supreme Court. The appeals panel reversed one of North's convictions, blaming faulty jury instructions from U.S. District Judge Gerhard Gesell, the trial judge. That conviction could be reinstated only through a new trial. The panel reversed North's conviction for altering and destroying security council documents, saying Gesell had given an erroneous instruction to the jury on how to weigh evidence of what superiors might have told North to do. Gesell could reinstate the two remaining convictions if he found they had not been tainted by North's immunized testimony. Gesell's inquiry ``must proceed witness-by-witness; if necessary, it will proceed line-by-line and item-by-item,'' the appeals court said in an opinion supported by judges Laurence Silberman and David Sentelle, both Reagan appointees. Chief judge Patricia Wald, a Carter appointee, dissented, saying she was ``satisfied that North received a fair trial'' and received ``all of the constitutional protections to which he was entitled.'' The majority held that the government must show by ``a preponderance of the evidence'' that no use was made of North's immunized testimony either by witnesses or by the Iran-Contra prosecutor's office. North's conviction for destroying security council documents led to his $23,100-a-year Marine pension being revoked. In Baton Rouge, North said at a reception for Bagert: ``I guess they'll give me my retirement benefits again.'' A Marine Corps spokesman said that if North's attorney requests a review, ``that would be something that the Marine Corps would have to look at.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Steps up Counterattack on Big Defense Cuts
Precede WASHINGTON
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today used the gleaming backdrop of a new U.S. aircraft carrier to fortify his argument against weakening U.S. defenses in the post-Cold War era. ``We must maintain a policy of peacetime engagement and armed forces sufficient to sustain our vital national interests,'' Bush said at a christening ceremony for the nation's newest Nimitz-class carrier, the George Washington. Barbara Bush, with the president at her side, smashed a bottle of champagne against the ship's hull to formally dedicate the giant vessel in a shipyard where 240 other Navy vessels have been constructed. The 1,040-foot, nuclear-powered vessel, built at a cost of $3.1 billion, is to enter service in 1992. Standing directly under the carrier's massive bow, the president quoted the nation's first president, for whom the ship was named, as saying `` `to be prepared for war is one of the most effective means of preserving the peace.' '' Bush, a World War II Navy aviator who flew combat missions from a Pacific-based carrier, wore a navy blue tie adorned with gold Navy aviator wings. The trip to Newport News coincided with congressional debate over whether to shrink the Navy's carrier battle group fleet. The George Washington is the sixth of the Nimitz-class carriers to be built for the Navy. Two more are under construction. Fifteen carriers now are in active service. On Friday, during a tour of Warren Air Force Base near Cheyenne, Wyo., home of the nation's arsenal of MX intercontinental missiles, Bush indicated he was willing to accept limited cuts in his 1991 defense budget request. Last week, the Senate Armed Services Committee, firing an opening salvo in the battle over the first post-Cold War budget, voted to cut $18 billion from Bush's request for $307 billion in defense spending for the fiscal year starting Oct. 1. The House Armed Services Committee has yet to act on the budget but is expected to take an even bigger bite out of the administration's 6-month-old proposal. ``I'm asking Congress to hold the line at the already painful reduction in the defense budget set down by the Senate Armed Services Committee,'' the president said Friday. ``There were some positive things from the committee, especially their support for strategic modernization, as well as some other actions, on the other hand, that cause me problems.'' He did not elaborate on the ``problems'' except to say he would like more latitude in making personnel cuts than the committee proposed. Speaking to several hundred workers at Warren Air Force Base, the president said: ``I especially need ... flexibility so that the bedrock of the military, its highly trained, highly motivated and exceptionally dedicated men and women, people such as you, will be protected. I cannot support reductions in the defense budget that would unfairly penalize those of you who have given so much to our country.'' Bush stressed that while he could accept a lower 1991 spending total, he was not going to let Congress hold ``some kind of fire sale'' of U.S. military assets. ``As we strive for strength and stability, we must maintain an effective deterrent, especially in the face of continuing across-the-board modernization of the Soviet strategic forces,'' Bush said. ``This won't be easy in the fiscal environment we face now. We all recognize that we must get the deficit under control and that defense will contribute its share. But I don't want defense to contribute more than its share.'' Bush toured the silos at Warren that hold all 50 MXs, the nation's most modern long-range nuclear missiles. The president is pushing for $2.2 billion in 1991 to take the launchers for the 10-warhead missiles out of their silos and place them on rail cars to make them less vulnerable to attack. Critics argue that current U.S.-Soviet arms control negotiations are likely to lead to a ban on mobile missiles. Reflecting a growing conviction in Congress that the demise of the Soviet military threat should mean big cuts in U.S. defenses, the Senate Armed Services Committee cut $1.6 billion from Bush's MX plan. It left in $548 million for research but prohibited any spending on procurement or construction.

DOC.HEAD: Ceiling in Supermarket Collapses, Killing Two
DOC.TEXT: A ceiling collapsed on shoppers in a supermarket Saturday, killing two people and injuring 17, authorities said. A space above the ceiling was used for storing packages of food. ``I heard a sudden explosion and then the screams of the many people inside,'' said one shopper, who escaped injury from falling containers of food. So big were the mounds of canned goods and other groceries that landed on shoppers that it took police about four hours to drag out the dead and wounded. The discount supermarket Save-On is on the edge of the town of Paola, about four miles south of Valletta. Authorities were conducting an investigation into the collapse.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Searching for Successor to Supreme Court's Leading Liberal
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Top 8 grafs with meetings continuing, more names of possible successors, picks up 8th graf pvs, ``Bush's choice xxx''
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, moving quickly in the wake of Supreme Court Justice William J. Brennan's surprise retirement, met today with top aides to discuss possible successors to the high court's leading liberal jurist. ``I am going to try to make this determination as soon as possible,'' Bush told reporters aboard Air Force One. ``The process is moving.'' Participating in the 75-minute White House meeting were Bush, Attorney General Richard Thornburgh, White House Chief of Staff John Sununu and presidential counsel C. Boyden Gray. Bush declined to reveal the names of those discussed as possible Supreme Court nominees. As Bush flew to Newport News, Va., for a ship christening, Thornburgh and Gray continued their discussions at the Justice Department. The administration is reviewing about 15 candidates, officials said. Solicitor General Kenneth W. Starr, the government's top courtroom lawyer, has been mentioned as a leading possibility for a high court vacancy. Starr gave up a federal judgeship to take the Justice Department job. Other possible candidates include a number of federal appeals judges, including Ralph K. Winter of the 2nd Circuit, J. Harvie Wilkinson III of the 4th Circuit, Patrick E. Higginbotham of the 5th Circuit and Clarence Thomas of the District of Columbia Circuit in Washington. Others who have been mentioned have been U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills and Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah. The list also includes appellate judges Edith H. Jones of the 5th Circuit, William W. Wilkens Jr. of the 4th Circuit and chairman of the U.S. Sentencing Commission; and David Souter, a former New Hampshire Supreme Court judge who now sits on the 1st Circuit Court of Appeals in Boston. Bush's choice will help determine the court's approach _ possibly well into the next century _ to abortion rights, affirmative action, freedom of expression and other contentious issues. The Republican president said he intends to choose the best qualified person, even if it means triggering a confirmation battle in the Democratic-controlled Senate. ``The matter is now official and we will now start the process of finding a successor,'' Bush said. He received a facsimile of Brennan's resignation letter as he boarded Air Force One in Wyoming on Friday. The Supreme Court had hand-delivered a copy of the letter to the White House at 7:40 p.m. EDT. ``I've always said I want somebody who will be on there not to legislate from the bench but to faithfully interpret the Constitution,'' Bush said. ``So that gives me a wide latitude. But I do not plan at this point to talk about any issues or any judicial philosophy.'' The stakes are unusually high in picking a successor to Brennan, 84. He has been the liberals' leading voice on an increasingly conservative court and, by most accounts, has been their most skillful negotiator in helping preserve past liberal victories. Brennan's departure is ``an incalculable loss to the law and civil liberties and to every person whose rights are threatened in the United States,'' Norman Dorsen, president of the American Civil Liberties Union, said. The battle lines over abortion already are forming. ``I've been saying for months that the threat to our right to choose is as close as the next Supreme Court appointment,'' Kate Michelman, president of the National Abortion Rights Action League, said, adding, ``It's a very, very dark day.'' The Iowa Right to Life Committee said, ``The appointment of one more justice who believes that all human life, both born and unborn, deserves protection, will be the beginning toward our country once again protecting pre-born life.'' The high court split, 5-4, last year in giving states broad new power to limit abortions. Last month by the same vote, the justices said states generally may require that unmarried teen-age girls notify parents before getting an abortion. On both occasions, the court stopped short of overturning its 1973 ruling in Roe vs. Wade that said women have a constitutional right to abortion. Bush said, ``It's not like we're starting from ground zero'' in picking Brennan's replacement. But he refused to drop any hints on leading candidates. The conservative court is led by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and includes three appointees of former President Reagan _ Justices Sandra Day O'Connor, Antonin Scalia and Anthony M. Kennedy. A fifth conservative vote often is provided by Justice Byron R. White. The liberal wing that Brennan often led now is reduced to Justices Thurgood Marshall, Harry A. Blackmun and John Paul Stevens. Brennan said he decided to end his 34-year career on the court _ one that spanned the administrations of eight presidents _ because of his ``advancing age and medical condition.'' He suffered a small stroke after the term ended, falling down in Newark Airport en route to a Scandinavian vacation, court spokeswoman Toni House said. Brennan's doctor advised him to ``avoid stress and strain and consider retiring,'' Ms. House said. In a letter of resignation to Bush, Brennan said: ``Strenuous demands of court work and its related duties required or expected of a justice appear at this time to be incompatible with my advancing age and medical condition.'' Appointed to the court by President Eisenhower in 1956, Brennan quickly found a home among the liberal majority led by Chief Justice Earl Warren. As the court changed over the next three decades and the balance of power moved to the right, Brennan played a key role in preserving liberal victories while also speaking out numerous times as a dissenter defending individual rights. Among the more than 1,200 opinions he wrote are landmarks that imposed a ``one-person, one-vote'' standard for electing state legislatures, created constitutional protections for libel lawsuit defendants and helped invent a legal definition of obscenity.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Shakes Old Image On Way To Goal of Leading Unified Germany
DOC.TEXT: In one of the most extraordinary political journeys of modern times, Helmut Kohl has shaken off his image as a plodding, unimaginative politician and positioned himself to become the first chancellor of a united Germany. The road has not been smooth. As his ratings have risen and fallen over the years, Kohl has been written off by critics so many times that his survival as chancellor seems almost miraculous. But early last week, the portly conservative proved what his supporters long maintained: He is a patient and skillful bargainer, an ambitious man with an even more ambitious vision for Germany. At a meeting in the Soviet Union, Kohl won President Mikhail Gorbachev's approval of NATO membership for a united Germany and the promise to withdraw all Soviet troops from East Germany by 1994. The agreements cleared the biggest obstacles to German unification, which can now be sealed in all-German elections in December. Germany, divided for 45 years of Cold War animosity, will have nearly 80 million citizens after unification. It will be the most powerful, prosperous nation in Western Europe and a high-stakes player in global politics. The diplomatic coup in Moscow, Kohl acknowledged, was a high point of his career. ``This day, these 24 hours, belong to the most important experiences of my life,'' the jubilant chancellor told reporters after returning to Bonn. Newspapers across the country's political spectrum hailed the deal. The mass-circulation Bild, usually a government supporter, nonetheless proclaimed Wednesday, ``The world is astonished at Kohl _ Adenauer and Brandt outdone.'' Konrad Adenauer was West Germany's first chancellor, who led the country from World War II's ruins to democracy and membership in the Western alliance. Willy Brandt, chancellor from 1969-74, won a Nobel Peace Prize for formulating ``Ostpolitik,'' West Germany's rapproachement to the East. Even Kohl's political opponents congratulated the Christian Democratic Union leader, including Oskar Lafontaine, the opposition Social Democrats' candidate for chancellor in the next elections. Kohl's public opinion rating has surged. The latest poll, by the research institute INFAS, said an unprecedented 61 percent of 800 West Germans polled supported Kohl as chancellor. ``I think it was statesmanship at its best,'' said Klaus Becher, a foreign policy analyst for the private, non-partisan German Society for Foreign Affairs in Bonn. ``The magnitude of what he has done is miraculous,'' echoed Hans Binnendijk at the London-based International Institute for Strategic Studies. ``Part of it was, I suppose, being at the right place at the right time. ... But being there at the right time, he made the most of it.'' Kohl, 60, has seldom had such moments of political eloquence since taking office in October 1982. He frightened Poles and worried allies earlier this year by playing to conservatives at home and not immediately assuring the inviolability of Poland's western border. One-third of Poland is former German territory, and Poles feared possible German revanchism. Both German states have since vowed to respect the border and to sign a treaty guaranteeing the frontier after unification. In a 1986 interview with Newsweek, Kohl caused an uproar when he likened Gorbachev's public relations skills to those of the infamous Nazi propaganda minister, Joseph Goebbels. And he stirred international controversy in 1985 when he invited former President Reagan to Bitburg to visit a war cemetery that included the graves of 49 Nazi SS soldiers. ``I would say that a man grows with his tasks,'' Gerhard Wettig, a leading analyst at the Federal Institute for Soviet and International Studies in Cologne, said in explaining Kohl's earlier blunders. But he said Kohl had also been underrated. ``As a rule is he not intellectually brilliant as was Helmut Schmidt,'' Wettig said, referring to another former chancellor. ``But he is a very clever and ... to some degree wise politician who is able to accomplish a lot of things which you would not guess when just having talked with him a few times.'' Said Binnendijk: ``Obviously, he is a politician who works from the gut and his instincts are very good... He's not a smooth or urbane politician. In American terms, you'd say he's a very clever Chicago politician.'' Kohl has an ability to appeal to ordinary Germans, analysts said. ``When he's talking it's not too different from a man in the street. His sentences are simple, his thoughts are not complicated,'' Wettig said.

DOC.HEAD: Louisiana Will Switch Execution Method To Injection
DOC.TEXT: The state's electric chair is being retired now that Louisiana has decided to execute inmates with lethal injections. The change comes from legislation signed into law on Friday by Gov. Buddy Roemer. Sen. Donald Kelly pushed the bill through the legislative session that ended July 9, saying the electric chair is too cruel. The chair will be retired beginning Jan. 1, 1991. Louisiana has executed 19 men since the 1976 U.S. Supreme Court ruling allowing states to resume the death penalty. Only two other states _ Texas and Florida _ have had more executions.

DOC.HEAD: Newest Aircraft Carrier Christened Today
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to update with christening, Bush speech, picking up at 6th graf pvs, `In the modular...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NEW1 of July 20
DOC.TEXT: The $3.57 billion aircraft carrier George Washington was christened today as a crowd of more than 15,000 stood, waving flags and cheering. The nuclear-powered carrier was built in more than 150 huge modular sections at Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Co., the only shipyard in the nation capable of building the 1,092-foot-long, 91,487-ton vessels. President Bush today praised the thousands of workers who helped build the carrier and said it represents America's commitment to liberty. Bush called aircraft carriers ``an indispensable element of our nation's defense, projecting power and preserving peace. ... So today, we must maintain a policy of peacetime engagement and armed forces sufficient to sustain our national interest.'' First lady Barbara Bush officially christened the ship. The ship is to be commissioned next year. The Navy commissioned the carrier USS Abraham Lincoln this year, and has two other Nimitz-class carriers under construction at Newport News. The Washington, built under the supervision of W.B. ``Miff'' Miffleton and James S. Morris, is the third Nimitz-class carrier to be assembled according to a modular plan involving 100-ton-or-more sections called ``super lifts.'' In the modular process, ``super lifts'' are built in workshops and later lifted into place by crane to be welded together. The process saved about $80 million and some 17 months in construction time. The biggest piece is the 700-ton bow section. The deck house is seven decks high, weighs 454 tons and lays atop the 4{-acre flight deck. They were lowered into place by a 900-ton crane that was built especially for carrier construction. Each of the Nimitz-class carriers takes six years and 10,000 workers to complete. Before modular construction, the ships were built one 40-foot-by-30-foot panel at a time. ``It was sort of like building a large house of cards,'' Miffleton said. Christening of the ship is the high point for the workers. ``It's like a fever that runs through the gang. There may be as many as 2,000 to 3,000 workers on the ship at any one time. They all feel they have a stake in her,'' said Morris, veteran of 38 years in the yard. When the George Washington is commissioned, it will be home to 2,800 officers and men. Another 2,700 will be aboard when the ship adds its air wing of 85 aircraft. The carrier measures 1,040 feet from bow to stern and 1,092 feet on its flight deck. From its keel to the top of its mast, it is 244 feet high _ the equivalent of a 24-story building. Its top speed is about 45 mph.

DOC.HEAD: After Uproar, Carnegie Mellon U. President Opts To Rent House
DOC.TEXT: The new president of Carnegie Mellon University has decided to rent a house at his own expense rather than depend on the school to buy a residence for him, as it did for his predecessors. Robert Mehrabian, who took office July 1, made his intentions known Friday in an open letter to CMU. Two weeks ago, CMU trustees disclosed plans to buy a 16-acre estate for Mehrabian and his wife at a reported price of $1.9 million. School officials said they wanted a house with substantial grounds because the Mehrabians own six horses. But after the purchase price was publicized, the deal was called off. Mehrabian said in his letter: ``I have relieved the Board of Trustees of all responsibility for providing a house for my wife and me.'' Mehrabian has been dean of the College of Engineering at the University of California at Santa Barbara.

DOC.HEAD: Bush May Get Bashed on Taxes at Home, But Not on the Road
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's abandoning his no-new-taxes pledges may have triggered a firestorm in the capital, but it has not set off alarms elsewhere, judging from the reception Bush got on a four-state Western swing. As Bush headed off to California on Wednesday, House Republicans were voting en masse to declare their opposition to tax increases in any form, including tinkering with the maximum tax rates on upper-income earners. That was just the latest display of unhappiness in the ranks of GOP lawmakers about Bush's confession last month that solving the deficit problem would require ``tax revenue increases.'' Coming from the man who made ``Read my lips: no new tax'' the mantra of his landslide 1988 campaign, the reversal may have caused some erosion in Bush's popularity. His sky-high approval ratings have dipped from a lofty 80 percent to 63 percent in a recent Gallup Poll. But the crowds that lined the streets outside the Nixon library in Yorba Linda, Calif., on Thursday morning and later in Boise, Idaho, and Billings, Mont., were waving flags and ``Welcome, Mr. President'' signs, not tax rebellion banners. He also got a rousing Western welcome in the rain in Cheyenne, Wyo., where cheering crowds turned out for a White House parade grafted onto the city's Frontier Days celebration. Bush himself broached the tax issue, if gingerly, at a fund-raising dinner for Republican Senate candidate Larry Craig in Boise on Thursday evening. ``You've seen the firestorm about revenues being on the table,'' he told the party faithful. ``Well, I've done my part and now it's their turn,'' he said, prodding Congress to show its hands on spending cuts. The next morning in Billings, he told another GOP fund-raiser, ``I've taken a few shots. You've heard it rebounding around out here. I've said before that I'll negotiate without preconditions, and I will, in spite of the outcry about revenues.'' Bush, on the flight home Friday night, told reporters, ``I didn't hear too much talk about tax increases, but I sure got a lot of people mentioning to me in these side meetings about doing something about getting the federal deficit down.'' ``Maybe people understand my view on that. I was very pleased with what I felt was support from the people to whom I was speaking, which in these instances were largely Republican audiences. They seemed to be supportive of what I was saying,'' the president said. Bush is building up to what aides say will be almost non-stop campaigning this fall for Republican candidates, especially Senate races. Bush's fondest dream is that the voters will give him what Ronald Reagan enjoyed for six years of his presidency: control of the Senate, where Democrats now hold a 55-45 edge. But Bush's retreat on tax increases has taken a powerful campaign weapon out of the hands of Republican hopefuls, who were only too happy to join the old Bush in taking the no-new-taxes pledge. There was a schizophrenic quality to much of Bush's campaign trip on this political foray. In one breath he lambasted the Democrats as the party on ``the far side'' and blamed them for ``government by gridlock,'' the skyrocketing deficit and pork barrel spending. In the next, he told GOP loyalists in Billings, ``Frankly, I think in fairness to say we are getting some good cooperation with the leadership on the Democratic side of the aisle'' in the budget negotiations. It may be that the public took Bush's no-new-taxes pledge with a grain of salt in the first place, or perhaps they have learned not to get too excited about the talk of higher taxes until they see what Bush and the leaders of Congress actually come up with. But White House officials say it came as no surprise to them that taxes did not generate much excitement _ or resentment _ on this trip. ``It hasn't been a factor at all,'' White House deputy chief of staff Andrew Card said as he stood by the president's rain-swept stage outside the gold-domed Wyoming State Capitol on Friday. ``I think people respect his leadership and recognize that he is meeting with very difficult responsibilities'' in trying ``to generate some governing in Washington,'' Card said. And what kind of reception will Bush get if the budget summitteers actually hit people in the pocketbook? ``I'm sure there will be some reaction,'' Card said. But he added, ``As long as the people are not abused in the process, I think they'll accept the results.''
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Christopher Connell covers the White House for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Progress Toward Peace in Cambodia Now Depends on China
An AP News Analysis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf pvs, `Evans noted...' to CORRECT that Indonesia talks begin this week
DOC.TEXT: The United States has opened the way for new approaches to peace in Cambodia, but Khmer Rouge guerrillas may escalate the fighting unless China goes along. On Wednesday, the United States announced it was withdrawing recognition of the guerrilla coalition's seat at the United Nations in order to open talks with Vietnam on ending the war. Although the coalition has three factions, two of them non-Communist, the Beijing-supported Khmer Rouge is by far the strongest. Because of the U.S. action, ``all of us can look forward with confidence to the whole (peace) process having new momentum,'' said Foreign Minister Gareth Evans of Australia, a key mediator on Cambodia. Washington's decision widened the gulf between it and China, but brought the United States closer to the Soviet Union, the main ally of Hanoi and the Vietnamese-sponsored government of Cambodia. Evans noted the talks on Cambodia to be held this week in Indonesia by the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, United States, Japan, Australia, Canada, New Zealand and the European Community. The Bush administration changed the U.S. position after American intelligence reported increased Khmer Rouge assaults reminiscent of those that brought it to power in April 1975. By the time Vietnamese forces invaded in December 1978, the Khmer Rouge had slaughtered hundreds of thousands of people in labor camps and execution chambers, and hundreds of thousands more had died of starvation. Its 30,000 fighters are the dominant force in the guerrilla coalition. The other factions are led by Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the former ruler of Cambodia, and Son Sann. Many non-Communist resistance leaders say the U.S. shift will drive the Khmer Rouge closer to China and convince its leaders they must win militarily because they have been shut out of a political settlement. Sihanouk, overall leader of the coalition, expressed anger at the U.S. action and said the insurgents would be ``more firm and fierce in their determination to continue to resist.'' China has said it will halt aid only when other countries do and only when a comprehensive political settlement is reached, and demands the Khmer Rouge be included in a settlement. U.S. intelligence agencies estimate it gives the Khmer Rouge $100 million worth of aid annually. ``I haven't seen any sign that they're softening on either of these positions,'' a Western diplomat in Beijing said of the Chinese. He said China wanted to remain the region's dominant power and was trying to head off Vietnamese attempts to forge an Indochinese bloc by controlling Cambodia and Laos. China does not seek direct influence in Cambodia, but wants to ensure its neutrality, he said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Diplomats also said China has been serious in talks on Cambodia with the United States, Soviet Union, Britain and France, the other permanent members of the U.N. Security Council. ``The Chinese appear to us to have all sorts of options in their bag,'' De Montigny Marchand, Canadian undersecretary of state for foreign affairs, said Thursday after talks in Beijing. ``They struck me as not being as doctrinaire as I expected them to be.'' Moscow has sharply reduced its economic aid and political support, so Vietnam and its client government in Phnom Penh may be more amenable to concessions. The U.S. dialogue with Vietnam, their first political talks since the Vietnam war ended 15 years ago, has inspired hope that Hanoi will put pressure on Phnom Penh to make peace. Vietnam knows settling the war is essential to achieving normal relations with the United States, which are critical to ending its isolation and solving its economic problems. Hope also flowered, however, when Vietnam and China began talks on Cambodia in January 1989. In June, the fourth round collapsed in mutual recrimination. Despite many negotiations over 2{ years, the factions still disagree on who would govern until general elections. The government wants to retain interim power and rejects any significant Khmer Rouge role; the guerrillas demand a four-party coalition government or a U.N. authority. Diplomats said the U.S. change could help induce Vietnam and the Cambodian government to accept a U.N. authority, which they have rejected because the guerrilla coaltion occupies the Cambodian seat. Cambodia's state news agency said the American decision would ``enable the United Nations to play its honorable and appropriate role'' in a settlement. Vietnam expressed willingness to negotiate an early solution.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Peter Eng has been a reporter in the Bangkok bureau of The Associated Press since 1983 and has frequently reported on Cambodian affairs.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Seaman Who Jumped Ship In New Orleans Is Released From Detention
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet sailor who says he overstayed his U.S. welcome to satisfy his curiosity about America has been freed after 25 days in immigration detention. ``I am very glad!'' Nikolaj Vetkovskij shouted Friday as he ran from the detention center at the U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service office. Asked why his release took an hour after bail was posted, he added, ``Burocratya! Burocratya!'' But bureaucracy _ in the form of hearings on his status _ also may keep Nick, as his adoptive American family calls him, in the United States long enough for him to satisfy more of his curiosity. Coincidentally, his freedom came on the opening day of the Goodwill Games, which have drawn hundreds of Soviet athletes to Seattle and brought more than 1,000 Soviet citizens for ``home stay'' visits with Americans. In all, the Goodwill Games have drawn some 2,500 athletes from 50 countries. Vetkovskij was aboard the Czechoslovakian merchant ship M-S Tatry when it docked June 14 in New Orleans, and he went ashore with a landing pass good for 29 days. He had been to the United States before for three-day stints but wanted more. In his broken English, he explained: ``Many times visit America but it's very little time. It's very good when every people can be every one, two, three months here.'' The ship set sail the next day, but the 29-year-old native of Peno, near Leningrad, set off across the United States. He hitchhiked to San Diego and ended up in Seattle on June 24. He decided to look for a job in the city's port and found one on a ship. The skipper told him he needed to go to the INS to get the proper papers. But the captain of the Czech ship had reported Vetkovskij missing, which invalidated his papers, and when he walked into the INS building he was arrested as an illegal alien. Later, Nick was to describe the INS detention center as a ``retirement home'' compared with the Soviet jail in which he said he spent 10 days for his refusal to take part in the Soviet occupation of Afghanistan. Nick was in the center for three weeks before marine engineer Eric Bergh, whom Nick had met while job-hunting, decided to see what had happened to his acquaintance. When he found out, Bergh contacted his sister, Kathryn Sterbick. On Wednesday, she got immigration lawyer Dan Danilov to take the case. Sterbick, whose Norwegian-immigrant family is full of sailors, met Nick and agreed to put him up in her Tacoma home until his immigration status is resolved. ``Seamen are brothers _ it's a law of the open sea,'' Sterbick explained. ``He's a warm and friendly young man and he reminds me a lot of my brothers.'' At a hearing Thursday, Danilov got bail lowered from $5,000 to $4,000, and by Friday afternoon had raised enough in contributions to post bail. Vetkovskij waved his arms and clenched his fists in victory outside the INS detention center while remaining detainees cheered from the second floor windows. ``Hey! Tomorrow we meet again!'' he shouted. Danilov said Vetkovskij will decide over the next few days whether to seek political asylum. A deportation hearing is set for July 27 but Danilov said he will ask for a three- or four-week delay to give him time to prepare. With the hearings and delays, Nick might be able to stay long enough to satisfy his curiosity.

DOC.HEAD: Brennan's Retirement Likely to Aid Court's Conservative March
DOC.TEXT: Justice William J. Brennan is leaving behind a Supreme Court legacy of commitment to individual rights and fairness, and his departure is likely to lead to a more conservative court, legal scholars said Saturday. Brennan, 84, announced Friday that he is leaving the court after nearly 34 years because of failing health and advancing age. His tenure spanned the administrations of eight presidents, and in recent years he has been a roadblock in a conservative march by the deeply divided justices. Scholars agreed President Bush's choice to succeed him inevitably will help take the court further to the right on the most divisive social issues of the day _ abortion rights, affirmative action, school prayer and the separation of church and state. ``He will be replaced by a justice surely more inclined to augment the state's power to regulate abortions, more accommodating of religion and more dubious of affirmative action,'' said University of Virginia law professor A.E. Dick Howard. Bruce Fein, a conservative court analyst, predicted the court will become ``a conservative juggernaut.'' Brennan ``was the intellectual glue,'' Fein said. ``The remaining liberals will be dispirited. They just don't have that strength and winsome character to bring up that fifth vote ... and keep their cherished rulings intact.'' But court watchers also said some of Brennan's major accomplishments will survive regardless of his successor. Robert Bennett, dean of Northwestern University's law school, said what is ``most impressive is the enduring aspects of Brennan's work. Some of those principles are almost unassailable.'' Bennett cited opinions Brennan authored that established the equal voting standard of ``one person, one vote'' and that gave the news media broad constitutional protection against libel suits by public figures. ``What Justice Brennan succeeded in doing was fashioning a body of jurisprudence that relied on fairness, equality and human decency,'' said Howard. ``The appeal of principles of that kind is lasting. He succeeded, I think, in distilling some of the better instincts of modern American life.'' Some of Brennan's more recent pronouncements on freedom of speech also might endure. Brennan wrote for the court last month when it struck down a federal law against flag burning. In a 5-4 ruling, Brennan said, ``The government may not prohibit the expression of an idea simply because society finds the idea itself offensive or disagreeable.'' Two of the court's most conservative members, Justices Antonin Scalia and Anthony M. Kennedy, were in the majority. Some legal scholars said that suggests that another conservative appointee by Bush also might side with liberals on free-speech issues. When Kennedy joined the court in 1988, he solidified a 5-4 conservative majority. He was the third justice to be picked by President Reagan, who also promoted William H. Rehnquist to chief justice. But liberals, led by Brennan, have managed to win important victories in key cases by attracting a normally conservative justice. For example, at the conclusion of its 1989-90 term last month, Brennan authored the court's 5-4 opinion upholding the federal government's broad power to grant preferential treatment to minorities. Scholars agree that Brennan's departure means more than a loss of a key liberal vote. The University of Virginia's Howard said Brennan combined unmatched experience and expertise, formidable intellectual skills and amiable personal qualities. ``No one hates Justice Brennan,'' Howard said. ``No one will fill those shoes.'' Brennan is a diminutive man whose physical stature and irresistible Irish charm remind some of a leprechaun. Justice Harry A. Blackmun, labeled a conservative when he joined the court but in recent years a reliable Brennan ally, has paid tribute to his colleague's peruasiveness and savvy. Blackmun has recalled how Brennan came up to him one day in a corridor in the court building, threw his arm around Blackmun and said, ``Harry, us liberals have to stick together.'' The most closely watched battleground between conservatives and liberals continues to be abortion rights. There appear to be four votes to overturn the court's 1973 ruling in Roe vs. Wade that established a constitutional right to an abortion. Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, the only woman ever to serve on the court, has provided a fifth vote to give states new power to regulate abortions but has stopped short of voting to overturn the 1973 ruling. Activists on both sides of the abortion debate expect Bush to name someone who will provide the pivotal vote to reverse Roe vs. Wade. ``Unless there is a massive and unprecedented political mobilization, Justice Brennan's departure may be a death knell for the right to choose in America,'' said Kate Michelman, head of the National Abortion Rights Action League. ``Justice Brennan's resignation shakes the so-called abortion rights to its very foundation,'' said Joseph M. Scheidler, director of the Chicago-based Pro-Life Action League. ``After 17 years, the court that invented a woman's right to destroy new life is rapidly disappearing. A new court is emerging.''

DOC.HEAD: USS New Jersey Readied For Decommissioning, Again
DOC.TEXT: One of the Navy's four battleships, the USS New Jersey, is being stripped and readied for decommissioning, the fourth time in its 47-year history. There were no bands, no pomp and circumstance and no admirals as the vessel, sporting menacing 16-inch guns and 17-inch armor, pulled up to Pier 6 at the Long Beach Naval Station on Friday. Its last journey was a brief one, running 45 minutes from Seal Beach where its crew unloaded ammunition. ``This is just another day in the life of the battleship,'' said the dreadnought's skipper, Capt. Ronald D. Tucker. Maybe. The New Jersey was recommissioned four times since it was launched Dec. 7, 1942, a year after the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor brought the United States into World War II. At a cost of $435 million, it was last recommissioned on Dec. 28, 1982, under former President Reagan's plans for a 600-ship Navy. The New Jersey's latest tour of duty included firing salvos at Syrian anti-aircraft batteries in the mountains of Lebanon in December 1983. But the ship cost more than $35 million a year to maintain, making it a dead-in-the-water target for congressional budget-cutters. Only three other battleships, the Iowa, the Missouri and the Wisconsin, exist. On Friday, its 1,500-man crew began preparing the 887-foot-long battleship for decommissioning in February. In March, the ship will be towed to join its sister ship, the USS Iowa, with the Navy's mothballed reserve fleet off Bremerton, Wash. In the Pacific Theater during World War II, its operations covered the Marshall Islands, New Guinea, the Marianas, Leyte, Luzon, Iwo Jima and Okinawa. The ship also saw action in the Korean and Vietnam wars.

DOC.HEAD: Boys File Complaint Over Creek Pollution
DOC.TEXT: At an age when the only form most youngsters see is a report card, three boys tired of finding garbage and sewage in their neighborhood creek have filed a complaint with county authorities. ``If we don't do something, who will?'' said 12-year-old Phillip Wortman. He and his 11-year-old brother, Rollin, and 12-year-old friend Steve Ryals filed a formal complaint with the Tulsa County Health Department in an effort to end trash and sewage dumping. ``We're talking about a life and death matter,'' Ryals said. ``Look at this. It's really polluted. Not too long ago, I got in the water and a rash immediately broke out on my skin.'' The 3-foot-wide creek is scattered with trash and junk, which is piled as much as 5 feet high on one bank. Everything from garbage and appliance parts to tires clutter the creek. In addition, there are plumbing pipes that protrude from the earth behind a couple of nearby homes. The boys claim the pipes occasionally discharge a smelly liquid into the creek, located in a suburban neighborhood on the outskirts of Tulsa. The Health Department began investigating the boys' complaint Friday, said department spokesman David Haynes. It's the first time he knows of that children have filed a pollution complaint, he said. The trio ``seem very serious about the condition of the area,'' Haynes said. Dumping trash and sewage is illegal but not uncommon, he added.

DOC.HEAD: Blacks Still Struggling To Win Top Spots in South
DOC.TEXT: Andrew Young's lackluster performance in last week's Georgia gubernatorial primary underscored the uphill battle black candidates are having as they seek some of the highest political posts in the South. After slowly gaining a presence in local and state government, blacks are making unprecedented runs for office in a region once known for racial discrimination. Though he failed to place first, Young has made it to an Aug. 7 runoff for the Democratic nomination for governor. Two other blacks are trying to win top elections elsewhere in the South. In North Carolina, Harvey Gantt is the Democratic nominee trying to unseat Republican Sen. Jesse Helms; in South Carolina, state Sen. Theo Mitchell has won the Democratic gubernatorial nomination. But Young, Gantt and Mitchell each are running against strong candidates, as well as a history that says voters in the predominantly white states generally cast ballots along racial lines. Young, a former Atlanta mayor, congressman, U.N. ambassador and civil rights movement veteran, finished 12 percentage points on Tuesday behind the front-runner _ Zell Miller, a four-term lieutenant governor. Gantt, the former mayor of Charlotte, N.C., is up against Helms, a nationally known incumbent who has been in office 18 years. Mitchell, a state senator from Greenville, S.C., is challenging Republican Gov. Carroll Campbell, a popular incumbent with strong ties to the Bush administration. Despite numerous differences between the three candidates, their opponents and their states, the three are bound by more than just the physical fact that they're black, said David Ruffin of the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, a black-oriented think tank in Washington. ``All these candidates are using politics to renegotiate the compact between society and blacks,'' said Ruffin, who edits the center's Focus magazine. ``All of them are looking for change. The big difference is in the conditions in which they're running.'' The nation has no black senators and one black governor, Virginia's L. Douglas Wilder, who was elected last year. Since winning the Democratic runoff in North Carolina in June, Gantt has been on the road meeting voters, trying to offset the financial advantage held by Helms, an archconservative who some consider politically vulnerable this year. ``We think what we're doing is building support that is deep and won't be swayed by Helms' 30-second (television) barrages,'' said Susan Jetton, Gantt's press secretary. Ms. Jetton said the Gantt campaign is finding plenty of anti-Helms sentiment across the state. ``He will have plenty of money and help in running against Helms,'' said Earl Black, a political science professor at the University of South Carolina. ``There is so much opposition to Helms that any Democratic candidate can expect good financing.'' But even some black supporters of Gantt aren't counting out Helms. Tyrone Brooks, a black Georgia state legislator who supports Gantt, said he was nonetheless skeptical about Gantt's chances in the North Carolina election. Brooks was asked about the North Carolinian earlier this month during a federal court hearing on a so-far-unsuccessful suit challenging the runoff provision of Georgia's election law. He testified that Gantt's runoff victory was an ``aberration'' and not representative of the climate for black candidates in Southern statewide elections. ``You can't say that because Mr. Gantt won in North Carolina, that we're going to win every runoff,'' Brooks said. Many political observers said the second-place finish in the Georgia primary was a disappointment for Young, who was well known and ran as a moderate stressing his talent for attracting business investment. But Young failed to win strong white support, and urban blacks failed to give him the overwhelming backing he counted on. Young said the morning after the primary vote was counted that he was unsure why the black vote was smaller than he wanted. Mitchell, on the other hand, attracted a sizable black vote in the Democratic primary and has been campaigning regularly at black churches, said Black. Mitchell soundly defeated state Sen. Ernest Passailaigue, a white, in the Democratic primary, earning 60 percent of the vote. Election officials said voter turnout was low overall but that Mitchell was helped by the high black turnout. He remains the underdog in the general election campaign, however. Keith R. Billingsley, an associate professor of political science at the University of Georgia, said Young's success with black voters may have been reduced because his two terms as mayor of predominantly black Atlanta were not an unqualified success among the city's residents. ``A number of black folks have told me they did not respect the way he ran the city, especially the police department,'' Billingsley said. Race has not emerged as an overt issue in any of the campaigns, though there is a definite racial undercurrent, said Billingsley. Young and Miller each have promised that the candidates' records will be the issue in their runoff campaign. ``They're going to talk about it (the record), and the voters are going to look at their color,'' Billingsley said.

DOC.HEAD: Cecil B. DeMille Trust Gives $1 Million to Academy Center
DOC.TEXT: The Cecil B. DeMille Trust has contributed $1 million to the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences' Center for Motion Picture Study. The donation was made by trustees Cecilia DeMille Presley, Peter DeMille Calvin and Joseph W. Harper, the grandchildren of the famous filmmaker. ``It seems absolutely right to us that a film maker of the stature of C.B. DeMille is being honored in this way,'' actor Karl Malden, the academy's president, said Friday. ``We're pleased and grateful that his grandchildren have made this important contribution to ensuring the future of this vital cultural resource,'' Malden said. DeMille was a founding member of the Academy and served on its Board of Governors from 1934 to 1940. Among his films were ``The Greatest Show on Earth,'' ``The Ten Commandments'' and ``The Squaw Man.'' He died in 1959. The center is currently under renovation and is scheduled to reopen Nov. 12. The DeMille gift brings the center's endowment campaign to nearly 40 percent of a $15 million goal.

DOC.HEAD: Activist Prepares For Life After Bombing
LaserPhoto FX1
DOC.TEXT: The pipe bomb that maimed environmental activist Judy Bari of the militant Earth First! movement nearly killed her spirit, but she says the support of fellow environmentalists has revived her. ``I didn't have any will to keep going after this happened,'' she said, referring to the May 24 car bombing that broke her pelvis and partially paralyzed her right leg. Bari spoke about the bombing in Oakland and about what she considers an earlier attempt to kill her in an interview Thursday with The Associated Press at the rehabilitation center where she is undergoing therapy. She said that when a logging truck once ran her off a road, ``I was able to reach inside of myself and find the courage to go on. But this time I didn't have anything left. It was the support of the movement that enabled me to go on.'' Supporters suspect the bomb that injured Bari and passenger Darryl Cherney was planted by timber interests in retaliation for their roles organizing Redwood Summer, a series of protests against the logging of old-growth redwood forests. Bari said she had received several written death threats. She said she is kept awake nights by severe pain and fear that whoever planted the bomb might strike again. But most frustrating, she said, was that authorities suspected her and Cherney in the bombing. They were arrested for investigation of explosives possession and transportation because police suspected they were carrying a bomb that went off accidentally. ``I feel persecuted by the police. I don't feel protected by the police,'' Bari said. ``I'm the victim of a horrible crime, and I think I'm in a position where I need the police to protect me and find who did it. ``They have not for one minute dropped their view of me as a criminal simply because of my political views.'' Bari and her supporters felt vindicated last week when prosecutors said they would file no charges against the pair _ for the time being at least. But investigators insist no one has been exonerated and that their investigation of the explosion is continuing. Investigators have been hampered by the refusal of some Earth First! supporters to cooperate, said Oakland police Lt. Mike Sims. ``People who may support Bari and Cherney's side of the story have been directed by attorneys to refuse to talk to us,'' he said. Bari has a simple response. ``As long as they are presuming me guilty, then we are foolish to cooperate with them,'' she said. At issue: the tactics favored by some Earth First! members, including ``monkey-wrenching'' _ acts of sabotage against those who, they feel, are damaging the environment. Such sabotage has included tree spiking _ driving large nails into trees, which can damage power saws and risk injury to timber and mill workers. Earth First! activists also have chained themselves to tree-cutting machines, blocked logging roads and occupied road-building equipment. But members say the group takes no official stance on such activity and that its members are mostly involved in acts of civil disobedience. Bari herself has rejected the use of sabotage, although she does not condemn all of it. The bombing has helped change the movement to save the redwood forests, she believes. ``Obviously, it has galvanized a lot of attention,'' she said. ``But on the other hand it knocked out the experienced leadership. So I think it had both a negative and a positive effect.'' Although more moderate environmental groups have joined Earth First! in calling for an independent investigation of the bombing, most have not spoken out in favor of the Earth First! movement itself. Bari is pleased by reports of anti-logging protests, although none of the protests yet this summer has attracted the many thousands of people organizers boasted would flock to the region. Bari wonders when she'll be well enough to take an active role in the movement. ``I've been really terrified to the depths of my soul,'' she said, but added: ``My brain is still functioning.''

DOC.NOTE: For release at 6:30 p.m. EDT
DOC.HEAD: Air Force Says Two B-2s May Be Delayed; Aspin To Urge Program Killed
DOC.TEXT: The Air Force has told Congress it needs another $1.4 billion to acquire two B-2 bombers on schedule, an admission bound to further erode congressional support for the radar-evading aircraft. Air Force Secretary Donald B. Rice notified House Armed Services Chairman Les Aspin, D-Wis., of the budget shortfall in a letter obtained by The Associated Press over the weekend. It came on the eve of a speech Monday by Aspin in which, congressional sources say, he will propose canceling the B-2 program entirely. Aspin, who kept the increasingly expensive plane alive with compromise legislation last year, has been moving towards halting funds for the program because of its high cost, which has skyrocketed to about $860 million each. The pricetag may surpass the $1 billion mark based on the latest revelations. Proponents of House legislation to limit the program to the planes currently in production say they are a handful of votes short of the number needed for approval. But the plane still has staunch support in the Senate, where the chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, Sam Nunn, D-Ga., is a key proponent. Rice, in his letter dated July 11, said that without the $1.4 billion, acquisition of the two bombers will have to be delayed until 1997. The two B-2s are among 15 bombers intended to be bought through 1990 at a cost of $27 billion. The Air Force had begun procurement of the two planes in 1988 and 1989. Rice also said that the cost of buying two other B-2s and related items in the 1991 fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 will total $4.6 billion, an increase of about $500 million from the original figure. Rice blamed the increase in costs primarily on a jump in overhead charges and changes in the production rate. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, facing economic pressure and a lessening Soviet threat, in April revised plans for the B-2, cutting the total number of aircraft planned from 132 to 75 and the 1990 budget request from five to two. Rice said Cheney's revision pushed the shortfall to an estimated $1.4 billion. This shortfall ``will become a liability when the contracts'' are signed and executed, Rice said in the letter. Initialing of the contracts is expected in December 1990 and the summer of 1991. The Air Force examined several options to make up the shortfall, including using unobligated money from past years or supplemental appropriations. The service has decided to restructure the previous year's purchases of 15 planes. ``This restructure would involve moving two aircraft to fiscal 1997, one from fiscal 1988 ... and one from fiscal 1989,'' Rice said. Thus, instead of the Air Force's current plans for 15 planes to be bought through 1990 at a cost of about $27 billion, the Air Force would be left with 13 planes. Rice said the B-2 is ``not unique to this type of shortfall as program costs react to changes in quantity or schedule.''

DOC.HEAD: Man Who Breaks into Jail Gets to Stay
DOC.TEXT: A man has been sentenced to a year in jail _ for breaking into jail. ``It's the first time I've ever had where somebody was trying to break into jail,'' Assistant District Attorney Chuck Rosenthal said. David Matthew Winfree, 22, pleaded guilty to burglary for breaking into the Municipal Prison Farm and was sentenced Friday to a year in the Harris County Jail. Winfree, a landscaper, was apprehended inside a maintenance building Thursday with a $270 battery charger. He told police he was looking for landscaping tools to steal, said Rosenthal. ``It's gotten to the point that the judicial system has made it so attractive for criminals that criminals ask us for prison time instead of probation,'' said State District Judge Michael McSpadden. ``But we've hit an all-time low when they start knocking down doors to get into prison.'' McSpadden referred to recent incidents where people have asked for prison time instead of probation because they expected to be out of prison quickly, without the inconvenience of being on probation. The state's overcrowded prison system has forced authorities to release many inmates early.

DOC.HEAD: Dies in River Day Before Wedding
DOC.TEXT: A man who was to have been married Saturday drowned a day earlier as he sought relief from heat in a section of river posted as dangerous. Steve Ensey, 25, of Bakersfield, along with his cousin, Jim Cook of Los Angeles, disappeared Friday after they slid down a rock into a section of rapids on the swift Kern River. Ensey's best man, Mark Fisher, called authorities and divers recovered the victims' bodies, said Kern County Senior Deputy Jim Johnson. He said the area, three miles from the mouth of Kern River Canyon, is considered dangerous and is posted as such. However, even while divers looked for the drowning victims, other people continued swimming nearby to escape 100-degree heat, he said. More than 150 people have drowned in that stretch of the Kern 125 miles north of Los Angeles since the sheriff's department started keeping a count in 1968, Johnson said.

DOC.HEAD: Geography, Lifestyle Make Boulder Attractive To Traffickers, Authorities Say
DOC.TEXT: Boulder's two most attractive features _ its laid-back lifestyle and rugged geography _ also help attract drug traffickers who use it as a base, law enforcement and city officials say. Federal grand juries in Denver last week indicted 12 men allegedly involved in two separate marijuana smuggling rings based in Boulder. One of the operations is believed to be the biggest ever to operate in Colorado, smuggling an estimated 100,000 pounds of pot into this country from Mexico from 1978 to 1988. ``There obviously is an attraction to the area,'' said police Sgt. Joe Pelle. ``I think there are several reasons why Boulder is popular. It is secluded and affluent.'' ``The feds tell me the majority of cases they have in Colorado have Boulder ties,'' Pelle said. Pelle noted that only a small fraction of the marijuana imported into Boulder is actually distributed in the Boulder-Denver area. Boulder, snuggled against the Flatiron Mountains, is a city of about 80,000 and is home of the University of Colorado. Pelle and other officials said they do not believe Boulder has any higher proportion of drug users than other college towns. One indictment named six men who allegedly ran the state's largest marijuana trafficking operation. That indictment resulted from a two-year investigation initiated when a maid discovered $42,000 while cleaning a motel room in Boulder. About $10 million worth of cash, gold, artworks, rare coins and other valuables have been impounded from members of the group, and federal authorities are seeking the forfeiture of a total of $50 million in assets, officials said. Four members of that group are in custody. In the other Boulder drug case that came to light last week, six other men were accused of smuggling 10,000 pounds of pot into the city from Mexico from 1986 to 1989. All six were arrested.
