The alleged ringleader of this group was nicknamed the champagne smuggler. The group apparently marked dates and load sizes on champagne corks to record their ventures. Boulder Mayor Leslie Durgin said she is not sure Boulder has any more drug operations than other cities, but cited many lifestyle characteristics of the community in explaining why it tends to be a base for smuggling operations. ``There is a willingness of people in Boulder to be tolerant. We give people quite a bit of room in their own lives,'' she said. ``That's something we're proud of in Boulder, the tolerance of diversity and the space given in individual lives.'' Robert Pence, head of the Denver FBI office, noted that the relative affluence of Boulder allows drug traffickers to live a comfortable lifestyle without drawing attention to themselves. ``It's not that Boulder has a corner on the market, they're all over, but the city has been popular with what I would call the yuppie-type drug traffickers,'' he said. Pence said Boulder's geography also makes it hospitable to drug smugglers. Because it is near the mountains the operators can find relatively secluded houses and still be close to Boulder and to Denver, 30 miles away. Boulder also has easy access to interstate highways and has three small airports nearby, and its central location in the United States makes it an ideal distribution center, said Pence. Pence said Boulder's liberal politics and its reputation as a fun place to live also tend to attract drug operators. ``It has a lifestyle they're comfortable with,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Restive Republics Mark 50th Anniversary of Soviet Sovereignty
With AM-Soviet-Communists, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Baltic republics on Saturday quietly marked what Lithuania called ``a day of injury, humiliation and tragedy,'' the 50th anniversary of the declaration of Soviet power over them. Flags flew at half-staff in the Lithuanian capital of Vilnius, and Latvia announced its lawmakers had voted to nullify the 1940 declaration of Soviet power. For decades, July 21 had been celebrated officially as a holiday in Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania. But the three Baltic republics in the last year have expanded their sovereignty and announced their intention to break with the Soviet Union. Lithuania's prime minister was quoted Saturday as saying that negotiations with Soviet officials on the republic's March 11 declaration of independence could start next week. Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia were independent of Moscow briefly between the two world wars. But under a secret agreement Stalin and Hitler signed in 1939, they fell into the Soviet sphere of influence. Soviet soldiers moved in as Nazi forces attacked Poland, and under Soviet pressure the parliaments of the three republics voted to join the Soviet Union. They were admitted as Soviet republics in early August of 1940. Thousands of Lithuanians, Latvians and Estonians were killed, sent into exile or prison. The Latvian Supreme Soviet parliament voted Thursday to void the 50-year-old declaration of Soviet power, Aris Yansons, an assistant to Latvian President Anatoly Gorbunov, said Saturday. The proclamation strengthened the parliament's condemnation of the act in February. The official Soviet news agency Tass quoted a Latvian government statement Saturday as saying July 21, 1940, marked the start of ``mass terror and genocide against the residents of Latvia, the consequences of which are still being felt.'' Lithuania's government said in a statement Saturday that ``the 21st of July remains a day of injury, humiliation and tragedy in our memory.'' Aidas Palubinskas, a spokesman for the Lithuanian Supreme Council parliament, said flags were flying at half-mast at the parliament building and a few other locations in Vilnius. He said supporters of Soviet power held a small rally in a city park, but the day otherwise was quiet. A small rally was also held Friday in Tallinn, Estonia, but the anniversary itself was ``a typical Saturday,'' said an editor at official Estonian Radio. The Soviet Union's main newspapers carried long articles Saturday backing the Kremlin position by depicting the Baltics' absorption into the country as voluntary. They also published a call by national parliamentary leaders for ``responsibility and common sense.'' The small Communist Party faction in Lithuania that has remained loyal to Moscow also issued a statement saying the republic joined the Soviet Union voluntarily, the party daily Pravda reported. Meanwhile, Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimeira Prunskiene said in an interview published Saturday that the republic could start negotiations next week with Soviet officials, ``and the Soviet side is ready for this.'' ``I would say that our dialogue now is taking place in a very calm tone,'' she told the Interfax news service, which is affiliated with official Radio Moscow. Lithuania agreed on June 29 to put a 100-day moratorium on its declaration of independence, starting when negotiations formally begin with Soviet officials. The Kremlin then halted an economic embargo that had shut off oil shipments, most natural gas and many other goods and raw materials. Mrs. Prunskiene said she and another Lithuanian official, Bronus Kuzmickas, had a ``short and concrete'' conversation with Gorbachev on Friday after a joint meeting of the Presidential and Federation councils to discuss economic reform and a new treaty between Moscow and the Soviet republics. She said both sides expressed the desire ``to start negotiations, and strive for a convergence of positions in order to sign an agreement.''

DOC.HEAD: Amid Battle Over Defense Budget, Bush Touts Need for Strong Navy
DOC.TEXT: President Bush took his campaign against big defense cuts to one of the nation's few remaining shipyards Saturday, saying the United States must retain a strong military despite the apparent demise of the Cold War. ``While freedom has made great gains, we have not entered an era of perpetual peace,'' Bush said at a christening ceremony for the nation's newest aircraft carrier, the George Washington. Standing in a shadow of the carrier's massive bow, Bush quoted the nation's first president: ```To be prepared for war is one of the most effective means of preserving the peace.''' The message contrasted with Bush's recent attempts to persuade Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev that the United States poses no military threat. After the 40-minute ceremony the president flew from nearby Langley Air Force Base to his mountain retreat at Camp David, Md. The visit to Newport News was Bush's second defense-related trip in as many days. On Friday he traveled to Warren Air Force Base near Cheyenne, Wyo., where all 50 of the nation's MX intercontinental ballistic missiles are stationed in silos. The focus on defense coincides with growing debate in Congress over how deeply and quickly military spending should be reduced as a result of the collapse of the Soviet threat in Europe and the spawning of democracies in the East bloc. Speaking at the Newport News Shipbuilding yard, Bush made no mention of the budget debate on Capitol Hill. At Warren on Friday, however, the president said he was willing to accept a Senate Armed Services Committee proposal for a $289 billion defense budget for the coming fiscal year. Bush said Congress must ``hold the line'' at the Senate panel's spending figure and that he needed greater flexibility in pruning the size of the armed forces. The Senate panel called for cutting 100,000 personnel from the total armed services of 2.1 million. That is nearly three times the number Bush has proposed dropping. In his February budget request, Bush asked Congress to hold defense spending to $307 billion. As recently as last week Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said the administration was not ready to abandon its proposal. With the Navy's top officers at his side during the carrier christening ceremony, Bush said the United States must sustain a superpower military strength. ``We must maintain a policy of peacetime engagement and armed forces sufficient to sustain our vital national interest,'' he said. ``We are ... the pivotal factor of stability. We will not shrink from this responsibility.'' Barbara Bush, with the president and their daughter Dorothy LeBlond at her side, performed the formal christening of the 1,040-foot carrier. She stood on a platform directly beneath the ship's bow and smashed a bottle of champagne against the hull. For the occasion Bush, a former Navy pilot who flew combat missions from a Pacific-based carrier during World War II, wore a navy blue tie adorned with aviator wings. Bush praised the Newport News shipbuilders, noting that the yard constructed the nation's first carrier, the Ranger, in 1934 and that it had produced 239 others since then. ``Few realize the magnitude of your task _ what it means to build a state-of-the-art supercarrier: a warship, a floating city, and an airport, all rolled into one,'' Bush said. The $3.1 billion George Washington is due to enter service in 1992. It is the sixth Nimitz-class carrier to be built; two more are in development. In all, the Navy has 15 active carriers, including one in overhaul.

DOC.HEAD: Police, Protesters Clash After Huge Anti-Government Rally
LaserPhoto SEL7
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 14th graf pvs, `The push...' to CORRECT time element to this week. Pick up 15th graf pvs, `On the...'
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of protesters clashed Saturday with riot police after a huge anti-government rally that drew together South Korea's splintered opposition and attracted about 300,000 people. Also Saturday, President Roh Tae-woo said South Korea is willing to negotiate conditions set by North Korea before it will consider allowing unrestricted travel between the rival nations. There were no immediate reports of arrests or injuries in Seoul. The anti-government rally at a park in the southern part of the city was the first since Roh's election in 1987 in which the spectrum of opposition groups joined forces. ``Down with Roh Tae-woo!'' protesters screamed as they poured into the streets after the rally. The clash broke out as riot police blocked a column of about 20,000 radical students at a bridge leading toward the center of the capital. The demonstrators ripped up sidewalks and threw chunks of concrete at police, who fired tear gas during the hour-long battle. In the southern city of Kwangju, an opposition stronghold, police firing tear gas stormed Chonnam University to break up an anti-government rally by about 1,000 students and dissidents, news reports said. There were no reports of arrests or injuries. At the Seoul rally, thousands of laborers, housewives, students with red headbands and men in business suits cheered as opposition speakers demanded new general elections. The speakers called for a common front against the Roh government, which they claimed has lost public confidence. ``Let's strike while the iron's hot,'' said Kim Dae-jung, head of the leading Party for Peace and Democracy. ``We must form a new National Assembly and hold new general elections.'' Six huge air balloons floated overhead, lowering streamers emblazoned with anti-government slogans such as ``Crush Roh Tae-woo!'' Radical students used red paint to daub anti-government slogans on park roads. ``Unification of all opposition forces is a call of the era,'' said Lee Ki-taek, head of the splinter opposition group, the Democratic Party. ``Let's make this moment the beginning of a new march for democracy.'' The rally came a day after the nation's two opposition parties, led by Kim and Lee, agreed to merge into a new unified party, to be joined by other dissidents. They promised to finish the merger before September. If successful, it would be the first unified opposition party in Korean history. South Korea's opposition, always divided, has never posed a serious threat to the government. The push for the merger intensified after all 78 opposition lawmakers in the 299-member National Assembly pledged to resign this week to protest the pushing through parliament of several controversial bills, including one aimed at reshaping the nation's broadcast industry. On the border-opening issue, the latest round of discussion began Friday, when Roh proposed the opening of the heavily fortified boundary on a trial basis in August. Although North Korea immediately denounced Roh's free travel proposal, Roh told a Cabinet meeting Saturday that Seoul ``must continue ... efforts to achieve the goal, and we can actively discuss points of contention with them.'' To prepare for free travel, North Korea said South Korea should first demolish ``concrete walls'' allegedly built along the border, repeal security laws banning pro-North Korean activity and release people jailed for violating such laws. The Korean peninsula was divided into the Communist north and the capitalist south at the end of World War II. The nations' border is tightly sealed and guarded by more than 1.5 million troops. There is no mail or telephone service between the countries.

DOC.HEAD: Vice President's Wife Undergoes Surgery
DOC.NOTE: EDS: UPDATES and EDITS throughout to attribute medical information to expert, give health background on Mrs. Quayle and mother. ADDS byline
DOC.TEXT: Marilyn Quayle, wife of Vice President Dan Quayle, underwent gynecological surgery Saturday following a test primarily used to detect cancer and was ``recovering well,'' her spokesman said. Although press secretary David Beckwith disclosed neither the specific reason for the surgery nor the hospital where it was performed, he said Mrs. Quayle's ``disease'' was diagnosed early with a Pap test. ``The Quayle family is thankful that this test was able to detect her disease at its earliest stages,'' Beckwith said, reading from a prepared statement. He would not elaborate. The spokesman said she ``is recovering well following surgery this morning. Mrs. Quayle will be able to resume her full schedule in four to six weeks. Full and total recovery is expected.'' A Pap test can help detect 25 to 30 possible medical problems, but its primary purpose is to screen for malignancies and pre-malignancies in the reproductive tract, said Dr. Allan B. Weingold, chairman of obstetrics and gynecology at the George Washington University Medical Center. Weingold, who has no personal knowledge of Mrs. Quayle's condition, said of the 25 to 30 possible diagnoses, 15 to 20 could be for malignancies or pre-malignancies. The rest could be for infections and hormonal changes. Mrs. Quayle turns 41 a week from Sunday. Friends had given her a surprise party on Friday at a skating rink in a Virginia suburb of Washington. Other than a sprained ankle she suffered a year ago, this is the first reported health problem for Mrs. Quayle. Her mother, Mary Tucker, died of breast cancer in 1975 at the age of 56.

DOC.HEAD: Press Is Biased and Blind to It, Says a Report
DOC.TEXT: A conservative research organization is trying to convince the nation's press that it is biased. The Media Research Center has mailed out to newspapers and other opinion-makers 8,000 copies of a report that uses hundreds of examples to make the case that the media ``serve as a cheerleader'' for liberal causes. The booklength report, ``And That's the Way It Isn't,'' pictures a national press corps composed of liberals who surround themselves with like-minded friends and colleagues to the point they are oblivious to what mainstream American thinks. And, it says, these journalists are blind to their own tendency to give a liberal spin to the news. ``Their friends are liberals, their sources are liberals, what they read and hear is written by liberals,'' it says. ``This helps explain why policies considered `liberal' by the public are seen as `mainstream' by reporters and editors.'' The center describes itself as ``a conservative media foundation.'' Brent Baker, executive director and the book's co-editor, said copies have been mailed to college professors and libraries, politicians, think tanks and news bureaus in Washington, and to radio talk show hosts, editorial writers and political editors across the country. He said the conservative William H. Donner Foundation is furnishing between $50,000 and $100,000 to help pay for the project. The rest of the money comes from the center's own finances, provided by gifts of $1,000 to $25,000 a year from several hundred supporters. The book is a compilation of more than 40 studies that, taken together, says Baker, are ``hard to dismiss as an aberration.'' Most of the studies cite examples drawn from ``big media'' _ The New York Times, The Washington Post, The Wall Street Journal, the papers of the Gannett Co., which publishes USA Today, Time, The Associated Press, United Press International, the American Broadcasting Co., National Broadcasting Co., Columbia Broadcasting System, Public Broadcasting System, and Cable News Network. Researcher Stephen Hess of the Brookings Institution, author of three books about the Washington press and of a study cited in the report, takes issue with the report. He said the press ``has become increasingly professional'' and lives up to a set of standards ``which work as a brake against their personal bias and inclination.'' The nation's agenda is set not by the press, but by the politicians, candidates and businessmen who hold the news conferences, issue the reports and conduct the hearings that the media report on. Conceding that the media were unable to prevent the election or re-election of Ronald Reagan, the report said, ``No, they don't win every time, but they do win most of the time,'' it says. The report cites: _Surveys of the political attitudes of journalists. It says they consistently show they're more liberal than the public. _Studies of what journalists did in other careers. It contends that most who move from the political world into journalism come from liberal quarters. _Compilations of quotes from journalists ``in unguarded moments'' that show their true colors. As an example the report cites a quote from ABC newsman David Brinkley in the Washington Post Magazine: ``If I had to pick the best presidents in my lifetime, I would of course pick Roosevelt and Kennedy, and I would also pick Harry Truman.'' _Counts showing how often some terms such as ``ultraconservative'' and ``ultraliberal'' are used. It says they show that ``conservatives were far more likely than liberals to be painted as ideologues and extremists.''

DOC.HEAD: Pizza: The Iowa-USSR Connection
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Last name `Trcka' is cq, pronounced Turch'-ka.
DOC.TEXT: The introduction of Pizza Hut to Moscow will also see the introduction of Margy Trcka from little Coralville, Iowa, to her first taste of life in another country. Trcka, manager of the Coralville Pizza Hut, is part of a five-member team leaving Aug. 1 to train 300 Soviets to make pizza for the chain's next restaurants. ``I've never been overseas. It will be quite the adventure for me,'' she said. ``It's kind of a mystery. I can picture myself lying on the beach in Mexico, maybe, but I can't see myself in Moscow.'' When she learned last spring that she had been selected from 5,300 managers to make the trip, Trcka enrolled in an eight-week language class at Kirkwood Community College. ``The thing I fear most is the language barrier. My favorite phrase is going to be `I do not speak Russian,''' Trcka said. The management team will train Soviet employees through interpreters. Pizza Hut, owned by Pepsico Inc., plans to open two restaurants in Moscow by the end of August. One Pizza Hut will be in surburban Moscow and will seat 325 people. ``It's about five times the size of my little Coralville Hut,'' Trcka said. The second will be near the recently opened McDonald's and will seat about 80 people. It won't be the first time Muscovites have been exposed to pizza. Two New Jerseyites, Louis Piancone Sr. of Newark and Ukranian-born entrepreneur Shelley M. Zeiger of Moorestown, entered a joint venture with Soviet officials in 1987 to take the company's Astro Pizza mobile concession truck to Moscow. The truck began selling to tourists and Soviet customers in April 1988. Trcka, along with managers from Florida, Illinois and New York, will spend three weeks training the 300 workers selected to staff the two Pizza Huts from about 6,000 applicants. In Coralville, a suburb of Iowa City in eastern Iowa, Trcka oversees a crew of 25. ``I've heard the Soviet people are very friendly and really take to Americans,'' she said. ``McDonald's broke some ground as far as smiling and such. They're getting used to Western culture.'' But while McDonald's emphasizes fast food, ``We're going to concentrate more on service and family dining.'' The restaurants will offer carryout service, ``a totally new concept for the Soviet Union,'' Ms. Trcka said. ``If all goes well, they'll consider delivery, too.''

DOC.HEAD: PLO Guerrillas, Syrian-Backed Militia Storm Hezbollah Stronghold
LaserPhoto BEI1
DOC.TEXT: Palestinian guerrillas and Syrian-supported Shiite militiamen stormed a Hezbollah mountain stronghold Saturday and at least 30 people, most of them fighters, were killed, police said. Seventy-two people were wounded in the fierce fighting in the villages of Jarjou and Kfar Milki. The day's battles raised the casualty toll in six days of fighting to at least 103 killed and 304 wounded. ``It's hand-to-hand fighting in Jarjou. The village square and the streets are littered with bodies. Almost every building has been shattered,'' said one security source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The fighting began Monday when the Islamic fundamentalist Hezbollah, or Party of God, attacked and seized Jarjou from the Syrian-backed Amal militia in an effort to expand its area of control toward the Mediterranean and open up a badly needed route to Iran, its main supplier of arms. PLO fighters have been trying to stop the fighting between the two Shiite groups, apparently to halt the Hezbollah advance toward Sidon, a southern port where PLO guerrillas are based. It is 10 miles northwest of Jarjou. Amal and Palestine Liberation Organization guerrillas fought a three-year war between 1985 and 1988, but joined together to storm the Hezbollah positions. Police said Saturday that about 300 Amal fighters and 250 Palestinians were ``nibbling their way'' into Jarjou on the southwestern tip of Hezbollah's enclave. But a police spokesman said: ``Hezbollah is not withdrawing despite the enormous pressure. The Hezbollahis are fighting tooth and nail, fighting a battle to the last bullet and dying in place.'' Both sides were reported moving in reinforcements and security sources said the Palestinians and Amal were massing forces and hauling in ammunition for an expected night assault. The Lebanese Red Cross appealed for urgent blood donations to cope with the casualties. The Palestinians, mainly men from Yasser Arafat's Fatah faction, and Amal militiamen launched their first attack on Jarjou at 3.a.m behind a curtain of fire from multi-barrelled rocket launchers and howitzers. They reached the village's main square by midday, police said. Hezbollah sent reinforcements from hills overlooking the village and launched a counterattack around 1 p.m., but was beaten back, the spokesman reported. Amal and Palestinian gunners shelled Jarjou's northern and eastern edges in an apparent effort to try to cut it off from Hezbollah reinforcements. The fundamentalists hammered the Palestinian-held southern part of the village with phosphorous shells, the spokesman said. Reporters near the battle zone said the village was on fire, with smoke billowing from almost every building. Hezbollah's radio station broadcast martial music. An announcer declared: ``O Allah, shatter the criminals who are attacking your men in Jarjou! O Allah, you will lead us to victory!'' Hezbollah and Amal have been fighting off and on for three years for control of Lebanon's 1.2 million Shiites, the country's largest sect. More than 1,100 people have been killed and some 3,400 wounded in the inconclusive showdown between the Shiite rivals. The PLO has roughly 5,000 guerrillas in south Lebanon. Amal has about 6,500 front-line fighters. Hezbollah can muster up about 2,000 Shiites, but has often defeated Amal in clashes.

DOC.HEAD: Hard Times for Soviet Communists
Laserphotos MOSB1,MOSB2
DOC.TEXT: Their policies are attacked from all sides. They are losing cars and country homes. And now they have to start paying their office telephone and electricity bills. For Communist officials in this ancient Russian city, these are not the best of times. And they may be a sign of things to come for other areas. Just ask Sergei Goryachev, the acting city party chief of Tver, a Russian city 105 miles northwest of Moscow on the Volga River. Recently, he took a vacation, and had some time to think. What he thought about was quitting the party. ``Of course there is worrying, serious worrying,'' said Goryachev, the 38-year-old son of a soldier. In his office in Tver, an ancient city once called Kalinin, a portrait of Soviet founder Vladimir Lenin stares from the wall. Looking at it, Goryachev summed up the result of his soul-searching. ``In this period, to leave would be pure betrayal,'' he said simply. But dozens of party leaders have come to the opposite conclusion. Spurred by dissatisfaction with the outcome of this month's 28th Communist Party Congress, loyalists are abandoning the party in droves. The exodus began with maverick politician Boris N. Yeltsin and has included other well-known figures: politicians, lawmakers, and the mayors of Leningrad and Moscow. The party is under attack from the left for keeping a hand in the KGB and army and police, and not sharing facilities including buildings and printing presses with would-be competitors. The right is angry that the party loosened its grip on Eastern European allies and is borrowing from capitalism in its economic reforms. It is not known how many Communists nationwide have turned in their party cards. But in the Tver region, 3,000 of the 150,000 members left the party in the first half of this year. Goryachev predicts more will quit. The unhappiness with the party is apparent when he meets with workers, he said. ``They are cold in the very beginning when you walk in,'' he said. ``But then, people see that you are the same as they, have the same problems and that the problems concern me.'' Many complaints, he said, are about privileges accorded party officials. Goryachev and other officials say many summer cottages, cars and medical facilities reserved for the party elite have been turned over to the public. Tver's 53-year-old regional party chief, Alexander Ilyenkov, acknowledges that hearing criticism is unpleasant. But nowadays, he freely admits the party has made mistakes. ``Many of the misfortunes today were generated by me and I take the responsibility,'' he tells the public. The party is taking responsibility in other ways as well. The phone and electricity bills of party offices at factories have traditionally been paid by the host organizations, Goryachev said. But to head off claims by prospective competing parties, such bills will now be paid out of the party budget, he said. The local party's four city committees are being consolidated into one, half of its 112 staff employees are to laid off and its budget is to be cut by two-thirds. Since the party has given up its constitutionally guaranteed monopoly of power, Tver's mayor, Sergei Kisilev, says he's ready to act in the spirit of the times. Although no opposition parties have officially registered in Tver, Kisilev says that if they do he will ``guarantee everyone equal conditions.'' The government, he says, will no longer pay for the party's use of the local TV station or non-party newspapers, and it will send a bill to the party for meetings in theaters and other public buildings. In keeping with Mikhail S. Gorbachev's reforms, Tver's party is also separating itself from the government. Goryachev says Tver's police chief used to call him regularly to report on crimes in the city _ but no more. Party departments that supervised the local KGB and other agencies are being abolished, he says. Ilyenkov believes the reforms will enable the party to win back the people's hearts. But he says the process won't be easy. Changing the party, he says, isn't like going to the tailor, where you simply step out ``in a renewed suit, discarding the old one.''

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Brennan's Successor Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Under the U.S. system of separation of powers, it is the president's job to choose Supreme Court nominees and the Senate's role to confirm or reject them. After the president announces his choice, the appointment goes to the Senate Judiciary Committee, which conducts hearings on the nominee. The committee has the power to block the nomination, but given the importance of the Supreme Court nominees, it's likely the nomination will be forwarded to the full Senate. Twenty-seven high court nominees in the nation's history have failed to win Senate confirmation, only seven in this century. Most recently, the Senate in 1987 blocked President Ronald Reagan's appointment of Robert Bork to fill a vacancy created by the retirement of Justice Lewis F. Powell. The Senate vote was 58-42, with six Republicans joining 52 Democrats in opposing Bork. Reagan's second choice, Douglas Ginsburg, withdrew after revealing he had smoked marijuana. The Senate then confirmed Reagan's third pick, Anthony M. Kennedy.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Brennan's Successor Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a brief description of the eight remaining justices of the Supreme Court. William Rehnquist, 65, appointed to the court in 1971 by President Richard Nixon and appointed chief justice by President Ronald Reagan in 1986. Once a frequent dissenter, he now is generally acknowledged as the leader of the court's working conservative majority. Rehnquist is well liked by his colleagues, who praise him for his informal, genial style. Byron R. White, 73, appointed to the court in 1962 by President John Kennedy. White generally votes with the conservatives, although his deference to federal power can produce some contrasting results. He voted with the liberals last month to uphold a key federal affirmative action program. He is among the court's most avid questioners of lawyers during oral arguments and can be abrasive. Thurgood Marshall, 82, appointed to the court in 1967 by President Lyndon Johnson. Brennan's most consistent ally, Marshall is the only black ever named to the court and is a figure of historic importance in the civil rights movement. But critics say his interest in court work has flagged in recent years. Marshall has been an outspoken critic of Reagan and has vowed to remain on the court as long as he is alive. Harry A. Blackmun, 81, appointed to the court in 1970 by Nixon. He is best known as the author of the 1973 ruling in Roe vs. Wade that established a woman's constitutional right to an abortion. Once labeled a conservative ``twin'' of former Chief Justice Warren E. Burger, he has cast generally liberal votes in recent years. John Paul Stevens, 70, appointed to the court in 1975 by President Gerald Ford. He is a maverick whose intellectual brilliance has been overshadowed by his independence. He generally votes with the liberals but is unpredictable. He was with the dissenters who voted to uphold laws against flag burning. Stevens is known for his bow tie and his incisive, and unfailingly polite, questioning of lawyers at oral arguments. Sandra Day O'Connor, 60, appointed to the court in 1981 by Reagan. The only woman ever to be a justice, she has controlled the balance of power until now on abortion issues. She also has been a swing vote on affirmative action. O'Connor is generally conservative but has provided some key liberal votes, particularly on issues affecting women's rights. She is hardworking and not given to broad pronouncements or sweeping rulings. She underwent a mastectomy last year and says her cancer has been cured. Antonin Scalia, 54, appointed to the court in 1986 by Reagan. A scholar and jurist of unquestioned brilliance, he has tried to pull the court further to the right and has been outspoken in criticizing conservative colleagues who prefer incremental change. Scalia has a libertarian streak and strict adherence to constitutional principles that occasionally produce a surprise. He cast a recent dissenting vote when the court refused to grant child abuse suspects the right to confront their young accusers in court. Anthony M. Kennedy, 53, appointed to the court in 1988 by Reagan. The court's newest member solidified a conservative majority but says he has felt no special pressure in being a pivotal figure. An unassuming Californian, he was Reagan's third choice for a vacancy created by the retirement of centrist Justice Lewis F. Powell. Kennedy's major defections from the conservative camp were his votes to strike down laws against flag burning.

DOC.HEAD: People In The News
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to add detail on pollution fear.
DOC.TEXT: Singer Diana Ross is singing the blues over a truck weigh station being built near her home in this celebrity enclave. ``I try to talk to people about the weigh station _ and nobody listens,'' said Ross. Ross said on Friday that she did get a good reception from Democratic gubernatorial candidate Bruce Morrison. Morrison, a congressman from Hamden, agrees with Ross and some of her neighbors in the Belle Haven section of Greenwich that the truck weigh station being built on Interstate 95 probably poses an environmental hazard. They argue that exhaust from idling engines would pollute the air and that fuel spills could make their way into the nearby Long Island Sound. After having lunch with Ross and 17 other Greenwich residents, Morrison pledged to keep the $6 million weigh station from operating if elected governor. ``He seems like a nitty-gritty type of guy,'' Ross said. ``I want to have a voice, and he listens.'' The 46-year-old former Supreme's Greenwich estate was once the home of tobacco heiress Nancy Reynolds.

DOC.HEAD: Reviewing Oliver North Trial Testimony Could Prove Overwhelming
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS grafs 1-3 with 4 grafs to UPDATE with new quote and add that dropping case is possible, although unlikely. SUBS 11th graf pvs, bgng: Walsh could, to include estimated costs of Iran-Contra prosecution. Picks up 12th graf pvs, Walsh's office
DOC.TEXT: The prospect of reviewing every single word of testimony in Oliver North's Iran-Contra trial is so daunting, prosecutors may decide instead to appeal the court-ordered examination. They also could drop the case altogether, but that's unlikely given the track record of the Iran-Contra prosecutor's office, which has been aggressively pursuing the arms and money scandal for more than 3{ years. The demanding review called for by a federal appeals court suggests that prosecutors ``will fight tooth and nail not to have to go through this tremendously cumbersome hearing procedure,'' said Paul Rothstein, a criminal law professor at Georgetown University. Gerald Caplin, a George Washington University law professor, said he would be ``surprised if the government doesn't appeal.'' The appeals court Friday vacated all three convictions and sent the case back to U.S. District Judge Gerhard Gesell for a hearing to determine whether the case was tainted by the former White House aide's televised testimony to Congress. North testified before Congress with a grant of immunity from prosecution. In addition, the court reversed one conviction outright _ that North altered and destroyed National Security Council documents. That means the only way the conviction might be reinstated would be through a new trial. The hearing process required by the appeals court ``may be unworkable,'' acknowledged Paul L. Friedman, an attorney who formerly worked in the office of North's prosecutor, Lawrence Walsh. ``If you really have to proceed witness by witness, that's a heavy procedural burden,'' Friedman said. One way for the Iran-Contra prosecutor's office to proceed would be to seek Supreme Court review of the appeals court decision. If Walsh concludes the appeals court decision ``goes beyond what is required'' by the Supreme Court, ``then I think there is a strong argument that Walsh go directly and get them to reverse this opinion,'' Friedman said. Alternatively, the prosecution could seek a review by all 12 members of the court of appeals. Or it could attempt to proceed with the hearing process before Gesell. Walsh could decide not to continue with the North case. His office has said that it cost $20.9 million through May 31 to convict seven individuals and one corporation. Others have put the cost as high as $40 million. Walsh's office said only that ``We are studying the opinions to determine the most appropriate next step.'' A jury convicted North on May 4, 1989, of three of the 12 charges he faced. They were aiding and abetting an obstruction of Congress, altering and destroying NSC documents and accepting an illegal gratuity. North on July 5, 1989, was sentenced to a suspended prison term, was fined $150,000, put on two years' probation and ordered to perform 1,200 hours of community service. Gesell's inquiry ``must proceed witness-by-witness,'' said the appeals court in a ruling supported by Reagan administration appointees Laurence Silberman and David Sentelle. Chief Judge Patricia Wald, a Carter administration appointee, dissented. ``If necessary, it will proceed line-by-line and item-by-item,'' the court added. The majority on the court panel suggested that North's Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination may have been violated. North was compelled to testify to Congress under a grant of immunity. In that nationally televised testimony, he admitted many of the activities for which he was later charged with crimes. The ruling also could signify trouble ahead for the Iran-Contra case against North's old boss, former national security adviser John Poindexter, who was convicted of five felonies in the Iran-Contra case last April. Like North, Poindexter had given immunized testimony to Congress in 1987. The question of taint in regard to Poindexter's testimony will be a major issue on appeal, said Richard Beckler, one of his lawyers.

DOC.HEAD: Spain Reinforces Embassy Guard, Police Surround Embassy
DOC.TEXT: Nine more Cubans sought refuge Saturday in the Spanish Embassy in Havana, bringing the total of asylum-seekers to 18, Spanish officials said. Cuban police surrounded the embassy and Spain said it was beefing up its guard. Diplomats wrangled, meanwhile, over whether to grant the Cubans asylum and safe conduct out of the Caribbean island nation, according to officials and news reports. Fidel Castro's Communist government has been insisting that all asylum-seekers surrender to Cuban authorities without condition. The government has called all those who have gone into the Spanish, Czechoslovak and Italian embassies and diplomatic residences in recent days ``scum'' and habitual vagrants. Spain has been insisting they should all be given asylum. In Madrid, the government announced it plans to send four or five more members of a tactical police squad to Havana to reinforce security at the embassy. A Spanish official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the police would leave ``as soon as possible'' to join four other members who arrived in Havana Thursday. The official said four more Cubans entered the embassy grounds early Saturday, and five more gained access two hours later. Nine Cubans were already holed up in the embassy. The Spanish news agency EFE said the first group entered the embassy by way of a terrace, while the second group scaled one of the embassy's outer walls and broke a balcony while trying to enter the building. Notimex, the official Mexican news agency, said Cuban police blocked several streets near the embassy and completely surrounded it. Another four Cubans are at the residence of the Italian ambassador. Five Cubans spent a week in a Czechoslovak diplomat's apartment but gave up their bid for asylum Thursday after the Cuban government assured them they would not be prosecuted. Cuban officials have been accusing foreign diplomats of encouraging people to seek refuge at the embassies as part of a plot to destabilize the Castro regime, one of the few orthodox hard-line Communist administrations left. Foreign diplomats have rejected the accusations as unfounded, accusing Cuban police in turn of violating diplomatic territory to make arrests. In one incident, they said Cuban police entered Spanish Embassy grounds to seize a refugee. The U.S. State Department called the Cuban accusations ``outrageous'' and a U.S. statement accused Cuban agents of trying several times to compromise U.S. officials in Havana in recent months. In Washington, Michael Kozak, a deputy assistant secretary of state, called in a Cuban diplomat Friday to lodge a formal protest. The United States cut diplomatic relations and imposed a trade embargo on Cuba in 1960, but under a 1977 agreement the two countries maintain interest sections in other embassies in each others' capitals. In April 1980, thousands of Cubans jammed the Peruvian Embassy in Havana. Soon after that, many joined what became the Mariel boat lift, which eventually took 125,000 Cubans to Florida. Spain recalled its ambassador in Havana for consultations on Thursday after Cuba _ a Spanish colony for 406 years until 1898 _ called Spanish Foreign Minister Francisco Fernandez Ordonez a ``frustrated colonial administrator'' and a victim of ``historical amnesia.'' The Cuban government rebuked Fernandez for having publicly suggested that Castro should be cautious about allowing Cubans to leave since their departure would cause his regime to crumble.

DOC.HEAD: POW@MIA Groups Welcome U.S. Policy Shift on Vietnam
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs 8th graf, ``Gareth Porter xxx to CORRECT figure from 50,000 to 60,000
DOC.TEXT: Americans with loved ones dead or missing from the Vietnam War are welcoming President Bush's decision to hold Cambodian peace talks with the heirs of Ho Chi Minh. Richard Cockrell of Sandusky, Ohio, moist-eyed after viewing the names of friends and classmates on the Vietnam Memorial wall, spoke for many. ``Somebody's got to start talking,'' the veteran of Navy service in Vietnam said. ``We've been to war with them and that didn't solve anything.'' Randy Elmore, a member of the Vietnam Veterans of America post in Bellingham, Wash., which has kept a chair vacant at its meetings for a local man who disappeared in the Southeast Asia fighting, agreed. ``The Vietnamese hold all the cards on the prisoners of war,'' Elmore said in a telephone interview from Bellingham. ``Opening the dialogue is a good idea.'' Except for limited contacts concerning servicemen still listed as prisoners of war or missing in action, the United States has shunned talks with the Vietnamese regime since Ho Chi Minh's communist North Vietnamese defeated U.S.-backed South Vietnam in 1975. Secretary of State James A. Baker III ended that era Wednesday, disclosing in Paris that the administration will take up the question of peace in Cambodia directly with the Hanoi government, which installed the current government in Phnom Penh. A Baker aide said the decision was approved by the president. Gareth Porter, who was in Vietnam during the war as a journalist and now teaches international relations at American University, found it not surprising that Americans welcome the talks with the regime that nearly 60,000 of them died fighting. ``I think they have been ready for far longer than the administration,'' said Porter. ``The administration has lagged behind public opinion on the question of letting bygones be bygones.'' Prior to Baker's announcement, members of Congress had urged Bush to change U.S. policy in Cambodia, where a U.S.-backed coalition that includes the communist Khmer Rouge is battling Cambodian government forces. Representatives of organizations seeking the recovery of the estimated 2,302 Americans still missing in Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia said they welcome the administration's initiative. ``If the U.S. government feels that announced official Cambodian discussions with the Vietnamese will help bring a solution to the Cambodian problem, then I think all Americans would have to applaud that,'' said Ann Mills Griffiths, executive secretary of the National League of Families of American Prisoners and Missing in Southeast Asia. Dolores Alfond of Seattle, chairwoman of the National Alliance of Families for the Return of America's Missing Servicemen, said, ``We are very anxious for dialogue, but of course we feel that in the dialogue, there should be negotiations for our prisoners of war.'' Ms. Alfond, whose brother, Air Force Capt. Victor Apodaca, disappeared during a 1967 flight over North Vietnam, welcomed Baker's statement that normalization is linked to Hanoi's cooperation on the missing in action issue. Elmore was more skeptical, saying, ``I think the administration has to make some demands, and they haven't.'' Vice President Dan Quayle told the National League of Families on July 13 that Vietnamese cooperation in U.S. efforts to track down reported POWs and MIAs could ``remove the last vestige of the war and lay the groundwork for improved relations in the context of a comprehensive settlement in Cambodia.'' At the same meeting, Robert M. Kimmitt, undersecretary of State for political affairs, assured the families ``that we do not dwell on the past or harbor vindictiveness in our approach to Vietnam and its neighbors.'' Officials were at pains to say the talks would not deal with the prospect of normalizing relations with Hanoi. From the time U.S. ground troops were first sent to Vietnam in 1965 until the last of the troops were pulled out after the South Vietnamese surrender 10 years later, the Southeast Asian war increasingly convulsed American life. Some critics called it an immoral war; others said the fighting men were being hamstrung by the politicians. By the time it was over, about 57,000 U.S. troops had died, approximately 46,600 of them in combat. South Vietnam had lost about 254,300 men and North Vietnam more than a million. George A. Carver, a former CIA specialist on Vietnam now with the Center for Strategic and International Studies, said the memory of the unpopular Vietnam war is no reason for America to shun contact with Hanoi. ``A great power has to look after its interests,'' Carver said. ``It can't be rendered catatonic by the fact that people might criticize it for something that happened 15 years ago.''

DOC.HEAD: March Commemorating Revolution Turns to Anti-Communist Rally
DOC.TEXT: A march commemorating the December revolution that toppled Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu turned into an anti-Communist rally Saturday. Demonstrators chanted ``Down with Communism!'' and ``Down with Iliescu!'' Opponents have demanded the resignation of President Ion Iliescu, a former Communist who won free elections in May, saying he condones totalitarianism. Meanwhile, the trial of 24 former top Communist Party and government officials opened but was adjourned until Monday. The 24, all former members of the Communist Party Politburo, are accused of having backed Ceausescu's orders to shoot at demonstrators last December as the revolution began. The defendants, who include a former foreign minister and former vice premier, face maximum sentences of life in prison. The adjournment came after the defense asked that court president be replaced because he was one of the five judges in the secret trial of Ceausescu and his wife Elena, who were executed on Christmas Day. More than 2,000 people turned out for Saturday's march, which was organized by the 21 December Association, a leading opposition group. Demonstrators knelt, prayed and lit candles for the victims of the revolution seven months ago that ended 45 years of Communist rule in Romania. The march began in Bucharest's central University Square, the site of much of the fighting during the initial days of the revolution. The square was also the site of a 53-day anti-government protest that was violently broken up by police last month, setting off riots that the government put down with the help of club-wielding vigilante coal miners. December's popular uprising left at least 1,038 dead and more than 2,600 injured, according to official figures. Referring to those who lost their lives in the revolution, Eugen Botoc, a 43-year-old driver, said: ``They died happy because they thought they did it.'' But like many other protesters, he seemed unhappy with the results of the revolution. ``There is no chance for us but to flee _ to flee from Communism,'' he said. Adrian Chiriac, a 19-year-old student, told a small crowd that ``old times have come back, with the same old hope of running away'' to the West. He carried a huge banner saying: ``The only hope that is left is ... to defect.'' Before dispersing peacefully, the demonstrators distributed leaflets announcing a student-organized demonstration Sunday to call for the release of jailed student activist Marian Munteanu. Similar demonstrations were planned in the Transylvanian city of Brasov and in the western city of Timisoara, the cradle of the revolution, sources said. Munteanu was one of the leaders of the 53-day University Square demonstration. Students have organized demonstrations to protest his detention, including one last week in downtown Bucharest that drew about 20,000 people. Iliescu was harshly criticized abroad for Munteanu's arrest and for calling in pro-government miners last month, who indiscriminately beat demonstrators and passers-by. Iliescu told a news conference Friday that since Munteanu is in pre-trial detention, prosecutors could release him ``with an appropriate motive.'' As president, Iliescu maintained, he only has the power to ``reprieve people from jail.''

DOC.HEAD: Jury: Prosecutors Liable for Failing to Protect Witness
DOC.TEXT: A woman set on fire by her estranged husband just before she was to testify against him has won a $1.15 million judgment against prosecutors, whom she charged failed to protect her. However, the woman will receive just $50,000 _ the maxiumum for which the state could be held liable when she filed her suit. Since then, the state's liability has been raised to $100,000 in such cases. Attorneys in the case said they believe it may set a national precedent for holding prosecutors accountable for the safety of witnesses they subpoena. ``Justice has been served,'' Ruby Whylly Powell said after the jury verdict in her favor Friday. But ``no kind of money can compensate me for what I've been through.'' She suffered third-degree burns over half of her body when Jerome Whylly talked her into leaving the Hillsborough County courthouse, doused her with gasoline and threw a lighted match at her in July 1981. Jurors deliberated more than four hours before returning a total judgment of $2.3 million. But they also ruled Ms. Powell and the state attorney's office shared negligence equally, reducing the prosecution's liability to half of the award. Pamela Lutton-Shields, chief trial counsel for the state attorney general's office, would say only that an appeal was being considered. Ms. Powell was 22 in 1981 when she was called to testify against her husband in a probation revocation case. She was to testify that he burned their 6-month-old son with cigarettes and beat and bit him. The 1988 suit said Ms. Powell went to prosecutors twice before the attack and asked for protection, offering her husband's threatening letters as evidence. In one letter, he wrote, ``Best enjoy your time left on this earth.'' The Hillsborough County state attorney's office told her not to worry because he was safely behind bars. However, Whylly had been let out of jail on his own recognizance because of an error by the prosecutor's office, Ms. Powell's attorneys contended. ``The state attorney did nothing,'' said Ms. Powell's attorney, James D. Clark. ``They could have provided her an escort the day of the court hearing, or subpoenaed her husband at a different time.'' Whylly, now 39, was convicted of attempted murder for the attack on Ms. Powell and sentenced to 114 years in prison. Ms. Powell, now a 31-year-old divorced mother of two who works as a custodian, has undergone dozens of operations over the past nine years to reduce scarring on her face, arms and torso. Her oldest son, now 12, refuses to live with her and moved in with her parents after the attack. She said ``he's still scared of my face, the scars and all.'' But she said she's prepared to endure any more legal battles. ``I've gotten this far. I'm in it till the end.''

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Brennan's Successors Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is are brief descriptions of those mentioned as possible successors to retired Supreme Court Justice William J. Brennan.

Solicitor General Kenneth W. Starr, 44, took his present job as the government's chief Supreme Court advocate last year. He served as counselor to Attorney General William French Smith from 1981 to 1983, when he became a judge on the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals here. He gave up the lifetime appointment to be solicitor general in a move seen by many as a step toward the Supreme Court.

Edith H. Jones, 41, of Houston was appointed to the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in 1985 by President Ronald Reagan. A 1971 graduate of the University of Texas, Jones previously had been a private attorney who served as general counsel to the Texas Republican Party. She is known among conservatives as a ``law and order'' judge who favors the death penalty.

David Souter, 50, was appointed by Bush earlier this year to the 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. Previously, he was a member of the New Hampshire State Supreme Court, appointed to that post in 1983 by then-Gov. John Sununu, now Bush's chief of staff. Souter succeeded Sen. Warren Rudman, R-N.H., as the state's attorney general.
Patrick E. Higginbotham, 51, of Dallas, was appointed to the 5th Circuit Court of Appeals in 1982. He was mentioned as a possible Supreme Court nominee when Reagan filled vacancies on the high court.

William W. Wilkins Jr., 48, of Greenville, S.C., serves as a judge on the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals and is chairman of the U.S. Sentencing Commission. He was appointed a federal district judge by Reagan in 1981 and elevated to the appellate court in 1984. Conservatives express unhappiness over Wilkins' performance on the Sentencing Commission, which has considered tough sentencing guidelines for corporations convicted of crimes.

J. Harvie Wilkinson III, 45, of Charlottesville, Va., was named to the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals by Reagan in 1984. Wilkinson served as a deputy assistant attorney general in the Justice Department's civil rights division during the Reagan administration. He was also editorial page editor of the Norfolk (Va.) Virginian-Pilot.
Ralph K. Winter Jr., 54, of New Haven, Conn., was named to the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in 1982. Winter has been mentioned in the past as a possible Supreme Court nominee.

Roger Miner, 56, of Albany, N.Y., was appointed by Reagan to the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in 1985. He served as a federal district judge in upstate New York from 1981 until his elevation to the appellate bench.
Pamela A. Rymer, 49, of Los Angeles was appointed last year to the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals by President Bush after serving for six years as a federal district judge in California.

Laurence Silberman, 54, was appointed to the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals here in 1985 by Reagan. A former undersecretary of labor, Silberman also served as U.S. ambassador to Yugoslavia. A leading member of the D.C. Circuit's conservative wing, he wrote an opinion in 1988 that declared unconstitutional the independent counsel law. That opinion was reversed by the Supreme Court. On Friday, Silberman joined in an opinion that set aside former White House aide Oliver L. North's Iran-Contra convictions.

Frank H. Easterbrook, 41, of Chicago was named to the 7th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in 1985. He previously had served as a deputy solicitor general in the Justice Department during the Reagan administration.

Richard A. Posner, 51, of Chicago was appointed to the 7th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in 1981. A former assistant solicitor general in the Justice Department he also served as an assistant commissioner of the Federal Trade Commission.
Cynthia Hall, 61, of Pasadena, Calif., was appointed a federal district judge by Reagan in 1981 and named to the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in 1984.

Pasco M. Bowman II, 56, of Kansas City, Mo., was appointed to the 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in 1983. A former dean of the University of Missouri Law School, Bowman has previously been mentioned as a possible Supreme Court nominee.

J. Clifford Wallace, 61, of San Diego was appointed by President Richard Nixon to the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in 1972. Wallace, named as a possible Supreme Court candidate whenever a vacancy occurs, was first appointed a federal district judge in 1970.

DOC.HEAD: His Nearly 1,200 Opinions Second In Number Only to Late William O. Douglas
DOC.TEXT: Nearly thirty years ago, Dwight David Eisenhower was asked by a television interviewer if he had made any serious mistakes during his presidency. ``Yes, two,'' said Ike. ``And they are both sitting on the Supreme Court.'' Earl Warren is long gone. But until late Friday, William Joseph Brennan, 84, was still there, staving off the conservative tilt that Eisenhower and all Republican presidents since have envisioned for the court. What piqued Eisenhower was that Brennan, like Warren, turned out to be a powerful judicial activist, rather than a strict interpreter of the Constitution. Even toward the end, when he was outnumbered in the wake of Ronald Reagan's three appointments to the court, he still held great sway with his colleagues. ``No individual ... has had a more profound and sustained impact upon public policy in the United States'' over the past three decades, according to the grudging tribute of the National Review several years ago. ``His footprints are everywhere,'' said U.S. Appeals Judge Abner J. Mikva. ``His influence can be felt in nearly every area of the law.'' In his 34 years on the bench, Brennan wrote more than 1,200 opinions, second only to the late William O. Douglas. Among them are many landmark decisions on civil liberties, including the one person-one vote doctrine for apportioning state legislatures. Other decisions ordered school desegregation, upheld affirmative action plans for minority groups, struck down state aid to religious schools, and established constitutional protections for libel defendants. Brennan also wrote several of the court's rulings on obscenity, including a 1966 decision involving the 18th-century novel, ``Fanny Hill,'' in which he added a new test for obscenity: whether the material was ``utterly without redeeming social value.'' Along with Justice Thurgood Marshall, Brennan believes that the death penalty violates the Eighth Amendment, which bars cruel and unusual punishment, and he consistently voted to protect condemned prisoners who came to the court appealing for their lives. Increasingly he was on the losing side, the latest time just Thursday night in a Virginia case. ``The right to dissent is one of the great and cherished freedoms that we enjoy by virtue of the excellent accident of our birth as Americans,'' he said in a speech earlier this year. ``I do not mean to suggest that one has a duty or right simply to make noise,'' Brennan said. ``What I am saying is that all of us _ judges, lawyers, students, teachers, factory workers, bankers _ must recognize values which are so important to us that we cannot remain silent if and when we feel those values threatened.'' While Brennan's service on the court has had a huge impact on American law, his sudden retirement Friday could well have a bigger one. The court's 5 to 4 conservative majority has moved tentatively until now, often tempering its decisions to win the swing votes of Sandra Day O'Connor in some cases, Byron R. White in others. With President Bush sure to appoint another solid conservative, the court almost certainly will move further to the right in major cases _ including those involving abortion, racial discrimination, separation of church and state, and freedom of speech. ``In recent years, the other side has pretty much carried the day,'' Brennan said in an interview in April. ``That strikes me as nothing to be surprised about. After all, the president fills the vacancies.'' He said then that when he did leave, it would be for health reasons. And until recently, he showed little sign of slowing down. He still arose at 5 a.m., spent an hour on his Exercycle and put in a full day at the court. ``It's exciting,'' he said. ``It's thrilling to be here every day, since the day I came.'' But ``I think it would be so wrong to stay here unless you're fully able to do your job,'' Brennan said in the interview, which was just before his 84th birthday. ``Too much rides on what we do around here.'' Brennan was a New Jersey Supreme Court justice when he was appointed to the nation's highest court. He was confirmed by the Senate in March 1957 with only one dissenting vote _ from Sen. Joseph McCarthy, R-Wis. Earlier, Brennan had compared McCarthy's congressional hearings with the Salem witch-hunts. Brennan was born on April 25, 1906, in Newark, N.J., the second-oldest of eight children. His father, Brennan Sr., was an Irish immigrant whose first job in the United States was as a coal shoveler in a brewery. The elder Brennan rose through the ranks to become a labor leader and served as Newark's commissioner of public safety. Although he delivered milk in Newark when he was a boy and handed out change in trolley cars, Brennan scoffed at suggestions his was a ``rags-to-riches'' story. ``I'm no Horatio Alger,'' he once said. ``My father paid all my expenses till he died, then I was lucky enough to get a scholarship to finish Harvard Law.'' In recent years, Brennan has worried most about what he perceives as the court's failure to uphold privacy rights. In an interview with the New Yorker, he recited the Fourth Amendment verbatim: ``The right of the people to be secure in their persons, houses, papers, and effect, against unreasonable searches and seizures, shall not be violated, and no Warrants shall issue, but upon probably cause, supported by Oath or affirmation, and particularly describing the place to be searched, and the persons or things to be searched.'' Brennan repeated the words ``probable cause,'' then added: ``It's a high standard the Framers wanted. And it means that no search may be conducted unless the official knows of facts and circumstances warrant a prudent man to believe than an offense has been committed.'' By his account, the court has condoned several practices _ strip searches, police dragnets, random drug searches and tests _ that fail to meet that standard. Once, a radio reporter playfully baited him with the question: ``Why do you let some of these creeps go? They do such bad things, and on some technicality, you let them go.'' ``Honestly,'' Brennan said. ``You in the media ought to be ashamed of your selves to call the provisions and the guarantees of the Bill of Rights `technicalities.' They're not. They're very basic to our very existence as the kind of society we are. We are what we are because we have those guarantees, and this court exists to see that those guarantees are faithfully enforced. They are not technicalities!'' In a speech he wrote to celebrate the 200th birthday of the Constitution, he declared that ``one thing the old parchment is not is a china doll that has to be protected from the regular world by a good layer of cotton wool. It is a tough old soldier.'' As is William Joseph Brennan.

DOC.HEAD: President and Mrs. Bush Christen Nation's Newest Aircraft Carrier
With AM-Bush
LaserPhoto NEW2,5
DOC.TEXT: President Bush reminisced about his days as a naval aviator at Saturday's christening of the nuclear-powered aircraft carrier George Washington. ``Things were quite different then,'' said Bush, who flew as a carrier pilot in World War II. ``The planes were slower, the ships were smaller. ``And as I looked around at these admirals and some of the enlisted men and women I had the privilege to meet with, they all seem younger today,'' Bush told a crowd of about 15,000 at Newport News Shipbuilding. The $3.57 billion George Washington is the sixth Nimitz-class carrier built at the only shipyard in the nation capable of building the huge warships. The last ship named the George Washington was the country's first submarine capable of firing Polaris missiles. ``That was in 1960. We faced the dangers and uncertainities of a new kind of threat then _ the nuclear Cold War,'' Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said in introducing Bush. `` ... The submarine George Washington helped provide the deterrence our freedom required.'' Calling the aircraft carriers the nation's ``designated hitters,'' Cheney said the carrier George Washington would help provide the same strength and security to maintain peace. Bush said the carriers are ``an indispensable element of our nation's defense, projecting power and preserving peace. ... So today, we must maintain a policy of peacetime engagement and armed forces sufficient to sustain our national interest.'' ``We will not shrink from this responsibility,'' Bush said. ``And let the George Washington proclaim America's commitment to remain forever free.'' The crowd cheered and waved flags as first lady Barbara Bush christened the ship with the traditional bottle of champagne. As the bottle broke on the ship's bow, the ship's sirens and horns sounded and four Navy jets flew overhead. Construction of the 91,487-ton ship began in 1986. Refinements in construction techniques have speeded the building of the Nimitz carriers, and the George Washington was completed nearly two years faster than the first of its class. Two other Nimitz carriers are under construction at the yard. When the Washington is commissioned in late 1991, the ship ill be home to 2,800 officers and sailors. Another 2,700 will be aboard when the ship adds it air wing of 85 aircraft. The carrier measures 1,040 feet from bow to stern and 1,092 feet on its flight deck. From its keel to the top of the its mast the ship is 244 feet high _ the equivalent of a 24-story building. The galley will serve 18,150 meals a day. The ship can travel more than 45 mph at full speed, and its air-conditioning plant can cool the equivalent of 2,000 homes. The ship has more than 900 miles of electrical cable, more than 1 million tubes, transistors and diodes, and more than 2,000 telephones in its 3,000 compartments. The ship will be able to travel 800,000 miles to 1 million miles before its nuclear reactors need refueling. The Washington is the 26th carrier built at the yard.

DOC.HEAD: Arab Mediators Work to Defuse Crisis, Iraq Hints at War
DOC.TEXT: Arab mediators contacted President Saddam Hussein on Saturday in a bid to defuse his country's dispute with Kuwait, and Iraq's army newspaper hinted at military action against the Persian Gulf emirate. The official Baghdad Radio said Saudi Arabia's foreign minister, Prince Saud, handed Saddam a letter from King Fahd on ``developments in the region.'' It gave no details. But the Saudi leader and other Arab leaders have been making intense efforts to settle the crisis in the oil-rich gulf region. On Tuesday, Saddam accused Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates of flooding the oil market and driving prices down. Saddam claimed the move cost Iraq $14 billion in lost oil revenue. He also charged that Arab states in the Persian Gulf were conspiring with the United States and Israel to weaken Iraq's economy and undermine its military buildup. He warned he would retaliate with force, if necessary. Egypt's state-run Middle East News Agency said President Hosni Mubarak telephoned Saddam on Saturday in an effort to calm rising tensions in the region. It also reported that Iraqi Foreign Minister Tareq Aziz was expected to fly to Cairo on Sunday. The Iraq News Agency reported that Saddam also received calls from King Hussein of Jordan and President Ali Abdullah Saleh of Yemen. Another mediator, Arab League Secretary-General Chadli Klibi, met in Kuwait with that country's ruler, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, Saturday before flying to Baghdad. Iraq, with an army of nearly 1 million battle-seasoned men, has been amassing long-range missiles and chemical weapons since the cease-fire was declared in 1987 terminating hostilities in the eight-year Persian Gulf war. Iraq's official radio quoted an unidentified government spokesman as attacking Kuwait for sending a memorandum to the U.N. Security Council explaining its position in the dispute with Iraq. The spokesman said the move meant ``Kuwaiti rulers have given up the Arab option and insist on carrying out an imperialist plot against Iraq.'' Kuwait and Saudi Arabia supported Iraq during the war by providing interest-free loans totalling almost $35 billion. Iraq, saddled with a war debt to non-Arab states of $30 billion, has demanded that Arab countries write off the loans, claiming that Iraq saved the conservative Gulf states from Iranian fundamentalism. Saturday, the army daily, al-Qadissiya, warned in a front-page editorial that Iraq will take action to ``protect its rights and interests.'' It did not spell out what that action might be. But it stressed: ``Iraq has emerged victorious from the fierce war ... and is now capable of standing up to this and other plots.'' There were no reports from either side of any military buildup along the disputed frontier. Kuwait put its 20,300-member armed forces on alert Wednesday, but cancelled the alert Thursday night.

DOC.HEAD: Weather Could Cloud Eclipse Spectacle for Finns
DOC.TEXT: Cloudy weather Saturday threatened to mar the show for thousands of Finnish and foreign skygazers hoping to glimpse a total solar eclipse in this land of the midnight sun. The weather forecast took a turn for the worse in the evening, when the Finnish Meteorological Services predicted cloudy weather with a chance of showers for eastern Finland on Sunday. In the eastern town of Joensuu, a television news broadcast late Saturday showed it was already cloudy there with a light drizzle falling. The solar eclipse in Finland starts at 4:03 a.m. Sunday (9:03 p.m. EDT Saturday). At that time, the moon will begin gradually moving between the Earth and the sun. The total eclipse begins at 4:52 a.m. in Helsinki and will last 83 seconds. After the total phase of the eclipse, the moon will move away, uncovering more and more of the sun. The eclipse ends at 5:45 a.m. in Helsinki. About 10,000 people _ including 3,000 foreigners _ have converged on Joensuu, about 50 miles from the Soviet border. There conditions there are considered especially good for viewing the eclipse _ weather permitting. In Helsinki, the total eclipse phase will occur 16 minutes after sunrise, when the sun is only 1 degree above the horizon. At Joensuu, 310 miles northeast of Helsinki, the sun will be 5 degrees above the horizon in the total phase at a better angle for watchers. The sun rises unusually early during summer in the extreme northern latitudes where Finland is located. The sun comes up unusually late during winter. Ten months ago, Joensuu hired an ``eclipse secretary'' to handle arrangements for the expected influx of visitors. But that official, Marjut Cadia, said she had underestimated the interest in the event. ``We completely sold out the 10,000 special eyeglasses we made for this event, and our extra stock is finished too,'' she said in a television interview Saturday. During the past week, newspapers, television and radio have been full of information about solar eclipses, as well as advice for spectators not to stare directly into the sun. Some eclipse viewers won't have to worry about the clouds, because they will be above them. Finnair, the national airline, has arranged a dozen special flights for eclipse watchers, and private companies with small planes will provide more. The eclipse will be total in an arc about 125 miles wide from the northern Baltic Sea and southeast Finland, across the Kola Peninsula and northeast Soviet Union, to the Aleutian Islands near Alaska. Scientists will conduct several experiments during the eclipse, including gravity test measurements of the radius of the sun. However, scientific interest in this eclipse has been less than in longer eclipses, such as the seven-minute eclipse seen from northern Kenya on June 30, 1973. Seppo Linnaluoto of the Ursa Astronomical Association said the best place for observations of this eclipse will be the northeast Soviet Union. The last total eclipse to be seen in Finland occurred in 1945.

DOC.HEAD: Heat Puts the Flame Out in the Henhouse
DOC.TEXT: The heat is on in the henhouse, but the flame is out. Chickens don't like to mate in high temperatures, when they also become sluggish eaters, says Frank Jones, a poultry expert at North Carolina State University. That means layers aren't laying as often as they do in lower temperatures and the birds that are supposed to gorge for slaughter are taking their time about it, said Jones and Holly Farms spokesman Gordon Miller. ``They're subject to a lot of the same stresses we are as humans,'' Jones said. ``That means there will be less mating. They don't really feel like eating.'' Turkeys react the same way to summer heat, which has been in the 90s in North Carolina, the nation's top turkey producer and the No. 4 chicken producer. The state is expected to sell more than $1.5 billion worth of poultry this year. Miller said consumers may end up getting burned. If the heat continues, fewer birds could be on the market in time for Thanksgiving and Christmas and fewer eggs could drive up prices. Perdue Farms Inc. spokesman Steve McCauley doesn't believe that higher prices are a given. He said Friday that since the heat is an annual summer ailment, most growers are prepared. ``Typically, if a flock is affected, it's because something went wrong _ fans broke, alarms didn't work,'' McCauley said. ``But one flock is a few thousand birds and Perdue processes 1.6 million a week, and that's Perdue alone, so the loss of a flock or two would never have a significant impact on prices,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: At Least 40 Feared Dead as Bus Plunges into Pond in India
DOC.TEXT: A bus plunged into a roadside pond Saturday in the Hindu pilgrim town of Varanasi in northeastern India, a news agency said. At least 40 people were missing and feared dead. United News of India quoted witnesses as saying the driver apparently lost control of the bus before the vehicle fell into the pond. At least 12 bodies have been recovered so far, the news agency said. It gave no further details. Varanasi is about 435 miles east of New Delhi.

DOC.HEAD: Man Wrongly Imprisoned for Rape Freed After Eight Years
DOC.TEXT: A 25-year-old man who was put behind bars eight years ago for rape and robbery went free after someone who looks like him confessed, attorneys said. Randall Lynn Ayers _ who was sent to prison for 14 to 50 years in 1982 in the rape, robbery and shooting of a 15-year-old girl _ was ordered released Friday by Common Pleas Judge Thomas Crush after police said another man had confessed. ``It was a long wait,'' Ayers said. ``I didn't believe this would happen. I had given up.'' Ayers' attorney, Elizabeth Agar, said her client looks like the other man. ``Basically the only evidence in the case was eyewitness testimony,'' Ms. Agar said. ``You can see how a witness could make a mistake.'' Prosecutors would not identify the man who confessed. However, sources in the police department speaking on condition of anonymity told The Cincinnati Post the man who confessed was Robert Minton, 29, charged earlier this week in the slaying of two Cincinnati women. Senior Assistant Prosecutor Mark Piepmeier asked Crush to set aside Ayers' conviction. According to Piepmeier, a police investigator said the man who confessed offered details of the crime that ``fit all the way down the line.'' The victim of the 1981 attack looked at Ayers and the man who confessed and could not identify which was her assailant, Piepmeier said. Ayers was a 17-year-old high school senior when he was charged. The girl was robbed of $1 and shot in the neck. Friends testified at his trial that he was with them at the time. ``A jury convicted Randy Ayers,'' said Judge Crush. ``I expressed the opinion at the time that I would not have convicted him had it been tried to me.''

DOC.HEAD: Ethiopia Peace Talks Stalled Over U.N. Role
DOC.TEXT: SAN`A, Yemen (AP) _ Peace talks between Eritrean rebels and the Ethiopian government aimed at ending the 29-year-old civil war failed to get off the ground Saturday, officials and diplomats reported. Foreign Ministry officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the Yemeni-sponsored talks were postponed until Aug. 15. The officials said the talks failed because the Eritreans wanted the United Nations to organize a plebiscite in the north Ethiopian province where they have been waging a secessionist war in the East African nation since 1961. A spokesman for the Ethiopian Embassy in San`a said the Eritrean proposal was ``no problem from our side.'' But he added: ``It's the United Nations which rejects such participation because they consider the problem to be an internal problem. ... As far as I know, there are no relevant U.N. resolutions on the issue.'' Earlier this year, Yemen played host to a first round of talks between the Ethiopians and a group of rebel factions united under the banner of the Eritrean Liberation Front. The strongest rebel faction, the Eritrean People's Liberation Front, was involved in separate peace talks last year that were sponsored by former President Jimmy Carter. Those negotiations have also deadlocked. The Eritrean rebels have recently scored major successes on the battlefield. They have captured all of Eritrea except the provincial capital, Asmara, which they are surrounding.

DOC.HEAD: Scattered Thunderstorms East Of Rockies, Hot In West
DOC.TEXT: Rain and clouds were scattered from the Rockies to the East Coast on Saturday, and temperatures plummeted on the northern Plains. Showers and thunderstorms formed along a stationary front and were numerous from eastern Oklahoma and eastern Kansas to northern Illinois, and across Ohio and Pennsylvania. Strong thunderstorms also developed over the central Appalachians. Thunderstorms also developed over parts of New Jersey, southeastern New York, Maryland, Delaware and Virginia. Showers and thunderstorms developed ahead of an upper-level weather disturbance over eastern North Carolina, and also were scattered across the Gulf Coast states. Clouds, drizzle and light rain prevailed from Colorado and Wyoming across South Dakota and Nebraska. The heaviest rainfall for the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT was 1.04 inches at Fort Knox, Ky. Afternoon temperatures were only in the 50s and 60s from the northern and central high Plains into Nebraska and the Dakotas. Overnight readings dipped into the 40s and 50s in the northern Plains and the Rockies, and into the 50s in the upper Mississippi Valley, the Great Lakes, and northern Nevada.
