The low for the Lower 48 states was 40 degrees at Gunnison, Colo., and Belgrade, Mont. Hot weather prevailed west of the Rockies, with temperatures rising above 100 degrees in the desert Southwest and into the lower 90s as far north as Washington state. Temperatures in northern California at midday ranged from 56 degrees along the coast at Shelter Cove to 100 in the Sacramento Valley at Redding.

DOC.HEAD: Mussolini's Son Asks for Removal of `Fascist' From Plaques
DOC.TEXT: The son of the late dictator Benito Mussolini asked officials Saturday to remove the word ``Fascist'' from two plaques recalling a 1980 terrorist bombing at the Bologna train station. The request was made after a court this week threw out the convictions of four people sentenced to life in prison for the bombing, which killed 85 people. Prosecutors had described the attack as part of a neo-Fascist plot to undermine Italy's democracy, and the four were convicted of planting the bomb as right-wing terrorists. In his petition to the city prefect, or Interior Ministry representative, Vittorio Mussolini asked for the removal of the word ``Fascist'' from descriptions of the attack on plaques at the train station and the city hall of Bologna. ``The sentence pronounced in recent days by the court ... attests to the fact that the attribution (on the plaques) is unfounded and misleading and that therefore the offense is grave, defamatory and provocative,'' Mussolini wrote in his petition, presented by his lawyer. He added that to Fascists, the Bologna bombing was ``morally unacceptable and idealogically inconceivable.'' There was no immediate response from the prefect, Bruno Ciccone. Benito Mussolini, the first of Europe's fascist dictators, ruled Italy for 23 years.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Commander: Arrow Test Flight Within Two Weeks
DOC.TEXT: Israel will likely launch within two weeks its first test of a U.S.-funded anti-missile missile, the commander of the Israeli air force said in an interview broadcast Saturday. The Arrow missile is being developed with U.S. Strategic Defense Initiative funds to combat short-range ballistic missiles. The U.S. program is better known as ``Star Wars.'' In Washington, the U.S. Defense Department announced Friday that it would pay for the second phase of the Arrow program. Washington provided 80 percent of the $158 million in the first phase of the project, and Israel's Defense Ministry supplied the balance. Israel is seeking about $200 million from the United States for the second phase of development. Air force commander Maj. Gen. Avihu Bin Nun, speaking on Israel radio, said the Arrow could be operational within five years. When asked if the first test would be launched within two weeks, he said: ``This is a good assumption.'' The Arrow, which has already undergone three simulated ground tests, is designed to defend against ballistic missiles with a range of 600 miles or less. Bin Nun said the Arrow was needed in light of efforts by Iraq and Syria to develop chemical and nuclear warheads.

DOC.HEAD: Fans Throng Berlin Rock Spectacle, Cheer Fall of Mock Wall
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with details from concert, crowd estimated at 200,000, disappointed fans leaving early; CORRECTS date of Berlin's division to 1961 sted 1963; EDITS to trim. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos BER3,4,7
DOC.TEXT: About 200,000 rock music fans cheered as a mock Berlin Wall came tumbling down midnight Saturday at a benefit concert where the real divider once stood. Cyndi Lauper, Sinead O'Connor, Joni Mitchell and other stars performed songs from Pink Floyd's 1979 rock epic ``The Wall'' on a stage flanked by the massive plastic-foam wall meant to mimic the dismantled Berlin Wall. Organizers sold 180,000 tickets but finally ordered the removal of security fences to accommodate a huge crush of people. They streamed onto the strip of land where trespassers during Communist rule would have been shot instead of serenaded. ``There was so many people _ a lot of people without tickets _ that in the end it was safer to just put the fences down,'' said concert spokeswoman Wendy Laister. She estimated the crowd at 200,000. The 6{-hour concert was billed around the world as the biggest rock benefit ever. Proceeds were go to a fund for disaster victims. But thousands of fans began streaming out before the concert reached its climax. Many complained about the poor sound system, the difficulty most spectators had seeing the stage, and the wind-whipped cloud of dust and dirt that hovered over the 35-acre concert site. ``It wasn't good enough,'' said Corinna Treitel, 24, an American studying in Berlin. ``I can go home and turn on the TV.'' The carnival-like event _ held on a dust-choked expanse of land that was once enclosed by the Berlin Wall _ began in late afternoon and climaxed at night with a spectacular performance of Pink Floyd's 1979 rock epic ``The Wall.'' The concert was headlined by Roger Waters, a founder of Pink Floyd who composed ``The Wall'' but has since left the group. The 600-foot-long and 60-foot high mock wall, made of 2,500 Styrofoam bricks, came crashing down at midnight at the concert's climax. Many young people _ East and West Germans as well as foreigners _ pitched tents or sat under the stars near the concert site _ Potsdamer Platz, a former main square of old Berlin that was reduced to a desolate no-man's land when the Communists put up the Berlin Wall in 1961. The wall around the plaza was torn down three months ago in anticipation of German unification. When the concert began around 5:30 p.m., tens of thousands of people were crowded onto the former ``death strip'' on the East Berlin side of the Berlin Wall. ``I used to watch concerts like this on West German television,'' said 30-year-old East German Angelika Arnold, adding that her country's turn to democracy made the concert _ and her attendance _ possible. There were many British and U.S. tourists among the sprawling sea of relaxed fans who sat through the concert. Dave McCarthy said he rode 24 hours on a bus from Manchester, England, to attend. ``It's pretty amazing that not too long ago they would have shot someone who was sitting where I'm sitting,'' said the 31-year-old banker as he sprawled on the dirt. ``But I'm not sure how many people are into the politics. It's a pop concert.'' Tents and stands filled the grounds, selling everything from jewelry to Pepsi and wurst. The day was bright and hot, and concert-goers wore shorts and T-shirts. Rock bands such as the Hooters and the Irish folk group the Chieftains, accompanied by flutist James Galway, played opening sets before the performance of ``The Wall'' began at night. Huge projectors showed scenes from the century's wars on the giant plastic foam wall on stage. The concert also featured a six-story-high inflatible pig and an equally large teacher, two characters in Pink Floyd's atmospheric, other-worldly music. ``The Wall,'' which was made into a movie in 1982, is about alienation and the manipulation of the minds of individuals by authorities. It is not specifically about the Berlin Wall, though. The concert cost $8 million to stage and profits, as well as those from a planned album and video, are to go to a disaster relief fund, the Memorial Fund for Disaster Relief. Ms. Laister said it was uncertain how much of the proceeds would go to the disaster relief fund after expenses.

DOC.HEAD: Theater Critics Ask Congress to Remove NEA Restrictions
DOC.TEXT: The American Theatre Critics Association on Saturday urged Congress to continue funding the National Endowment for the Arts without restrictions on content. In a statement unanimously adopted by the 70 critics at the group's convention, the association said that for 25 years the NEA has ``fostered the arts in America and has provided enriching cultural opportunities for millions of Americans to participate in the arts as artists and audiences.'' Last year, President Bush signed into law an NEA approprations bill that included restrictions on artists receiving federal money. To receive NEA money, artists were asked to sign pledges they wouldn't depict ``sadomasochism, homoeroticism, the sexual exploitation of children or individuals engaged in sex acts and which, when taken as a whole, do not have serious literary, artistic, political or scientific merit.'' The NEA had come under fire for partially financing a controversial exhibit by photographer Robert Mapplethorpe and giving a small grant to Andres Serrano, who photographed a plastic crucifix in urine. ``As working theater critics, the members of this organization are in an ideal position to appreciate the value of the NEA,'' said Welton Jones, chairman of the 300-member association and drama critic for the San Diego Union. ``That is why we enthusiastically support the unrestricted renewal of the NEA authorization and funding.'' The statement urged Congress to ``reauthorize the NEA without restrictions on artistic content, leaving its traditional fiscal and evaluative structure intact, so that creativity can continue to flourish in the United States.''

DOC.HEAD: George Washington's Hair, Hitler Letter, Babe Ruth Baseball Auctioned Off
DOC.TEXT: A lock of George Washington's hair fetched $2,750 at an auction of celebrity memorabilia Saturday, which also featured a package of letters written by mass murderers and Adolf Hitler. The lock from the nation's first president went to a bidder, who, like the other buyers and the sellers, requested anonymity from the DuMouchelles auction house in Detroit, said auctioneer Joe DuMouchelle. The collection of letters from John Wayne Gacy, David Berkowitz, Charles Manson and Hitler brought $700. Fecthing the highest price was Babe Ruth's 700th home-run baseball, sold for $9,300 by a New Jersey buyer, said DuMouchelle, whose family owns the auction house. An autographed photograph of Marilyn Monroe, who died in 1962, brought $5,000, the robe worn by Sylvester Stallone in ``Rocky III'' sold for $2,400, and a pair of silk boxer shorts once owned by actor Jack Nicholson went for $700. Two art deco etchings by Louis Icart sold for $7,000 and $6,500 each, the auctioneer said. The items were auctioned off in estate sales and the standing-room only crowd of bidders came from across the nation, DuMouchelle said. Manson is serving a life prison term for the California murders of starlet Sharon Tate and six others by members of his cult ``family'' in 1969; Gacy was convicted in 1980 of the sex-related killings of 33 young men in suburban Chicago, more murders than anyone in U.S. history; ``Son of Sam'' killer Berkowitz murdered six people in New York City and wounded seven others in 1976 and 1977.

DOC.HEAD: Khmer Rouge Preparing to Storm Regional Capital
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS seven grafs with guerrilla leader proposing that government, rebels jointly occupy U.N. seat
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Cambodia-Analysis, Bjt
DOC.TEXT:
The Communist Khmer Rouge said Saturday it is preparing to attack a major town 75 miles north of the Cambodian capital. The announcement came three days after the United States announced it was withdrawing recognition of the tripartite guerrilla coalition and would open talks with Vietnam on ending the Cambodian war. The Khmer Rouge is the strongest member of the resistance forces. Khmer Rouge radio said hundreds of civilian supporters _ including children _ were carrying supplies, weapons and ammunition to guerrillas preparing to strike at Kompong Thom, the capital of the central province of the same name. The Khmer Rouge and non-Communist guerrillas loyal to Prince Norodom Sihanouk have seized wide areas of the province in recent months in some of their largest gains of the 11-year-old war. The two groups are allied with Son Sann's Khmer People's National Liberation Front in a coalition fighting the Vietnamese-installed government. The Khmer Rouge killed hundreds of thousands of people during its nearly four-year rule before Vietnam's late 1978 invasion installed the current government in Phnom Penh. In Washington, Japanese officials said Secretary of State James A. Baker III has sought their help in trying to persuade China to restrain the Khmer Rouge. A senior Japanese delegation is scheduled to visit China next week. U.S. intelligence has reported that China annually gives the Khmer Rouge about $100 million in aid. The Phnom Penh government on Saturday urged the Khmer Rouge and China to return to peace talks. ``We hope the Khmer Rouge and their patron in Beijing will return to the negotiating table to resolve the Cambodian problem by peaceful means,'' the official SPK news agency said. As first steps, it said, they should cooperate with an agreement reached last month in Tokyo to begin a cease-fire, stop receiving foreign military aid and participate in free elections under U.N. supervision. The agreement was signed by Phnom Penh's Prime Minister Hun Sen and Sihanouk. The Khmer Rouge boycotted the Tokyo talks, and China later said it did not support the agreement. The Phnom Penh government has been weakened by internal dissent and a drastic reduction in foreign aid from the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. The guerrillas have recently increased their attacks. Some Khmer Rouge officials said a truce without an overall political settlement would only benefit the beleaguered Phnom Penh government. Guerrilla leader Son Sann said Saturday a four-party coalition, including Prime Minister Hun Sen, should sit together in Cambodia's seat at the United Nations. He invited his guerrilla coalition partners and the prime minister to meet him to negotiate formation of a supreme national council. He said the council could then occupy the U.N. seat. He described Baker as ``a good friend of Cambodia'' but said he had been pressured by congressmen ``who listen too much to Vietnamese propaganda'' that the Khmer Rouge are ``bad people.'' ``Yes, I know and I accept that _ but the Vietnamese are worse,'' he said in the live interview from Paris on the Channel 4 TV program ``The World This Week'' in Britain. Under U.S. pressure, the United Nations has awarded a seat to the Cambodian resistance coalition and denied formal recognition to the Sen's government. Baker had said the United States was also changing its policy toward the Cambodian U.N. seat.
A senior administration official said the United States will no longer support seating a member of the resistance coalition, as long as it includes the Khmer Rouge, but would not support awarding the Sen government the seat either.

DOC.HEAD: `Fantasia' Animator Waiss Dies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `In the ...,' to ADD that Lantz created Woody Woodpecker. SUBS 8th graf, `Later, he ...,' to CORRECT typo in `Mehitabel.'
DOC.TEXT: George C. Waiss, an animator whose cartoon credits included Walt Disney's 1940 classic ``Fantasia'' and who went on to help design Titan missile silos, has died at age 83. Waiss, who also worked on Andy Panda and Woody Woodpecker cartoons, died of pneumonia Tuesday at the Alpine Manor nursing home in this Denver suburb and was buried Friday in his nearby hometown of Brighton. ``He had no formal education and was completely self-taught. Just give him a pen and some paper and tell him what you want, and he could do the job,'' said his son, Fred G. Waiss, of Sidney, Neb. The Chicago native moved to Colorado Springs at age 2, and grew up there. After a brief career as a boxer, he worked as an artist for the Rocky Mountain News and Denver Post. In the 1930s, he moved to Miami, where he worked as an animator for Woody Woodpecker creator Walter Lantz. He then worked for Max Fleischer Studios, which produced many movie cartoons in the 1930s and 1940s. Waiss then joined Walt Disney Studios in California, where he worked on ``Fantasia.'' In the early 1960s, he was a draftsman for Martin Marietta, where he helped design Titan silos. Later, he was a freelance artist and worked on medical educational films. In 1967, he did the animation for ``Twas the Night Before Christmas'' and in 1968 ``Archy and Mehitabel.'' He retired in 1983. Other survivors include his wife, Annette Westerman Waiss of Brighton; another son, William E. Waiss of Brighton; and three grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: Launch Team Confident of Sunday Launch For Atlas Rocket
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with launch scheduled for Sunday, details on repairs, EDITS to conform; picks up 6th graf, `The leak ...'
DOC.TEXT: Crews worked Saturday to repair a helium leak that forced the postponement of the launch of an Atlas rocket, but a spokesman said the problem will be fixed in time for a Sunday blastoff. The rocket holds a government satellite designed to study Earth's invisible magnetic field. The launch was scheduled for 3:28 p.m. Sunday from Cape Canaveral Air Force Station. The leak was caused by a liquid helium vent duct used for engine chilldown that separated in the interstage adapter, the area between the rocket booster and its upper stage, said Jack Isabel, a spokesman for rocket builder General Dynamics. The vent duct was removed, and workers planned to replace it with a new one, he said. ``We don't know what made it separate,'' Isabel said. ``We are looking forward to a launch attempt,'' he said. ``We're very proud of what's out there.'' The leak was not related to helium line damage in June that produced two small holes in the interstage adapter, Isabel said. Helium is needed to chill the rocket's main engines and pressurize the main propulsion system. The leak was detected less than an hour before liftoff Friday afternoon, as the commercial Atlas 1 rocket was being fueled. The escaping liquid helium was overchilling another chemical, hydrazine, which is used for steering the rocket's upper stage. The launch already was an hour late because of an unrelated problem with a compressor that furnishes gaseous nitrogen to the rocket to cool the Combined Release and Radiation Effects Satellite. The $189 million satellite, a joint program of NASA and the Defense Department, was to have been deployed in 1987 from space shuttle Challenger. The mission was put on hold after Challenger exploded in 1986. To ensure a quicker launch, NASA and the Air Force had it redesigned to fit into the $65 million Atlas. The 2-ton satellite contains 24 chemical-filled canisters that will be ejected over the next year, starting in September. The released chemicals will be ionized by the sun's ultraviolet rays and create large, glowing clouds. The clouds will spread along Earth's magnetic field lines, making them visible to the naked eye.

DOC.HEAD: China, Saudi Arabia Establish Diplomatic Relations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Sunday in lead is cq
DOC.TEXT: Saudi Arabia and China announced Sunday that they have established full diplomatic relations. It is the first time the Islamic kingdom has recognized a Communist nation. In their joint statement in the Saudi capital of Riyadh, the foreign ministers of both countries said that their countries will exchange ambassadors. Saudi Arabia said it recognized the People's Republic of China as the exclusive representative of the Chinese people. Taiwan's foreign minister, Fredrick Chien, predicted the announcement on Saturday and said the Arab kingdom would end its relations with Taipei simultaneously. Chien accused Beijing of using ``silver bullet diplomacy'' to win Saudi recognition, claiming the Communist government offered the Saudis a discount of $710 million on a weapons sale worth $6.6 billion that included intermediate-range ballistic missiles. It marked the first time Saudi Arabia, a theocratic Islamic kingdom, has recognized a Communist government. For years, the Saudi government has considered Communism a form of atheism. The upgrading of relations was delayed by the Chinese pro-democracy uprising that was crushed by Beijing in spring 1989. The Chinese crackdown prompted an international outcry that left China diplomatically isolated for many months afterward. The communique announcing diplomatic ties was issued at 12:18 a.m. Sunday and distributed by the offical Saudi news agency. The official Chinese news agency Xinhua said Chinese Foreign Minister Qian Qichen and his Saudi counterpart Prince Saud al-Faisal had jointly announced the decision. The upgrading of relations is expected to smooth the way for the Saudis to establish diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union. Saudi Arabia has trade relations with the Chinese and the Soviets, but relations with Beijing improved dramatically in 1986 when China sold the Saudis long-range missiles capable of reaching both Israel and Iran. The deal was disclosed in early 1988. Both Saudi Arabia and China have said nuclear weaponry was not involved. In Taipei, Chien accused Beijing of trying to isolate Taiwan diplomatically and of threatening to use force against the island. Taipei newspapers reported Saturday that Riyadh had rejected a request by Taipei's Nationalist Chinese government that the Arab kingdom not end its formal relations with Taiwan when it established ties with Beijing. The Saudi decision drops to 27 the number of nations recognizing the Nationalist government, while 136 countries now have diplomatic ties with Beijing. The Nationalists, who lost the Chinese civil war in 1949, say they are China's legitimate rulers.

DOC.HEAD: 1,000 Pack Topeka Church for Karl Menninger Funeral
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS lead; UPDATES throughout with new quotes; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Dr. Karl A. Menninger was eulogized Saturday as the man who brought psychiatry out of the ``snake pit'' era and gave new hope to the mentally ill. About 1,000 people, including Gov. Mike Hayden and U.S. Rep. Jim Slattery, D-Kan., packed the First Presbyterian Church for services for the famed psychiatrist, who died Wednesday of abdominal cancer. He would have been 97 on Sunday. ``If anything can be said about the Menninger era in psychiatry, which spans the entire history of psychiatry, it is that it has ushered in a new day of hope for those who were otherwise sealed in prisons of darkness,'' said the church's pastor, the Rev. W. James Richards. Menninger, once hailed by the American Psychiatric Association as the nation's greatest living psychiatrist, pushed psychiatry into the American mainstream and for more than six decades worked for compassionate treatment of the mentally ill. Richards said Menninger helped modernize mental hospitals that had been ``snake pits,'' challenged people to think and taught them to have hope. ``He said the Apostle Paul was wrong, that the greatest of faith, hope and love was not love, but hope,'' said Richards. Richards recalled his first Christmas as pastor in 1984, when Menninger was 91. Young church members had included Menninger on a list of people whose houses they planned to serenade with carols. ``But Dr. Karl was not home that evening,'' Richards said. ``He was having Christmas dinner with the prisoners at the county jail. He cared, not only for those imprisoned by their minds, but those in literal prisons and jails, too, and wrote about the crime of punishment.'' The half-hour funeral service was conducted in the church where Menninger's mother, Flo, taught Bible classes and which Menninger attended all his life. A stained glass window above the altar is dedicated to her memory. Menninger was buried in a mausoleum at Mount Hope Cemetery in southwest Topeka, which also contains the grave of former Gov. Alf M. Landon.

DOC.HEAD: Chokecherry Spitter Defends Crown
DOC.TEXT: The air was filled with chokecherries Saturday during the second annual chokecherry spitting contest held as part of this small central Nebraska town's Chokecherry Jamboree. Jerry Davenport of Sargent, who let fly with a spit of 30 feet, 10{ inches, succesfully defended his men's division title, said jamboree official Fred Meyer of Sargent. ``He didn't beat the record he set last year,'' Meyer said. Davenport's chokecherry spit last year of 33 feet, 6 inches is the record. ``He did have one go 39 feet, but it went out of bounds so we couldn't count it,'' Meyer said. Bob Travis of Sheboygan, Wis., was second in the men's division with a spit of 28 feet, 9{ inches. Mike Weverka of Lincoln was third at 28 feet, 5 inches. In the women's division, Bonnie Dixon of Napa, Calif., set a new record with a spit of 22 feet, 10{ inches. Janey Weverka of Lincoln, the old record-holder, was third with a spit of 19 feet, 4 inches. Her mother, Lana Weverka, came in second at 20 feet, 3 inches. In the kids division, Cory Beavers of Broken Bow spit a chokecherry 19 feet, 1 inch to come in first. Second was Sandra Ware of North Platte, 13 feet, 9{ inches, and third was Charlotte Edwards of Ravenna, 13 feet.

DOC.HEAD: Faulkner Contest Brings Out Southern Charm
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to ADD that this is first contest, CORRECT that winner to be feted next week, ADD that conference begins July 29; picks up 6th graf, `His winning ...' Niece's name, Dean, is cq.
DOC.TEXT: The winner of the first William Faulkner imitation contest gets feted here next week after besting such entries as ``As I Lay Dieting,'' and ``The Salt and the Fury.'' ``There are so many frustrated writers out there who read Faulkner,'' said Dean Faulkner Wells, niece of the late author, who coordinated the first contest. ``I think most of the people who entered just had a whale of a good time.'' The winner _ Saul Rosenberg, a New York graduate student _ penned his entry one day before the Feb. 1 deadline. ``Delta Faulkner'' topped nearly 650 other entries in the contest. ``I always do things at the last minute. I just kind of sat down and wrote what came out,'' Rosenberg said in an interview. ``I wrote it on a beat-up typrewriter which Faulkner would have liked.'' The 26-year-old London native will visit Oxford, Miss., during the University of Mississippi Faulkner and Yoknapatawpha Conference beginning July 29, and will be honored in a Southern ceremony at Faulkner's home. His winning entry was about the contest itself. Here's a part of it, complete with punctuation or lack thereof: ``They came that year as they had come the year before and would come again the year after; the editors and publishers and critics good bad and indifferent but mostly indifferent and some just to say oh yes the faulkner conference I made one and even the representatives of an airline who had come to award a prize on the lawn of the stillupkept colonial mansion to that one who man woman or child could write as well as he could when he didnt and wise too not because it was easy (it wasnt) and not because it would do their airline any good (it wouldnt) but at least it was possible because heaven help anyone who thought he or she could write as well as he could when he did; the mansion upkept still though the very bones of its erstwhile owner (himself owner and proprietor too of that two thousand four hundred square miles of land more famous than any actual or apocryphal in the whole peopled continent) which had held together long enough to support the spirit that produced the work in what agony what sweat had long since returned to the annealing immemorial dust.'' Rosenberg said the trip, his first south of the Mason-Dixon Line, should be ``a great experience.'' ``I think they liked mine because it was sort of a tribute to Faulkner,'' he said. Faulkner himself would have enjoyed the attempts of the contestants, said his niece. ``I think he would have laughed out loud. It's a gas,'' she said. ``It's like they were just waiting for something like this to open up for them to play with.'' Among the offerings were ``As I Lay Dieting,'' ``A Wal-Mart For Jefferson,'' and ``The Salt and the Fury.'' ``There is such an innate compliment there _ that people all over the world would try to imitate him,'' Wells said. Faulkner, winner of the Nobel Prize in literature, died in 1962. ``I've been reading Faulkner for years. I just thought it would be a shame if I didn't do to it,'' Rosenberg said. He called his win ``all kind of astounding.'' Rosenberg, who also wins a trip anywhere American Airlines flies, says he might go to Hawaii. But the Mississippi trip isn't bad, he says. ``I don't know which one is the real prize.'' The contest follows the now-defunct Ernest Hemingway Write-Alike competition. The top 50 finalists, which include several Mississippians, will have their work published.

DOC.HEAD: Seven-Personality Insanity Defense Upheld
DOC.TEXT: A woman who contends she didn't commit two bank holdups because another one of her seven personalities was in control will be allowed to present her unusual insanity defense, a judge ruled. Juanita Maxwell claims she had no way to prevent the 1988 robberies because an alternate personality named ``Wanda'' pulled them off, and that she should be acquitted by reason of insanity. Mrs. Maxwell, 34, used a similar defense to win acquittal in a 1979 murder case. Circuit Judge R. Grable Stoutamire's ruling Friday came after pretrial arguments in April in which prosecutors blasted the defense. The ruling sets the stage for a trial scheduled to begin July 31. Prosecutors had argued that it didn't matter whether Mrs. Maxwell knew of the robberies. They said what did matter was whether Wanda knew right from wrong when she held up two First Florida bank branches. Florida's insanity standard applies only to defendants whose mental problems cloud their ability to tell right from wrong. If Wanda did know right from wrong, prosecutors reasoned, Mrs. Maxwell should not be allowed to present the insanity defense at her trial. Jurors will have to decide where criminal accountablity lies when seven distinct personalities claim one body. Experts will be called to explain the forces that cause a personality to fracture. In Mrs. Maxwell's case, her subconscious created numerous personalities in response to an abusive childhood, her therapists have said. The personalities range from the flirtatious and sophisticated Jennifer to the protective but sometimes violent Wanda. Mrs. Maxwell claims Wanda turned to bank robbery so she could help support Mrs. Maxwell's three children in Ohio. It was Wanda who bludgeoned a 73-year-old Fort Myers woman to death during a squabble in 1979 over a ballpoint pen. In that case, a judge acquitted Mrs. Maxwell of murder by reason of insanity, and sent her to a state psychiatric hospital for treatment. Mrs. Maxwell was released in 1987 after state officials decided she was mentally competent.

DOC.HEAD: New York Bus Crashes Into Bridge Pillar, Injuring 30
DOC.TEXT: A city bus crashed into a pillar on a bridge Saturday, injuring all 31 people aboard, a Transit Authority spokesman said. The bus was traveling from Brooklyn to Manhattan on the Williamsburg Bridge when it crashed into a pillar on the Brooklyn side, said spokesman Bob Slovak. The driver, who had to be cut from the wreckage and was seriously hurt, and the 30 passengers were taken to hospitals, Slovak said. The cause of the accident was not known.

DOC.HEAD: Mock Shootout Turns Into Real Thing at Frontier Days Parade
DOC.TEXT: A mock shootout in the Cheyenne Frontier Days parade Saturday turned into the real thing when one of the cowboys was hit in the foot by a real bullet. Police officials said a Fort Collins, Colo., man was participating in a gunfight on one of the western-style floats when he was shot. Real ammunition was not to be allowed in the parade, police said. Ronald Tuenge, 37, was taken to Memorial Hospital, treated for the wound and released, authorities said. Police were investigating the incident, but declined to say whether the man shot himself or someone else fired the gun. The so-called ``Vigilante Float'' carried several rambunctious men pretending they were cowboys from the Old West who staged a mock hanging on the back of a flatbed truck. The downtown parade kicked off the 94th Annual Cheyenne Frontier Days rodeo.

DOC.HEAD: Egyptians Vent Anger at Arafat
DOC.TEXT: PLO chairman Yasser Arafat came under sharp attack in state-owned newspapers Saturday, signaling a new chill in relations between the Palestinian group and Egypt. The articles, written by three of Egypt's top journalists, appeared after the Palestine Liberation Organization leader accused Egypt of being subservient to the United States. The criticism centers on remarks that Arafat made in a speech to an Arab League meeting last weekend in Tunis, Tunisia. Meanwhile, the PLO's representative in Cairo told The Associated Press that Arafat might call off a visit to Egypt on Sunday because of the dispute. ``The visit is now being reconsidered in light of the latest developments,'' said Saeed Kamal, the PLO representative, referring to the newspaper attacks on Arafat. ``I do not know now if it will take place.'' Arafat had planned to attend a rally in Cairo for the 38th anniversary of the coup in which the Egyptian army overthrew the monarchy. Government sources who spoke on condition of anonymity said the rift would not affect Cairo's support of the PLO in future Middle East peace moves. In past regional peace efforts, Egypt has served as the principal conduit for exchanges between the PLO on one hand and Israel and the United States on the other. The United States established its own direct dialogue with the PLO in December 1988 after Arafat renounced terrorism and recognized Israel's right to exist. That dialogue was suspended by the Bush administration last month after the PLO failed to discipline the guerrilla group responsible for a foiled seaborne raid on Israel. Egyptian government officials on Thursday said Cairo resented critical remarks made by Arafat at the meeting of the Arab League Council in Tunis. Accounts of Arafat's criticism of Egypt at the Tunis meeting were published in Cairo newspapers Thursday in what officials acknowledged was a government leak. The reports said Arafat lamented the absence of Egyptian Foreign Minister Esmat Abdel-Meguid at the ministerial-level meeting. Abdel-Meguid was busy in Egypt at the time with a visit by Syrian President Hafez Assad. The newspaper reports said Arafat suggested in his council speech that Egypt was subservient to the United States, even though Washington was stingy in its aid to Cairo, while generously assisting Israel. On Saturday, columnist Anis Mansour wrote in the leading newspaper, Al-Ahram, that Egyptians were not eager to see Arafat and others return to Cairo when the Arab League moves its headquarters back to the Egyptian capital. Mansour wrote that Egyptians hate the fact that the former Arab League building is 100 meters from the Nile River because the distance makes ``it difficult for them to throw the building into the Nile to avoid seeing your faces.'' The League headquarters moved from Cairo to Tunis in 1979 after Egypt's membership was suspended for signing a peace treaty with Israel. Last year, the suspension was lifted and the headquarters is to move back to Cairo this fall. Samir Ragab, board chairman of the newspaper Al-Gomhouria, wrote a commentary accusing the PLO of seeking to ``abort Egypt's pan-Arab role.''

DOC.HEAD: Florio Signs Legislation To Help Prevent Oil, Chemical Spills
LaserPhoto NR1
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Jim Florio, standing near New Jersey's most polluted waterway Saturday, signed into law a package of bills designed to combat water pollution and which would penalize violators by up to $10 million. The governor signed the six bills at the Elizabeth Marina on the Arthur Kill, a shipping channel separating New Jersey from New York City into which 40,000 gallons of oil spilled Wednesday. More than 1 million gallons of oil have spilled into the Kill and nearby Kill Van Kull this year. ``It's not going to be business as usual any more,'' said Florio, flanked by legislators who sponsored the measures. ``These laws carry a very simple message, `You spill, you pay.''' Assemblyman Robert Smith, a sponsor of the one of the bills, said there is ``an attitude among many corporate executives in the oil industry that it is cheaper to pollute than to take responsible, preventative actions.'' The executive director of the New Jersey Petroleum Council, an industry group, issued a statement saying oil companies shared Florio's and the Legislature's concern about oil spills. ``Many of the measures are already being implemented,'' said James E. Benton. ``However, legislation that would impose a $10 million fine for major spills could ultimately have a detrimental impact on energy supplies during periods of peak demand, consumer prices, and jobs in New Jersey.'' Florio dismissed concerns about a loss of jobs. ``The question is costs versus costs. The status quo in this process is not cost free. It costs each and every person,'' Florio said. ``One of the spills resulted in parts of the Jersey Shore being closed. Anyone who thinks that is cost free, they are misled.'' The new laws, which take effect over the next two years, would: _ require protective booms be placed in the water whenever there is a transfer of oil or hazardous liquid from ship to shore or ship to ship; _ impose tougher standards on companies storing and transferring hazardous substances; _ require all pipelines in New Jersey to be mapped and registered; _ mandate special lighting be in place whenever pipeline transfers are done at night. The last two provisions grew out of the Exxon pipeline rupture on Jan. 1 that spewed more 567,000 gallons of home heating oil into the Arthur Kill. A Coast Guard investigation concluded in part that the spill was so extensive because workers were pumping oil through the pipeline at night and could not tell it was leaking into the waterway. If spills do occur, the new laws also pose tougher penalties of up to $10 million for spills of 100,000 gallons or more of a hazardous substance. The penalties would apply to any spills that reach New Jersey waters or lands, regardless of where they originate. Companies would not be able to deduct the costs of cleanups or fines from state taxes under the new laws. The state Department of Environmental Protection would also be able to assess civil penalties directly, rather than having to go to court to collect. Billable costs would be expanded to include the cost of restoring or replacing personal property, lost income resulting from damage caused by a spill, and the cost of repairing or replacing damaged and destroyed natural resources. The previous law provided only for penalties of up to $50,000 a day and did not take into account the size of the spill.

DOC.HEAD: Nixon Library Features Edited Version of `Smoking Gun' Tape
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to UPDATE with Nixon spokesman denying exhibit is distorted; picks up 3rd graf, `In addition ...' SUBS grafs 7-8, `On the ...,' with 5 grafs to UPDATE with comments; picks up 9th graf, `An accompanying ...'
DOC.TEXT: Exhibits at the new Richard M. Nixon Library & Birthplace include a heavily edited version of the ``smoking gun'' tape, but a Nixon aide said the ``most incriminating portions'' have not been deleted. Other exhibits on the Watergate investigation that led to Nixon's resignation take jabs at some Nixon critics. Text accompanying part of the museum's exhibit says the late Sen. Sam Ervin, D-N.C., who chaired the Senate investigation of Watergate, suffered ``partisan bias.'' In addition, the display includes a quote accusing then-Washington Post reporters Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein of ``offering bribes, illegally gaining access to telephone numbers and talking to members of the grand jury'' during their Pulitzer Prize-winning reporting of the story. The display attributes the quote to an unidentified ``scholar.'' The quote is contained in a book by Stanley I. Kutler of the University of Wisconsin, who said Friday he simply recounted what others had said at the time. ``Nixon is blaming the media and everyone else for his troubles while Watergate was his own doing and that of his aides,'' Kutler told the Los Angeles Times on Friday. ``The media simply reported the investigations of properly constituted legal authorities.'' The library, which opened to the public Friday, offers a cut-down version of the White House recording involving Nixon and his chief of staff, H.R. Haldeman. The library had said excerpts would be played for visitors. Nixon aide John Taylor said Saturday that the library ``isolated the most incriminating portions ... and did not edit within those incriminating portions.'' On the June 23, 1972, ``smoking gun'' tape, Nixon approved a plan to have the CIA tell the FBI to drop its investigation of the break-in at the offices of Democratic National Chairman Lawrence O'Brien at the Watergate complex. The library's version of the tape offers portions of the talk punctuated with a narration of explanations for Nixon's comments. It concludes with Nixon reading a diary entry describing later events. ``It is not a distortion,'' Taylor said. ``The real distortion would be to include a transcript without narration. We narrate, as with every other exhibit.'' He described the action as a ``documentary approach.'' The full tape would have run too long, taking up too much time for those touring the library, Taylor said. An accompanying text display concedes that ``Nixon himself has said he made inexcusable misjudgments during Watergate.'' In a museum film highlighting Nixon's career, a narrator says Nixon ``knew nothing about'' the Watergate break-in. The narrator concedes that ``some of his aides'' were involved in a ``cover-up.'' A grand jury named Nixon an ``unindicted co-conspirator'' in the affair, and impeachment charges were filed by the House Judiciary Committee.

DOC.HEAD: Murder Suspect Confesses to Four Killings; Body Found
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `Warren also ...,' to CORRECT name of town to `Travelers Rest,' sted `Traveler's Rest.'
DOC.TEXT: A man admitted killing four women, and directed authorities to a body he said was that of his latest victim _ a 21-year-old woman found stuffed in her car's trunk, officials said Saturday. Lesley Eugene Warren was captured Friday in High Point in central North Carolina, just hours after police from the Carolinas and New York held a news conference in Asheville alerting officials to be on the lookout for him. ``His mindset is such that he will kill again,'' New York state police Lt. Ed Grant, who specializes in investigations of serial killings, told the news conference in this western North Carolina city. The 22-year-old Candler man confessed to the crimes Friday night, and told Asheville authorities they could find a body in the trunk of a car on the second level of a downtown High Point garage, police said. The body of Katherine Noel Johnson of High Point was found in a car there, said High Point police Capt. Blair Rankin. Warren told Asheville officials he killed Ms. Johnson on July 15. Warren also confessed to killing Jayme Denise Hurley, 39, of Asheville; Velma Faye Gray, 42, of Travelers Rest, S.C., in 1989; and Patsy Diane Vineyard, 20, of Sacketts Harbor, N.Y., in 1987, officials said. Warren was charged in the slayings of Ms. Hurley and Ms. Gray. He is to be arraigned Monday in the Hurley case. Warrants are pending in Ms. Vineyard's death. Ms. Hurley had been missing since May 25; her body was found Wednesday in a shallow grave near her hometown. Asheville police Chief Gerald Beavers said Warren became a suspect in Ms. Hurley's case shortly after her disappearance. But he could be held only on charges of failure to produce title to a motor vehicle and misdemeanor larceny of a purse, and was released June 7 on a $25,000 secured bond. Officials said Warren met Ms. Hurley when he was her student at the Juvenile Evaluation Center in Swannanoa several years ago. Dr. LuJuan Gibson, a psychologist and assistant director of the center until she and Ms. Hurley left it about two years ago, said Ms. Hurley had taken a particular interest in Warren. She said she did not believe the two were romantically involved. Ms. Gray was killed last August, and her body was found floating in a lake by two fishermen. Investigators in Spartanburg County, S.C., on the North Carolina line believe Warren abducted Ms. Gray after she wrecked her car. Investigators say they believe he was driving a tractor-trailer rig at the time. In 1987, Ms. Vineyard was found in Lake Ontario near her home in Sackett's Harbor. Her husband, an Army soldier at Fort Drum, N.Y., reported her missing when he returned home from two weeks of field training. Warren, who was an Army private at Fort Drum, was one of 150 soldiers questioned in the case. Warren was born and raised in the Asheville area. His parents were divorced when he was 4, he was a high school dropout and later worked in construction and in a factory. He has a wife and a child living in South Carolina, relatives said. Beavers said Warren has no prior convictions of violent crimes as an adult, but the Asheville police chief declined to comment on problems Warren had as an inmate at the Swannanoa juvenile center.

DOC.HEAD: Vandals Spray Capitol, Other Buildings With Pro-Choice Slogans
DOC.TEXT: Vandals painted pro-choice graffiti on a Roman Catholic church, a state agency building and the Capitol, where legislators approved what could become the nation's toughest state anti-abortion law. ``Louisiana Legislature Hates Women,'' ``Women Fight Back'' and ``Women Will Decide Their Fate'' were among the slogans marring the walls of the art deco-style Capitol, the nearby offices of the Department of Transportation offices and St. Joseph's Cathedral. Shocked tour guides and visitors early Saturday discovered the vandalism, which was carried out overnight. Police said they had no suspects. ``I nearly cried,'' one guide said after seeing the Capitol. ``I'm very attached to this building.'' Church workers painted over the grafitti at St. Joseph's, the seat of Baton Rouge's Catholic diocese. Officials said workers would begin scrubbing the paint off the state buildings Sunday. The damage was the latest protest in Louisiana's abortion battle, which has drawn thousands of people on both sides of the issue to the Capitol for demonstrations. The measure approved July 8 by the Legislature would prohibit abortion except for pregnancies caused by rape or incest or to save the life of the mother. Abortionists would face fines of up to $100,000 and 10 years at hard labor. Gov. Buddy Roemer has said he has problems with some of the bill's provisions and will not sign it. If he does not veto it, however, it would become law Sept. 7. Days before that bill was approved, state lawmakers had sent Roemer even tougher legislation without exceptions for pregnancies caused by rape or incest. The governor, who had demanded those exceptions, vetoed that measure. The current bill was rushed through both houses of the Legislature the day before the session ended after anti-abortion lawmakers failed to override the veto. Abortion opponents want to use the law to challenge the 1973 Roe vs. Wade ruling by the U.S. Supreme Court defining a woman's right to abortion. Only the U.S. territory of Guam would have a stronger anti-abortion measure. The Guam law, which was passed in March, only allows abortion to save the life of the woman and would penalize both the woman and the abortionist.

DOC.HEAD: Gay Leaders Blast Network Decision Not to Rerun Controversial Show
DOC.TEXT: Gay and lesbian community leaders said Saturday they have launched a letter-writing protest against ABC-TV's refusal to rerun a controversial``thirtysomething'' episode featuring two men in bed. The network's entertainment president, Bob Iger, said his office has already received a substantial number of complaints since his decision to cut the provocative installment from summer repeats was reported in Thursday's Los Angeles Times. Iger said he pulled the show from the network's summer schedule solely for economic reasons. Fifty percent of ``thirtysomething'' advertisers pulled their commercials from the episode's first run last season, Iger said, costing the network more than $1 million. ``In my opinion, I am not sending any kind of a signal,'' he said Saturday following a news conference with television critics. ``It was a very, very hard business decision that I made.'' Gay and lesbian activists called it cowardice. ``This knuckling under says we should be made invisible again,'' said Michael Shere, a Los Angeles board member of the national Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation, which gave ABC an award last season for the program it now refuses to repeat. ``There are far too few examples of gays and lesbians in films or television that shows them as something other than criminals or buffoons,'' Shere said. The episode in question showed a homosexual couple in bed talking about friends who had died from AIDS. The two men did not touch. ABC executives said Saturday they did not know which advertisers had boycotted the program. Capital Cities@ABC Inc. President Daniel Burke said during Saturday's news conference that ABC could not afford another loss of that size. ``It's very difficult to run a network through the summer with a $600,000 or $700,000 deficit,'' he said. ``I guess our position is that we've already run it once,'' said John Sias, executive vice president of Capital Cities, ABC's parent company. Los Angeles County Human Relations Commissioner Morris Kight called the network's position ``a peculiar form of cowardice.'' ``It's a fact that a significant number of men go to bed with men in this country,'' said Kight, a longtime activist for homosexual rights. ``We're all very sorry that they've made this decision.'' Kight and Shere said homosexual rights' advocates from several national organizations are sending letters and telegrams to ABC. Parents and Friends of Gays and Lesbians also will join the campaign, said the group's Los Angeles chapter president, Adele Starr. ``This shows the small minority out there who are very homophobic and mean and hateful that they can control what goes on television at a time when people are becoming more enlightened,'' Starr said. Iger said the whole incident was unfortunate. ``I'm not saying I will never repeat this episode again,'' he added. ``It's only for this summer. We have not once deterred our creative community from what could be a sensitive issue to advertisers.''

DOC.HEAD: Birth Control Pill Researcher Dead
DOC.TEXT: Dr. Arthur T. Hertig, whose research on embryos helped lead to the development of the birth-control pill and test-tube fertilization, has died at age 86. Hertig died Friday at Falmouth Hospital of cardiac arrest after colon surgery, said his son, Andrew. The Lexington researcher was known for his work with fetuses less than two weeks old at Harvard Medical School between 1938 and 1952. A fellow researcher, Dr. John Rock, later developed the birth-control pill. The work also laid the foundation for infertility therapy and for the successful transplantation of fertilized eggs. Hertig, a gynecological pathologist, also studied ovarian tumors, gynecological cancers and miscarriages. After 37 years at the medical school, Hertig resigned in 1970 to study the morphology of primate ovaries at the New England Regional Primate Research Center in Southborough. He resigned three years ago. A native of Minnesota, Hertig graduated from the University of Minnesota in 1928. He graduated from Harvard Medical School two years latre. In 1979, Hertig received the Gold-Headed Cane Award from the American Association of Pathologists, which cited him as ``a physician who represents the highest ideals in medicine and pathology.''

DOC.HEAD: Republicans Nominate U.S. Rep. John G. Rowland for Governor
DOC.TEXT: Connecticut Republicans, convinced they can win the governor's office for the first time in two decades, nominated U.S. Rep. John G. Rowland as their candidate Saturday. Rowland's forces persuaded opponents of his choices for the rest of the slate to drop out, allowing the GOP to end its convention with one team and no September primaries pending _ unlike the Democrats, who have a primary for governor and possibly two other spots. ``Our party is united. And that unity of spirit and that unity of purpose is vital this year,'' Rowland said in his acceptance speech. ``We are at a turning point in our great state. Everyone in this room knows that it's been 20 years since a Republican last won the governor's chair,'' he said. ``... An entire generation has grown up knowing nothing but the ruinous rule of one arrogant, dominant party.'' The 33-year-old congressman from Waterbury, who began his quest for the nomination in October and who at one point faced three rivals, was unopposed at the convention and was nominated by acclamation. In a state where Democrats outnumber Republicans 3-2, Rowland needs Democratic support if he's to have a chance at winning in November. The Democrats have had the governor's office for 32 of the last 36 years. The last time a Republican won was in 1970. Rowland, who for the past six years has represented a traditionally Democratic, blue-collar district in Congress, has moved to broaden his appeal among Democrats by putting one on his ticket. Rowland's choice of former Democratic state Treasurer Joan R. Kemler for treasurer was endorsed by the convention. Kemler changed her party affiliation to Republican this week. Rowland's nomination touched off a long and loud demonstration on the convention floor, with hundreds of delegates shaking cow bells, rattling New Year's Eve noisemakers and popping red, white and blue balloons as they dropped from the ceiling of the Hartford Civic Center. In November, Rowland will face independent gubernatorial candidate Lowell P. Weicker Jr., a former Republican U.S. senator, and the winner of the Democratic primary between U.S. Rep. Bruce A. Morrison, the endorsed candidate, and state Rep. William J. Cibes Jr. Since Weicker announced his candidacy in March, he has maintained a commanding lead in the polls, far ahead of Rowland, who is just slightly ahead of Morrison, a four-term congressman from Hamden. But Rowland shrugs off the polls, attributing Weicker's lead only to his high name recognition after two decades as a statewide political figure. Most observers, including Weicker, expect the race to tighten up as the election approaches. Rowland said he expects Weicker and Morrison to split the liberal vote, while moderates and conservatives turn to him.

DOC.HEAD: Logging Protesters, Logging Families Hold Rival Rallies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs to UPDATE with protester march, two onlookers arrested, quotes; ADDS byline; picks up 9th graf, `On Friday, ....'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Car Bomb-Bari, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: About 1,500 logging protesters, closely watched by police in riot gear, marched along main street to protest logging practices, and were greeted by jeers, obscene gestures and occasional cheers from onlookers. On the other side of this small sawmill town 130 miles north of San Francisco, a more relaxed group of officers watched about 1,000 timber industry supporters hold a rival parade and rally against a forest protection measure on California's November ballot. In the second major event of ``Redwood Summer,'' a series of protests against logging practices modeled after the ``Freedom Summer'' civil rights protests in the South, demonstrators rallied for nearly two hours at a main intersection while police kept away a crowd of some 200 angry opponents. Some onlookers shouted ``Go Home!'' and made obscene gestures. The marchers shouted back, ``We are home! We are home!'' Police said they arrested two onlookers for investigation of obstructing officers and resisting arrest. After listening to folk songs and speakers, the demonstrators marched six blocks back to a timber company field on the north side of town where they'd rallied Saturday morning. About 300 officers from various jurisdictions were in this Mendocino County town of 6,100 to maintain order, but there was little trouble. Rally organizers said they'd gotten their message across to this community of 6,100 and called off plans to stage acts of civil disobedience. Pam Davis of the militant Earth First! environmental group, one of Redwood Summer's sponsors, urged the crowd to remain nonviolent and avoid clashes with police and loggers. Among the protesters' concerns are the cutting of ancient redwood forests, overcutting of forests in general and the shipping of unprocessed logs overseas. Organizers invited opponents to address the marchers. One man who identified himself as a timber industry worker said, ``We are not ruining our community and our trees ... We are growing more trees than we are taking out.'' But a mill worker from Oregon and a former logger from Fort Bragg warned that the timber industry was using up the forests. ``Stop clear cutting and do selective cutting. That's the reasonable way to do it,'' said Duane Potter, 36, who said he quit his job as a logger to protest timber company practices. The morning rally was held by permission in a field owned by Georgia-Pacific Corp., which operates two sawmills and two other wood-processing plants here and has thousands of acres of timberland in the area. On Friday, 17 people taking part in an Earth First! protest elsewhere in Mendocino County were taken into custody for allegedly trespassing on property of the Louisiana-Pacific timber company, bringing to 38 the number of arrests in three days of demonstrations. Forty-two people were arrested at a rally last month near Eureka. George Parsons, who owns a machine shop in Fort Bragg, said he attended Saturday's Redwood Summer protest ``because they are cutting the forests away so fast something has to be done.'' Parsons said he used to work in the woods and is sympathetic to timber workers. ``But the big (timber) companies are trying to polarize the community so they can go out and take as much as remains of our forests as they can,'' he said. ``If they (companies) were so concerned about the workers they would not be sending logs to Mexico to be milled,'' he added. But on the other side of town, hundreds of people, most wearing yellow T-shirts reading ``Timber Families _ An Endangered Species,'' marched to the pro-logging rally. Marchers chanted ``Families First!'' and ``It's OK to be a logger.'' Some carried signs reading ``Save Daddy's Job.'' The Proposition 130 ballot measure would authorize the sale of $742 million worth of state bonds to buy and preserve certain old growth forests. It also includes language that would restrict clearcutting, limit logging near waterways and require sustained-yield logging practices. Supporters say the initiative would protect California's forests. Critics claim it would cost thousands of logging jobs. The pro-industry rally was intended to help kick off a campaign against Proposition 130, said one of the organizers, Maribelle Anderson of the Community Solidarity Coalition.

DOC.HEAD: Pepper Commission Set to Recommend Paying Medicare Charges For Poor Elderly
DOC.TEXT: The Pepper Commission, a group created by Congress to study health insurance problems, will recommend that the federal government pay basic Medicare costs for the 3.5 million elderly people whose income is below the poverty line _ about $6,000 for an individual, according to a published report. The panel also will recommend that the government help pay Medicare costs for an additional 8.2 million elderly people whose incomes are up to twice the poverty level, The Washington Post reported in Sunday's editions. Those and other recommendations adopted by the panel Friday would cost the government about $2.8 billion a year, the paper said. Medicare is the health care program for the elderly and costs each recipient $343 a year in premiums if they are enrolled in the part of the program that pays a portion of out-of-hospital expenses. In addition, beneficiaries must pay the first $592 for each hospital stay and a portion of hospital stays that extend beyond 60 days. The commission is headed by Sen. John D. Rockefeller IV, D-W.Va., and named for the late Rep. Claude Pepper, D-Fla. In an earlier report, the panel outlined a plan for long-term care for the elderly and suggested that all employers be required to provide policies to workers or contribute to a government backup plan for those not covered through their jobs. An estimated 31 million Americans have no health insurance. The Post said 12 of the 15 commission members have agreed to the Medicare proposals for the poor elderly. The paper said the panel did not hold a formal meeting, but that the proposals were circulated to the members who responded with their approval or disapproval. The paper quoted unidentified sources as saying the tally was completed Friday.

DOC.HEAD: More Trouble for Man Who Bought 15 Thrifts on $1,000 Personal Investment
DOC.TEXT: A man who bought 15 Texas savings and loans using only $1,000 of his own money also bought an Oklahoma bank at a good price despite failing to disclose he'd been indicted for securities fraud, The New York Times reported. The Times said in Sunday editions that James M. Fail, who bought the Texas thrifts with his $1,000 and $70 million in borrowed money, was able to buy the United Oklahoma Bank, later renamed the Oklahoma Bank, without filling out a required form. The Phoenix man bought the bank and its approximately $100 million worth of assets for $500,000, which he borrowed. Fail has become a symbol of the savings-and-loan scandal because he secured $1.85 billion in federal subsidies with lobbying help from a former aide to President Bush. He is under investigation by a Senate subcommittee that is studying how he acquired the Texas S&Ls. Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, has called that deal with the defunct Federal Home Loan Bank Board ``the worst case'' to emerge from the S&L scandal. The Oklahoma purchase involves a different regulatory agency, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. The Times said that Fail and his lobbyist, Robert J. Thompson, received especially favorable treatment from the FDIC when Fail bid on the Oklahoma bank and didn't fill out the required background form. A year later, Fail filled out the form and stated that he had never been indicted, although he was indicted in 1976 in Alabama on charges of securities fraud. The form warns that false statements are subject to possible criminal prosecution. FDIC Chairman L. William Seidman said the agency should have postponed action or chosen a second bidder, bypassing Fail, who submitted the highest bid. ``We didn't stick strictly to the rules,'' Seidman told the Times. ``He duped us.'' Fail declined to be interviewed by the newspaper.

DOC.HEAD: Four Inducted Into National Aviation Hall of Fame
DOC.TEXT: The co-inventor of the theory of jet propulsion and the developer of an emergency escape system for combat pilots were among those inducted Saturday night into the National Aviation Hall of Fame. Hans P. von Ohain, Air Force Maj. Gen. Robert A. Rushworth, Elrey Jeppesen and the late Robert M. Stanley were inducted in ceremonies at the Dayton Convention Center. The event also included the presentation of awards to the mission team of the Voyager spacecraft and the Tuskegee Airmen, a non-profit, non-military organization founded in honor of America's first black combat aviators. Von Ohain, credited as co-inventor of the theory of jet propulsion, designed the engine used in the world's first jet flight at Germany's Heinkel Airfield on Aug. 27, 1939. ``The Hall of Fame is a phenomenal institution that keeps the spirit of innovation going strong,'' von Ohain said. ``When you see the individuals enshrined here, one can truly say it encompasses the history of flight.'' The retired Rushworth, a one-time test pilot, has clocked more than 6,900 hours of flight time, including 34 flights in the fabled X-15. The former vice commander of the Aeronautical Systems Division also flew 189 combat missions in Vietnam. Jeppesen developed ``Jepp Charts,'' manuals which give pilots important navigational information. During World War II, the charts were adopted as the Navy's standard flight manual. Stanley was enshrined posthumously for his development of emergency escape systems for combat pilots, including the first downward ejection seats and automatic release lap belts. As a naval aviator, he participated in the search for Amelia Earhart. A Milton Caniff Spirit of Flight award was presented to the Tuskegee Airmen by Lt. Gen. Benjamin O. Davis Jr., the nation's second black general and commander of all the Tuskegee Institute units during World War II. The award is named for the creator of the ``Steve Canyon'' comic strip. NASA Administrator Richard H. Truly presented a Caniff award to the mission team of the Voyager, which was launched into space in 1977 to relay interplanetary data and photographs to NASA's Jet Propulsion Lab in Pasadena, Calif. The fourth phase of the its 4.25 billion-mile interplanetary journey was completed last year. The National Aviation Hall of Fame was founded in Dayton in 1962 and recogized by an act of Congress in 1964. The 124 inductees include the Wright Brothers, Neil Armstrong, Earhart and other aviation pioneers.

DOC.HEAD: Herbert Nelson, Veteran Stage Actor, Dies at 76
DOC.TEXT: Herbert Nelson, a veteran actor whose credits include ``The Guiding Light'' soap opera and the television series ``Maude,'' has died at age 76. Nelson died of a stroke Thursday at the Actors Fund of America Nursing Home in this New York City suburb. A native of Stillwater, Minn., Nelson's career began in the 1930s with tent repertory and stock theater in the Midwest. He did more than 30 live radio shows in Chicago, including ``Perry Mason,'' before moving to New York in 1940 when ``The Guiding Light'' radio show switched to television. He was cast in his first Broadway role in 1941 in S.J. Perelman's ``The Night Before Christmas'' and helped launch the nation's first state-subsidized theater, the Barber Theater in Abingdon, Va. Nelson was also a founding member of the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists union. The 1950s was marked by many roles in live television dramas and daytime serials, including ``Believe It or Not,'' ``The Honeymooners,'' ``Perry Mason'' and four years with Hal Holbrook in ``The Brighter Day.'' He performed many times at the New York Shakespeare Festival under the direction of Joseph Papp, including a role in 1964 as Desdemona's father Brabantio in ``Othello.'' While he worked in New York, Nelson's home was in suburban Leonia, where he was active in civic affairs. He moved to Venice, Calif., in 1968, and lived there until 1989. During the late 1960s and 1970s, he had parts in many television shows, including ``The Bold Ones,'' ``The Waltons,'' ``Little House on the Prairie'' and ``Maude.'' His screen credits include ``Little Big Man,'' ``The Great Northfield Minnesota Raid,'' ``The Wilderness Family'' and ``The Hindenberg.'' Nelson is survived by two daughters, two sons, a brother and seven grandchildren. Services were scheduled for Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Military Reform Issue Stalls Salvadoran Peace Talks
DOC.TEXT: Peace talks in El Salvador's decade-long civil war foundered Saturday over rebel demands that the government pare down its military force and purge some right-wing officers. Little progress has been reported since the two sides reopened talks on Friday. The current round of talks are scheduled to end Tuesday. Leftist rebels said the conservative government of President Alfredo Cristiani had so far failed to satisfy their demands for major reforms of the military. U.N. mediator Alvaro DeSoto said he still hopes that this round of talks could still result in agreements on some political issues. ``We're waiting to see how the negotiations pan out,'' DeSoto told a news conference. But he cautioned that no action can be expected on the political topics unless the key issue of the military is settled. ``We have been working on the subject of the armed forces, but there will be no advances unless accords are reached in that regard,'' he said. Representatives of the guerrilla Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, or FMLN, insist that the military should be reduced in size and purged of right-wing officers responsible for human rights violations. The rebels also want a say in the appointment of the defense minister and commander-in-chief. FMLN representative Miguel Saenz said the latest government proposal did not go far enough. ``The government has made us a counter proposal, but we feel it doesn't satisfy our aspirations, because it only covers secondary themes,'' Saenz said. This is the third round of negotiations since Cristiani's rightist government took office in June 1988. In El Salvador, Cristiani indicated he rejected some of the guerrilla demands because they challenged the existence of the armed forces and could be considered unconstitutional. ``We can speak of their (the armed forces') qualitative and quantitative structure,'' Cristiani said, ``But their existence is not on the negotiating table. ``We cannot get away from our laws, especially our fundamental law which is the Constitution of the Republic,'' he added. Cristiani spoke briefly with reporters after opening a sports event in San Salvador, the capital. The Salvadoran armed forces, with about 54,000 members, is the second largest in Central America. Nicaragua has the largest armed forces, but the new U.S.-backed government in Managua has announced it plans to cut the size of the military as part of a peace agreement to end that country's civil war. The current Salvadoran talks are being held under the threat of a new guerrilla offensive, if no progress is made. The United States has been supporting a succession of governments during the decade-old Salvadoran civil war in which more than 72,000 people have been killed.

DOC.HEAD: Former NLRB Chairman Dies
DOC.TEXT: John H. Fanning, a 25-year member of the National Labor Relations Board, died Saturday at Georgetown University Hospital. He had diabetes. Fanning, 73, was appointed to the NLRB in 1957 by President Eisenhower and was reappointed by each subsequent president until he retired in 1982. He was chairman of the board from 1977-1981. The NLRB is an independent government agency established to prevent unfair labor practices and protect workers' rights. An attorney, Fanning, also worked at the Labor and Defense departments. His wife, Eloise Cooney Fanning died in 1982. His survivors include five children, 13 grandchildren, a sister and a brother.

DOC.HEAD: Public Buys Up Former Billionaire's Memorabilia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with auction over, raising more than twice as much as expected; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Eager buyers snapped up a cowhide-covered rocking chair, two French bronze horses at an auction of personal belongings of one-time billionaire Nelson Bunker Hunt, whose fortune foundered on silver. More than 650 curious collectors and antique connoisseurs packed the auction area on Hunt's 2,040-acre Circle T Ranch about 15 miles north of Fort Worth. The auction, which began at 11 a.m. and ended at 9:30 p.m., raised an estimated $410,000, said Carter Pate, the trustee for the estate. Pate had predicted the auction would raise up to $200,000. ``We're obviously extremely pleased, but extremely tired,'' said Pate. On sale were everything from salt-and-pepper shakers and wastebaskets to expensive bronze statues and porcelain figurines. Carter Pate, trustee for the estate, said the daylong auction had brought in about $380,000 by 8 p.m., nearly twice as much as expected, and continued into the evening. ``We've got a little bit of Hunt mania,'' Pate said. ``We got somebody that just paid $150 for a tea kettle that had a K-Mart sticker for $19.95 on the bottom. It beats the hell out of me.'' Pate said a buyer paid $9,000 for a Persian rug ``that was probably 30 years old.'' The 4-foot oak rocker, resembling a king's throne and covered with black and white cowhide on the seat and back, went for $3,000. A bronze statue of a mare and foal by French artist P.J. Mene sold for $3,250. Another Mene piece of galloping thoroughbreds sold for $1,000. The item officials had expected would attract the most attention, an elaborately carved Chippendale hall table, sold for $4,000. Its new owner, Jack Kent of New Orleans, said it would remind him ``that wealth doesn't always last forever.'' ``Every day I walk past that table, it's going to remind me that no matter how rich or powerful you are one day, you can wake up the next day with nothing,'' he said. Hunt and brother William Herbert Hunt, heirs to an oil fortune, lost more than $1.5 billion in an alleged attempt to corner the silver market a decade ago and sought bankruptcy court reorganization protection. The Dallas businessmen were ordered to sell off their antique collections and some personal possessions to pay their creditors, the biggest of which is the Internal Revenue Service. Eighty percent of the money raised Saturday will go to the IRS, Pate said. Nelson Hunt's debts topped $1.5 billion and Herbert Hunt's almost $1.2 billion. Saturday's auction is one of several to repay the debt. Two silver Greek coins sold for more than half a million dollars each at an auction of the Hunt brothers' coin and antique collection last month in New York. An 18-inch-tall Greek vase from about 510 B.C. sold for $1.76 million. At least one Hunt relative was at the auction Saturday, and he said he was disappointed the personal items were being sold. ``This is really unpleasant. It's unfortunate,'' said Houston Hunt, Nelson Hunt's son. ``But there are a lot of nice things out here. It's nice that people are getting to take this stuff home rather than just having it sit someplace else.'' Chris Grogan perused a table filled mostly with horse statues. ``We're horse nuts,'' she said. Nearby sat a bronze bust of Nelson Hunt. ``I suspect some family members will be after this one,'' said Jim Gall, chairman of the Miami-based Auction Company of America, which conducted the auction. Officials said some of the oilman's children and wealthy friends were expected to buy some of the items with the intention of returning them once the bankruptcy proceedings are finished. But Pate said later it did not appear that relatives or friends were doing much of the buying. Bebe Sternberg of Dallas came out to the auction out of curiosity. ``This is all a part of history. You hear so much about how the Hunts lived and how the rich live. ``I don't think they lived any different than the poor,'' she said, pointing to an old plaid green and white couch and other household items. ``Those will make good flea market items.''

DOC.HEAD: Shop Workers Go on Strike in Portland Area
DOC.TEXT: About 500 supermarket workers in the Portland area went on strike Saturday over a pay dispute, and their union encouraged 5,500 fellow workers to stay on the job to avoid disrupting shopping. Grocery owners in the five-county area threatened to lock out all 6,000 workers Sunday and hire replacements. Members of the United Food & Commercial union, which represents about 4,800 grocery clerks, 600 meat cutters and 600 delicatessen and bakery workers, voted overwhelmingly to take strike action, said union spokesman Rick Sawyer. The union targeted Kienow's 13 supermarkets, where about 500 employees walked out. The union was giving the public the ability to continue shopping at other major stores and still not cross picket lines, Sawyer said. Steve Erdmann, a spokesman for the grocery stores, said management will lock out all 6,000 workers rather than put one chain at an economic disadvantage. Management also wants all union members to bear the burden of lost pay while the strike continues, he said. Health care has been the major issue during contract talks, with the union pressing for employers to continue paying the full cost of benefits and the employers pressing employees to pay part of the benefits. The union's previous three-year contract was expiring at midnight Saturday. The workers, who have not had a pay increase since 1986, also are seeking higher wage increases. Erdmann said management offered a $1.15-an-hour raise for the clerks over a four-year contract. Journeymen clerks now make $11.05 an hour. The offer amounted to a 2{ percent increase a year, which is ``far below the projected rate of inflation,'' Sawyer said.

DOC.HEAD: Man Accused of Bothering Child TV Star Dies After Drinking Pesticide
DOC.TEXT: A man accused of mailing sexually explicit letters to the child star of the ``Who's the Boss?'' television show died 11 days after drinking a pesticide, authorities said Saturday. A postmortem examination determined that Mark A. Budman, 28, of Carson died of pneumonia and respiratory failure caused by malathion poisoning, said David Campbell, coroner's supervising investigator. Campbell said Budman's death was a suicide. Budman was pronounced dead Thursday at Harbor-UCLA Medical Center in Torrance, said Sheriff's Deputy Patrick Hunter. Budman was admitted to the hospital's intensive care unit July 8 after drinking malathion, Hunter said. Budman had previously tried to kill himself, authorities said. The man drank a quart of malathion, said Deputy City Attorney Alice Hand, who was prosecuting Budman in connection with harassment of actor Danny Pintauro. The prosecutor said Budman was charged June 7 with two misdemeanor counts of sending ``bizarre letters featuring sexual acts,'' to Pintauro, who plays Jonathan Bower on the ABC-TV show starring Tony Danza. On the series, Danza plays housekeeper to executive Angela Bower and Jonathan, her teen-age son. Letters and cassette tapes were sent to the young actor from March 1 to May 31, the prosecutor said. A warrant was issued after Budman failed to appear for a July 12 court date. Malathion is a commonly used pesticide available at most garden shops, hardware stores and nurseries. State agriculture officials have been spraying a syrup laced with malathion over parts of Southern California periodically for nearly a year in an effort to wipe out a Mediterranean fruit fly infestation. The spraying has prompted angry protests from residents complaining about the potential risks to public health, and several cities have tried unsuccessfully to halt the nighttime helicopter missions. Agriculture officials maintain that the pesticide is diluted to such small amounts that the aerial application is safe.

DOC.HEAD: Chuck Berry Denies Drug, Child Abuse Charges
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents
DOC.TEXT: Rock great Chuck Berry on Friday denied drug and child abuse charges he faces in Missouri, saying he had been framed, according to a statement. Berry issued the statement via his manager the day after his temper flared upon arrival at Stockholm airport for a Swedish tour. He created a commotion when he swung a bag and tried to kick a television photographer. No charges were filed, but the incident has been repeatedly aired on Swedish television. Three charges of child abuse allege that Berry made films of nude youths under age 17 for sexual gratification. A fourth charge alleges possession of more than an ounce of marijuana. In a raid last month at Berry's estate near Wentzville, about 40 miles west of St. Louis, authorities said they turned up several plastic bags of marijuana, some hashish, two .22-caliber rifles and a shotgun, in addition to $122,000 and pornographic videotapes, slides and books. The 63-year-old musician has refused to talk with reporters in Sweden. But he told Swedish manager Finn Johansson to relay a message.
