Johansson quoted Berry as saying he was innocent of both the drug and child abuse charges. ``It must be a sting. Someone is out to get me,'' the musician was quoted as saying. According to Berry's statement, someone planted marijuana in his ranch. That person was not identified. Berry secluded himself at Orsa, a small town in central Sweden, for his second performance on the tour. Critics panned the first show of the tour. Johansson said the tour would go on as planned.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Arrested for Using Men's Room Gets Wave of Public Support
DOC.TEXT: The arrest of a woman who used the men's room at a concert when she couldn't get into the women's room has generated a groundswell of support. ``It's obviously hit a nerve with a lot of women around town,'' Denise Wells said Friday. Ms. Wells was arrested July 7 at a George Strait concert. She received a ticket that could cost her $200 for violating a city ordinance that forbids members of one sex from using restrooms reserved for the other. The legal secretary also was kicked out of the concert, which she paid $125 to attend. A second woman was arrested at the same time. The Houston Post published Ms. Wells' story Thursday, and the phone started ringing. ``We've had people call that want to pay our fine,'' Ms. Wells said. ``I had a call from a woman who wanted to know who she could call in City Hall.'' Houston radio station KFMK told Ms. Wells it would pay any fine. ``The reason is because she is a listener and when you've got to go, you've got to go,'' said KFMK program director Bob Wood. Another radio station told Ms. Wells it would pay for her trip to Strait's next area concert and provide her with a personal portable toilet to use during the show. ``We just felt like she had gone through an awful lot of hassle to see George Strait and we wanted to make it a little easier for her the next time he came to town,'' said KIKK general manager Craig Magee. Ms. Wells said she went to use the women's restroom during the opening act, but the line was long and she decided to try later. She did so about 20 minutes into Strait's performance, only to find the line longer. The men's room ``would never be my first choice,'' she said. ``But I just could not, you know, it became kind of urgent, and I saw a guy take his girlfriend in in front of me. I saw them go in and I thought, `He's gonna run interference for her,''' so she followed them. A police officer arrested both women as they emerged. Ms. Wells' sister, Valerie Davenport, will represent her at the Nov. 1 hearing. ``My lawyer says necessity should be all the defense I need, but the way the city ordinance reads, it says that it's illegal to enter the restroom of the opposite sex with intent to cause a disturbance or something like that. And obviously that was not my intent,'' Ms. Wells said.

DOC.HEAD: Czech President to Meet Next Week with Kurt Waldheim
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel has confirmed he will meet next week with Kurt Waldheim ``out of respect for the Austrian nation,'' the official news CTK agency reported Friday. Havel was strongly criticized in both Czechoslovak and Austrian media for his plan to be keynote speaker Thursday at the annual festival in Salzburg, Austria, and meet with Austria's president, who has been internationally shunned for his wartime past. West German President Richard von Weizsaecker plans to meet with Waldheim at the same time as Havel, and is reaping criticism from the German Jewish community. On July 18, representatives of Charter 77, Czechoslovakia's dissident movement co-founded by Havel, asked him to reconsider his visit or give the reasons that led him to make ``such a serious step.'' ``I have thought about the dramatic situation for a long time and considered all its aspects. The result of my deliberations is the decision to go to Salzburg,'' Havel said in his answer to Charter 77, as carried by CTK. ``This decision of mine is an expression of respect for the Salzburg festival and especially the Austrian nation,'' Havel wrote. ``The Austrians are our close neighbors, bound to us by thousandfold relationships including common history, and I personally want to do everything in my power to strengthen our friendship,'' the president replied. Waldheim came under international criticism for initially concealing his wartime past as an intelligence officer with a German army unit implicated in atrocities in Yugoslavia and Greece. He has denied any wrongdoing, charging that allegations made against him were designed to prevent his election as president in 1986, and later, when that failed, to force his resignation.

DOC.HEAD: Iranian Pilot, Family Defect in Helicopter
DOC.TEXT: An Iranian pilot accompanied by his wife, three small children and sister-in-law flew to Saudi Arabia in a helicopter on Friday and requested political asylum, the Saudi Defense Ministry announced. In a statement distributed by the official Saudi Press Agency, an unidentified ministry spokesman said the air defense warning system detected a ``target ... flying at very low altitude over . .. the Arabian Gulf and toward our territorial waters.'' He said the target proved to be an Iranian helicopter piloted by a major who ``sent an SOS and requested emergency landing at the nearest airport on the kingdom's eastern coast.'' The statement said political asylum was requested, but did not say whether the request was granted.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Sentenced to Apologize to Falsely Accused Man in Ads Withdraws Appeal
DOC.TEXT: A woman sentenced to apologize in radio and newspaper ads to a man she falsely accused of raping her won't appeal the sentence to the state Supreme Court, her attorney said Friday. Elizabeth Irene Richardson, 24, decided against risking a longer jail sentence if the Nebraska Supreme Court decided she could not be ordered to pay for the advertisements as a probation condition, said her lawyer, Tod McKeone. ``There's still some possibility of not having to run'' the ads, he said. He is considering alternatives to appealing the sentence, including possibly filing a motion asking the district court for a sentence reduction. Ms. Richardson was sentenced June 8 to 180 days in jail, and was placed on two years' probation for perjury. A Dawson County District Court judge also ordered Ms. Richardson to apologize to Gary Nitsch in a half-page advertisement in every newspaper and a prime-time spot on each radio station in Dawson, a central Nebraska county of about 22,000 people. The cost has been estimated at $1,000. Ms. Richardson had accused Nitsch, 44, of raping her in September 1988. He was arrested and charged with sexual assault. Ms. Richardson testified that Nitsch raped her, but the case was dropped for lack of evidence. Authorities later learned that Ms. Richardson told friends the rape was a hoax. She was convicted of perjury last February. County attorney John Marsh said the woman was trying to get the attention of her husband, a truck driver who was often away from home. Ms. Richardson had appealed her sentence, claiming that it violates her constitutional rights to free speech, due process and protection from cruel and unusual punishment.

DOC.HEAD: Troopers Acquitted in Turnpike Beating Case
DOC.TEXT: Five current or former state troopers were acquitted Friday in the alleged beatings of three motorists pulled over on the New Jersey Turnpike. Only one officer was charged with assault. The others faced misconduct and conspiracy charges in an alleged plot to conceal the beatings, which the motorists claimed occurred at a police station in 1988. Robert K. Henig, 27, of Toms River, was acquitted of conspiracy, official misconduct and aggravated assault. Gary Tornquist, 25, of Plumsted Township, was acquitted of conspiracy, official misconduct and tampering with physical evidence. Sgt. Anthony Simonetti, 48, of Jamesburg; Lt. Robert Golembiewski, 53, of Rutherford; and Lt. Philip Pelligra, 53, of Flanders, were acquitted of conspiracy and official misconduct. Henig, Tornquist and Tornquist's former partner, Steven Waldie, 27, of Lawrenceville, have left the force. Waldie has been charged with aggravated assault, conspiracy, official misconduct, possession of a weapon for unlawful purposes, and perjury in the case. He is to be tried later. ``When I got indicted I couldn't believe it. I knew in my heart they couldn't find me guilty because I didn't do anything wrong,'' Tornquist said after the verdict, which took New Brunswick Superior Court jurors about seven hours to reach. Kenneth Lowengrub, 31, of North Plainfield, originally said he had been beaten in State Police Troop D headquarters in East Brunswick on Sept. 23, 1988. He was arrested earlier that day for investigation of a hit-and-run accident on the turnpike. Two other motorists, Stacy Brown, 23, of Plainfield, and Christopher Moore, 19, of New Brunswick, also claimed to have been beaten. They were held on drug charges in the station the same night. However, Lowengrub changed his story during the trial, testifying that he'd been beaten by Waldie, not Henig, in a police car on the way to the station. Defense attorneys said Lowengrub, an admitted drug user, falsely accused the officers in order to avoid charges in the traffic accident. The prosecution's star witness was William Sweeney, trooper of the year in 1988, who testified he was rebuked when he reported a prisoner had been beaten and was told to ignore any similar incidents in the future. Henig faces charges in another incident. He is accused of stealing cocaine from a police locker and using it to spike a motorist's urine sample.

DOC.HEAD: Trump Must Answer Questions Under Oath About Marla Maples
DOC.TEXT: A state judge ruled that developer Donald Trump must answer questions under oath for his estranged wife's lawyers about his relationship with Marla Maples. The ruling Thursday by judge Phyllis Gangel-Jacob was the latest development in the fight between Trump and his wife, Ivana, over a prenuptial agreement the couple signed Christmas Eve 1987. Mrs. Trump wants the agreement nullified so she can try to get up to half her husband's assets in any possible divorce action. Trump says his wife is entitled only to $25 million and any other property specified in the agreement, according to Trump's attorney, Jay Goldberg. Mrs. Trump's attorney, Michael Kennedy, charged that the prenuptial agreement was fraudulently obtained. He said Trump pledged his love to his wife while having an affair with another woman. ``In 1986, Donald had mentioned that he thought `open marriage' might be interesting, but that he knew I was too old-fashioned a girl to ever tolerate any other sexual relationship or affair,'' Mrs. Trump said in an affidavit. ``He did not tell me that he was seeing another woman and having an affair with her.'' Mrs. Trump also says in court papers that, had she been aware of her husband's ``adultery and philandering,'' she would not have entered into the prenuptial agreement and would have consulted a lawyer. Trump says ``love and affection'' were not material to the 1987 agreement, although those were mentioned in the first version signed in 1984. ``I find that there are (possible) concealments by (Trump) which should be determined'' at trial, Gangel-Jacob wrote in her decision. If the court finds that Trump updated the agreement without intending to live up to its terms, then the court could nullify it. Gangel-Jacob also ruled that nothing Trump did after the 1987 agreement was signed is relevant to the case. Trump reportedly gave depositions in the case earlier this week.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rules Clint Eastwood Can Continue $20 Million Libel Suit
DOC.TEXT: A judge ruled Friday that Clint Eastwood can press forward with his $20 million lawsuit against a Florida-based tabloid newspaper over a report that the actor was threatened by neo-Nazis. Superior Court Judge Dion Morrow turned down a request by Anthony Glassman, an attorney for The Globe, to dismiss the lawsuit. The judge gave the defendants 20 days to respond to the allegations. Eastwood contends an article in the tabloid's Jan. 2 edition was false and caused him mental anguish by making him fear for his life. The lawsuit also alleges ``false-light invasion of privacy,'' meaning the article portrayed the actor falsely, Glassman said. The Globe stands by the story's accuracy, Glassman said. The article was headlined ``Nazi Thugs Put Bounty on Clint _ But Dirty Harry Won't Lay Low.'' The Globe reported that Eastwood had received death threats and that a $100,000 bounty was placed on his life after he refused to speak at a convention of the Aryan Nations, a white supremacy group. ``Our position was simply that to be the enemy of American Nazis is not a bad thing. It's not offensive,'' Glassman said. ``He (Eastwood) claims, though, that he suffered emotional distress as a consequence of being put in fear that someone might act on that ... that it might cause someone to go out and try to collect the bounty.'' The Globe knowingly placed Eastwood and his family in danger ``by fabricating a sensational public dispute'' between Eastwood and white supremacist groups, Eastwood's lawsuit alleges. It could be a year before the case goes to trial, Glassman said. Eastwood is best known for his shoot-'em-up roles in Italian ``spaghetti'' Westerns and for the ``Dirty Harry'' movies, in which he plays a tough San Francisco detective. One of Eastwood's latest films, ``Pink Cadillac,'' pitted his character against a group of white supremacists.

DOC.HEAD: 2 Live Crew Cancels Concerts
DOC.TEXT: The controversial rap group 2 Live Crew's lead singer canceled all upcoming concerts because he's mentally and physically exhausted, his promoter said Friday. Jimmy Erhardt said lead singer Luther Campbell was debilitated by unrelenting interest in the band and its obscenity-laced music. He said the band will not perform in 11 planned concerts, but will return to the stage in November. The latest album from 2 Live Crew, ``As Nasty as They Wanna Be,'' has been ruled obscene in Florida. Campbell and other members of the band were arrested in June in a Miami suburb following a performance of some of their graphic songs. A band spokeswoman said Campbell was following doctor's orders not to perform. Scott Hurowitz, the general manager of the Country Club in Reseda, where the band was to perform two concerts next Wednesday, said he was disappointed by the decision because tickets were expected to sell well. ``We've done so much work on this,'' Hurowitz said. ``I sure hope they come back.''

President Bush is using the backdrops of a nuclear missile base in Wyoming and an aircraft carrier in Virginia to fortify his argument against weakening U.S. defenses in the post-Cold War era. Bush was flying to Newport News, Va., today to dedicate the nation's newest aircraft carrier, the George Washington. The 1,040-foot, nuclear-powered vessel, built at a cost of $3.1 billion, is to enter service in 1992. The trip to Newport News coincided with congressional debate over whether to shrink the Navy's carrier battle group fleet. The George Washington is the sixth of the Nimitz-class carriers to be built for the Navy. Two more are under construction. Fifteen carriers now are in active service. On Friday, during a tour of Warren Air Force Base near Cheyenne, Wyo., home of the nation's arsenal of MX intercontinental missiles, Bush indicated he was willing to accept limited cuts in his 1991 defense budget request.

Oliver North said a federal appeals court panel's decision to set aside his Iran-Contra convictions is ``a major step in the right direction.'' The panel, ruling 2-1 on Friday, reversed one of North's convictions and ordered a judge to review the evidence to determine whether all three convictions were tainted by ties to testimony he gave Congress under immunity. ``It has been, as you might imagine, a day of great exhilaration and excitement for me and my family,'' said North, stumping in Louisiana for a Republican U.S. Senate candidate. ``It has been what we believe to be a major step in the right direction and what has been a long and difficult ordeal,'' the former Marine lieutenant colonel and White House aide said during a speech Friday night on behalf of Ben Bagert.

Madrid's suspension of aid to Cuba underscores pressure for democratic change in the former Spanish colony and further isolates Fidel Castro at a time when his main benefactor, Moscow, is getting stingier. ``It's an abrupt and historic decision,'' said political scientist Manuel Alcantara, a professor of Latin American affairs at Madrid's Complutense University. ``Because of the events in Eastern Europe, Spain feels some kind of responsibility about Cuba, to work for change there.'' Last week four Cubans sought refuge in Spain's Embassy in Havana, and on Friday five more, including a woman and a young girl, entered the mission. Spain says it will not expel the asylum-seekers and will try to negotiate their departure from Cuba. Cuba calls all those who have sought refuge in the Spanish, Czech and Italian missions ``scum'' and habitual vagrants.

A new round of peace talks between the U.S.-backed government and leftist rebels got off to a slow start, and they were overshadowed by reports of heavy fighting. U.N. mediator Alvaro De Soto said negotiators only scratched the surface of their agenda when the five days of talks opened Friday. ``They got into specific themes, but without going very deep into the negotiations process,'' he told a news conference. The army reported that six rebels were killed and seven wounded Thursday in heavy fighting with soldiers near Jucuapa, 68 miles east of the capital. It said another rebel was wounded in fighting near Lolotique, 75 miles east of San Salvador.

A teen-age girl roughed up by a man who pulled her from her bicycle and dragged her into woods is fighting back with a self-defense book for her peers. At first, Amber Erling couldn't bear to stay home alone after the 1989 attack, when she was 14. She enrolled in karate to help regain her confidence and before long was holding self-defense workshops with her karate instructor and mother. Prevention is the main lesson of the book, called ``Safe & Sound: A Parent's Guide on Self-Protection for Kids.'' ``I figure if I can save one person, it will work,'' said Amber, now 15 and a high school sophomore.

DOC.HEAD: Hospitality In Moscow
DOC.TEXT: The Radisson Hotel people are shipping in the furniture, computers and facsimile machines in preparation for the fall opening of the first American-managed hotel in the Soviet Union. The Radisson Slavjanskaya, a 430-room enterprise connected to a 165-suite business center, is a challenge like none other for Radisson, a unit of the $6.2 billion (annual revenues) Carlson Companies of Minneapolis. There's nothing like it in Moscow, where a modern hospitality industry just doesn't exist, often to the dismay of American and other foreign business people. Services aren't available. Even the concept of service is dead. Equipping the operation with American television, communications modems, laser printers, phone lines, video conferencing gear and the like, tough as it will be, isn't the real challenge. Radisson has done that all over the world. The main challenge, faced before only by McDonald's, is to find Soviet workers and motivate them to say ``Yes, I can,'' a Radisson slogan, when a more tradiitional Soviet response has been to say ``No, I can't.'' Radisson's venture is a joint one with Intourist, the well-staffed Soviet foreign tourism ministry, which built the structure. But none of the workers will be hired from it. ``We want young, friendly people _ people inclined toward helping others,'' said Juergen Bartels, who heads the Carlson Hospitality Group, a $2.2 billion enterprise _ including Radisson _ within the Carlson Companies. ``We will look for nurses and teachers,'' he continues. ``We will not be hiring any of the hotel and restaurant people of Moscow.'' To do so would mean debriefing them. Teaching from scratch is tough enough, he suggested. The entire operation, says Bartels, a perfectionist who worked his way up through European and North American hotels, rises or falls with the quality of the people. His staff, he said, will choose, train, motivate and rate them. How do you do it? Can you find the type of workers you seek? Well, McDonald's did it. Bartels went straight to them with a list of 132 questions, to which they had answers for all but four. But selling burgers and fries is simpler than operating an international-standard hotel with services ranging from shoeshines and haircuts to banquets and secretarial services. It means training doormen, telephone operators, maids, reservations clerks, waiters, drivers, cooks and kitchen help. Bartels and his crew plan to employ 30 full-time foreigners, Americans included, and bring in 20 others temporarily from Radisson operations during the first weeks. Each foreigner will be understudied by one or two Soviets. The training begins with a clean slate, which can be both opportunity and frustration. Trainees will have few bad habits to unlearn, but they will have to be taught the most rudimentary technical skills of the trade. Unlike other Radissons, in which full services are offered from day one, the Slavjanskaya will develop gradually. Designed for four restaurants, it will begin with a buffet operation and gradually work up to full banquet facilities. The process will be both a learning and teaching experience. As the novices _ they'll begin with little more than the right attitude _ learn the technical side of their jobs, the hotel will become complete and efficient. It is expected to reach international standards within a year. When Bartels sets a standard it is achieved, partly because standards he sets for himself are higher. His belief that what is best today can be improved tomorrow is almost spiritual. People want to do better, he says. To achieve world-class standards, the Slavjanskaya's employees and services will be rated by guests on a scale of one to 10. ``We may have to discharge some workers,'' Bartels says. ``If average is seven, we expect nine.'' Based on their ratings, employees will earn points toward rewards. ``Western goods,'' says Bartels. ``Jeans, cigarettes, VCRs, radios.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PMs Monday, July 23.

DOC.HEAD: Western Scientists Unprepared for Effects of Interfamily Marriages
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to delete incestuous, since marriages to second cousins are not legally incestuous marriages, and with explanation of researcher's methods, contentions.
DOC.TEXT: As marriages to family members become more common in the United States, scientists are unprepared to offer counseling about the likelihood of genetic disorders, a University of Michigan researcher said. ``I'd been brought up to believe that inbreeding was pretty nasty,'' said Alan Bittles, a geneticist who has spent 10 years researching interfamily marriages in Pakistan and India. ``We never consider that in other parts of the world it's perfectly normal to marry a cousin.'' Bittles said he has determined that 500 million people worldwide are married to relatives, typically uncles and nieces or first or second cousins. He reached that total, he said, by combining his own research in Pakistan and India with information compiled by other researchers. ``All those have got to be rock-bottom low estimates, because we're missing information from so many parts of the world,'' he said. Such marriages are becoming more common in the United States because people from interfamily marriages are moving to this country and then continuing the custom. Bittles mentioned Lebanese, Palestinians and North Africans as being groups practicing interfamily marriage who are moving to the United States in substantial numbers. Although there are fewer genetic disorders among children born to married family members than Westerners believe, scientists have made few studies of those problems and have little information about them, he said. Inherited disorders include some blood diseases, protein deficiencies, spina bifida, cleft palates and hip and heart deformities. If parents from the same family marry and seek genetic counseling, doctors can give only occurrence rates derived from general population studies, Bittles said. ``We may be giving wrong advice,'' he said. ``We would be hard-pressed in this community to tell them what their risks are.'' Bittles, a Fulbright Fellow in the University of Michigan Population Studies Center, is a geneticist from Kings College in London. He is one of only a few researchers studying intermarriage but expects the field to grow. ``Once people recognize that this is a subject that needs investigation, that it has tremendous importance on a community, then they'll start studying it,'' he said.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday, July 23

For release Monday July 23
DOC.HEAD: Kohlberg Kravis Makes Friends With Bond Announcement
DOC.TEXT: Debt-financed takeover king Henry Kravis may have rejuvenated some respect from RJR Nabisco Co. junk bondholders with his firm's announcement it would buy back $3 billion worth of the high-risk securities. Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co.'s public announcement of the buyback plan immediately lifted the prices of RJR bonds and thereby made owners of those securities wealthier. It also scuttled any chance for Kohlberg Kravis, which bought the food-tobacco giant last year in a record $24.53 billion leveraged buyout, to repurchase the bonds cheaply and get a huge bargain in retiring some big debts. ``It's his way of making peace with the high-yield community,'' said Paul Getman, a bond market analyst with Regional Financial Associates Inc. in West Chester, Pa. ``It was a smart, moral thing to do.'' Managers that handle large funds with investments in junk bonds have been losing confidence in Kohlberg Kravis, which helped popularize the leveraged buyout in the 1980s and won recognition as the leader in the field. If Kravis, general partner in the firm and mastermind of the RJR LBO, had repurchased the bonds quietly, behind the backs of investors, he stood to further alienate money managers already skittish over several KKR-arranged LBOs that encountered trouble late last year. He probably couldn't have gotten away with a quiet buyback anyway because of the size of the repurchase. Junk-bond fund managers who aren't confident in a dealmaker can make life difficult by pushing for higher interest rates on these securities or staying away from the bonds altogether. If Kravis plans to arrange another buyout using junk bonds, he's going to need the support of those money managers. Another bond analyst agrees that Kravis had his reputation in mind when deciding to go public with the RJR bond repurchase. ``One of their marketing pitches is simple: `We don't mess around with bondholders. Give us 100 cents and we'll do everything in our power to give you 100 cents,'' said Dirk M. van Doren, of McCarthy Crisanti Maffei in Montpelier, Vt. ``KKR wanted to maintain its reputation. KKR may believe more deals are coming down the pike,'' van Doren said. RJR announced last Monday the details of a refinancing aimed at retiring more than $3 billion in bonds from two issues that totaled $7 billion. In the days following the announcement, prices of the two bonds, one due in 2007 and the other in 2009, rose about 10 percent. The bonds represented some of the most expensive debt in the RJR buyout. They are known as reset bonds because their interest rates are periodically recalculated. Retiring these bonds would eliminate the cost of periodically promising higher rates to make up for price losses in the market. A survey Getman conducted in March, during the depths of the junk bond market's slump, showed people thought KKR was becoming less prominent, he said. The survey asked 100 large-fund managers, bond issuers and academics to list three firms and indicate whether they would decline in importance, increase in importance or stay the same. Most of the 35 who responded to the survey listed KKR as the one in decline. The respondents said KKR was losing luster because several of its buyouts were having trouble, most notably Hillsborough Holdings Inc., which sought bankruptcy court protection from creditors late last year. Two other deals hit rough times in late 1989. Seaman Furniture Co., a retailer, was not able to meet debt payments. Bondholders agreed to reschedule the debt payments. SCI Television Inc. faced resistance from bondholders on a bond exchange offer. Now that KKR has made its repurchase public, bondholders can't say they got a raw deal from the firm, van Doren said. ``They (KKR) feel that's valuable. To be honest, in this business it's very valuable,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Popularity of Blue Jeans Fading
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS new 13th graf to add Levi's response that range of styles and fits has helped preserved its baby boomer market.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY5 of July 19; Graphic in AP Access under BLUEJEANS
DOC.TEXT: Blue jeans, for generations the uniform of rebels and conformists alike, are fading from the fashion forefront as aging baby boomers opt for new _ and more flattering _ looks. To put it bluntly, ``as their pocketbooks have gotten thicker, so have their waists,'' said Alan Millstein, publisher of the New York-based newsletter Fashion Network Report. Jeans, Millstein says, don't fit the lives of the thirtysomething generation, which is starting to confront the flab of middle age and facing the fact that ``gravity is the reality.'' The biggest fans of jeans, traditionally tight-fitting, youth-oriented fare, are those between the ages of 14 and 24, a segment of the population that has been shrinking for the past decade, said Dan Chew, marketing manager for Levi Strauss & Co., headquartered in San Francisco. Jeanswear Communications, a New York-based fashion industry group, said in a study released last month that total domestic jeans sales have dropped from a 1981 peak of 502 million pairs to 387 million pairs in 1989. Deborah Bronston, an analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., estimates the number of jeans sold declined by 6 percent during the first three months of this year alone. The decline of jeans has forced manufacturers to scramble for ways to protect their domain, often with products ranging from children's sweat gear to sexy lingerie. They have met with varying degrees of success. Some have been wounded because they responded to changing tastes too late. VF Corp., a Wyomissing, Pa., jeans maker that markets Lee and Wrangler brands and holds about 25 percent of the U.S. market, recently announced it will close four jeans factories by September. The costs of that cutback will be reflected in the company's second-quarter financial report and probably result in a 50 percent earnings decline from a year earlier, VG Chairman Lawrence R. Pugh said. He blamed a ``continuing shortfall in jeans orders resulting from weak consumer demand.'' Levi Strauss, on the other hand, is riding high. It has dramatically improved sales and profitability since becoming a private company five years ago in a debt-financed takeover. The improvement has come from much more than just sales of the 501, its classic 5-pocketed blue jeans. Levi's created Dockers, a cotton twill pant for ``maturing'' babyboom men. As one of retailing's brightest success stories, sales of Dockers went from $35 million in 1986 to a projected $500 million-plus this year. The product line has been expanded to include men's shirts and sweats as well as active wear for women and children. ``Dockers have helped offset the basic softness in men's jeans,'' Chew said. Levi Strauss also has strengthened its jean business by offering a range of styles and fits for baby boomers, who may have lost their physiques but not their desire for denim. Chew said that strategy has helped preserve the company's market for men over 25. For VF, however, diversification has been far rockier. The company purchased a North Carolina maker of men's cotton twill pants in 1984 but closed the unit two years later to focus on its acquisition of Blue Bell Holding Co., parent of Wrangler jeans, Jantzen swimwear and Jansport sports clothes. The move shoved VF ahead of Levi as the nation's biggest jeans maker. ``When jeans are booming, every age group is wearing them,'' said VF Chief Financial Officer Jerry Johnson. But these days, he said, there's ``a lack of fashionability attached to the product.'' This year VF has introduced a line of T-shirts and sweats under the Lee label in an effort to exploit its best brand name. So far sales are going ``very well,'' Johnson said, and the sweatshirts have sold out. Still, the company hopes to reduce dependence on jeans, partly by strengthening its intimate apparel offerings. VF, which sells Vanity Fair and Lollipop brands, purchased the lingerie concern Vassarette for $12 million earlier this year. Johnson said VF foresees growth of 10 percent annually in intimate apparel and is seeking to acquire ``additional brands or trademarks in that area.'' Analyst Bronston predicted intimate apparel will account for 15 percent of VF's estimated 1991 sales of $2.73 billion, up from the current 13 percent, while jeans will bring in 53 percent of annual revenue, down from the current 55 percent. Many experts said jeans makers are hoping to strengthen their dungaree business by exporting. While interest may be waning in the United States, jeans still retain considerable allure in the Soviet Union, parts of Europe and in the Far East. Levi's Chew said last year international sales accounted for roughly a third of the company's $3.6 billion in revenue, up from about 20 percent from five years ago. But Levi's strategists also say the U.S. market can't be ignored. The average American teen-ager still buys four to six pairs of jeans a year. So Levi's is spending heavily on a fresh advertising campaign directed by and featuring Spike Lee, acclaimed director of ``Do the Right Thing.'' Designer jeans, from Calvin Klein, Gloria Vanderbilt and others, are partly responsible for expanding the acceptance of blue jeans as appropriate dress for many occasions. But even at their peak in 1984, designer products accounted for less than 4 percent of the total blue jean market, Levi's Chew said. Nonetheless, some designer labels have managed to adapt to a changing marketplace. Guess? Inc., for example, which sells a basic $56, 3-zip jean (one zipper on the fly, one on each ankle because the pants are so tight), continues to drum up interest in its broader array of clothes. Expensive skin-tight jeans were the cornerstone product when Guess? was founded in 1981. But the company now sells everything from miniskirts and suede cowboy shoes to fragrances and eyewear in an effort to ``capture the customer who has needs other than denim,'' said spokeswoman Leah Levy. The company is pushing its new Georges Marciano line of career clothes for women, which appear in stand-alone boutiques in several major department stores. Still, Guess? derives about 80 percent of its estimated $400 million in annual sales from the denim collection. Rather than allow its fortunes to rest on a single jean design, Guess? continues to push ahead. This fall the silhouette of Guess? jeans change dramatically _ from excruciatingly tight to very baggy, ``anti-fit'' pants. Levy said part of the reasoning behind the shift is that today's jeans ``don't have to fit.''

DOC.HEAD: Slide In Pork Belly Futures Greased By Soft Bacon Market
DOC.TEXT: Whether it's anti-fat health consciousness or the popularity of fast food, for some reason the BLT seems to be losing stature as an icon of the American summer sandwich scene. At least that's what they're theorizing in the pork belly pits, where futures prices have slumped from a slack demand for bacon. Bacon manufacturers rely on the BLT effect _ an increased consumer appetite for bacon-lettuce-and-tomato sandwiches _ to boost sales during the summer to a seasonal peak. Bacon is made from pork bellies. The supply of fresh pork bellies usually falls short of demand during the summer, so slicers supplement their purchases of fresh bellies with frozen bellies that have been socked away in anticipation of the summertime demand surge. Demand has been so weak this month, though, that the supply of fresh supplies has been more than enough to keep the pipeline full, analysts say. The result has been a sharp drop in prices of both fresh and frozen bellies. Thomas Morgan, president of Sterling Research Corp. in Arlington Heights, Ill. said fresh belly prices on the cash market have tumbled from 62 cents a pound on July 5 to as low as 43.5 cents last week, a decline of about 30 percent. During the same period, the price of frozen bellies for July delivery on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange dropped from 56 cents to 45.9 cents a pound, an 18 percent decline. For belly traders, the plunge in fresh-belly prices below the frozen-belly futures contract price was a particularly bearish signal. Frozen belly prices normally average about 5 cents less than fresh prices in midsummer, which provides an incentive for slicers to use the frozen stocks. ``You need the cash market to be anywhere from 3 cents to 4 cents premium to futures to entice processers to draw out of the freezer,'' said Paul Georgy, president of Allendale Inc., a futures brokerage in Crystal Lake, Ill. ``This should be peak demand time for the bellies in general,'' he said, ``but the demand is slow enough that they're barely using the fresh bellies, so there's no incentive for them to pull bellies out of the freezer.'' On Friday, the Agriculture Department released a monthly cold-storage report that was expected to prompt renewed selling of belly futures on Monday. The report showed 88.1 million pounds of frozen pork bellies on hand as of June 30, about 1.8 million pounds more than the market had expected. The amount compares with 105.5 million pounds a month earlier and 126.7 million pounds a year ago. The situation may be troublesome to pork producers but shouldn't last long. Georgy pointed out that a recent government report indicated the nation's hog herd has shrunk since last year, which should reduce the number of bellies going into cold storage in the second half of the year. Morgan said he expects a price rebound. ``Sooner or later the market's going to get cheap enough that some of the users will say, `Hey, I'm going to take those,' and the supermarkets will say say, `Hey, I can make money featuring bacon at these prices,''' Morgan said. ``At the rate this market is dropping, it's not going to take too long to get there,'' he said. ``At least, it's going to bottom out and we might go soaring up for a couple of days.''

DOC.HEAD: Economists See New Numbers, Old Result
DOC.TEXT: Now that the Federal Reserve has changed its credit policy and the stock market has climbed to new record highs, what do Wall Street analysts see in the economic outlook? Sluggish, erratic growth _ the same as before. Amid all the headlines coming out of Washington and the Wall Street markets of late, most economic forecasters have found little reason to expect any big difference in the pattern of economic activity that has prevailed for months. True, stock-market investors have reacted enthusiastically to the Federal Reserve's actions at mid-July to relax its credit policy. In a move tipped off in advance by Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, the central bank took steps to lower the interest rate on federal funds, or overnight loans between banks, from 8\ percent to 8 percent. But the stated intent of that shift was not to stimulate business activity, but rather to offset a de facto tightening of credit brought about by increasingly stringent loan standards at many banks. ``I doubt that investors will be able to build a case that the economy will respond very significantly to this move _ or even to further moves to lower interest rates,'' said Greg Smith, investment strategist at Prudential-Bache Securities. ``I think the Fed's moves would have to be much more dramatic or much more frequent than I anticipate to convince investors that much better economic times are ahead.'' When the government reports this coming Friday on the growth of the gross national product in the second quarter of the year, analysts take it as a given that the figures will be anemic. ``The U.S. economy remains in a sluggish state,'' says the Merrill Lynch Market Letter in its current issue. ``We estimate growth the June quarter was a lackluster 1.3 percent, and we think increases of less than 2 percent are likely over the next few quarters.'' Such assessments helped blunt the stock market's rally in the past week. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials closed Friday at 2,961.14, down 19.06 from the week before. The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 2.68 to 197.65; the NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market tumbled 13.17 to 455.27, and the American Stock Exchange market value index was down 3.54 at 360.45. Volume on the Big Board averaged 166.96 million shares a day, against 171.27 million the week before. Whatever the Fed is up to, many analysts believe consumer spending, a primary factor setting the course of the economy, is likely to remain subdued at best. ``Looking beyond the erratic and often revised monthly changes in retail sales, recent underlying trends have been disappointing and should remain so,'' said Maury Harris, economist at PaineWebber Inc. ``Purchasing power is waning with softer labor markets. Consumer confidence _ a leading indicator _ also is waning. ``The likely continued weakness in home sales will reduce purchases of home furniture and furnishings. Spending at restaurants and bars _ a key indicator of discretionary consumer spending _ has been down for four straight months.'' Nevertheless, a good many analysts believe the strength of the stock market signals that the banking problems worrying the Fed will not lead to a recession. ``The outlook for the balance of 1990 looks simply to be more of the same,'' said David Resler, economist at Nomura Securities International in New York. ``The economy will continue to expand, but at a lackluster pace that is well below its potential.''

DOC.HEAD: Bad Week for Defense Contractors
DOC.TEXT: The nation's defense industry is struggling _ no surprise there _ but some of the reasons have little to do with the thaw in the Cold War and cutbacks at the Pentagon. The bad news this past week from some of the nation's largest defense contractors can be traced back to things that have been going on a lot longer than the dismantling of the Berlin Wall, stock analysts said. McDonnell Douglas Corp. announced a drastic cost-cutting campaign that will lay off thousands. General Dynamics Corp. announced a heavy second-quarter loss. And Grumman Corp.'s head resigned abruptly amid reports he was under investigation for possibly accepting improper loans from a subcontractor. The austerity measures taken by McDonnell Douglas, the nation's biggest defense company, are aimed at saving more than $700 million this year. But that plan, which some analysts said doesn't go far enough, is primarily a result of management mistakes that have left the St. Louis-based company inefficient and unprofitable. ``This is something they have to do to keep their head above water,'' said Michael Rosen, an aerospace analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. in New York. ``The company has its back to the wall.'' McDonnell Douglas has been plagued by production troubles at its Douglas Aircraft subsidiary in Long Beach, Calif., where most of its commercial jet construction is done. The company also has been hurt by losses on a range of military projects. Its production backlog has climbed to a record $54 billion. While it's nice to know there are plenty of customers, McDonnell Chairman John F. McDonnell said he wants to ensure the company is making, not losing, money on its orders. ``At this point in time, we have more costs than we can have to be successful in our business,'' McDonnell said. ``We made some mistakes and we're in the process of correcting them.'' Meanwhile, the nation's second biggest contractor, General Dynamics Corp., also headquartered in St. Louis, announced a $240 million loss in the second quarter because of cost overruns on the Navy's A-12 jet bomber. The company said deducting $500 million from quarterly earnings _ the biggest quarterly charge against earnings in its history _ primarily because the development of A-12 would cost more than expected. Industry analysts said this trouble was caused by what they called the dumb but popular idea in Congress that advanced military equipment should be developed on a pre-determined budget. ``It's like saying, `I'm going to do something adventurous without the adventure.' If you think you can pioneer something on a fixed budget, you're basically lying to yourself,'' said Wolfgang Demisch, an analyst for UBS Securities in New York. Fixed-price development contracts set a price for the development of a new piece of equipment. If a contractor goes over the price, the contractor has to file claims and ask for the additional money. Generally, defense contractors haven't listed cost overruns on the development of planes, tanks or other equipment until after the project is completed and those various contract claims have been settled. ``But what's happening here is the government is leaning very heavily on the contractors to take the charge and not say anything about the contract claims,'' said Paul Nisbet, an analyst for Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. in New York. ``The company is playing politics. They're looking to keep the customer happy even though they are paying dearly in the balance sheet.'' General Dynamics' partner on the A-12 program is McDonnell Douglas, which didn't take any charges for the project and reported a profit of $57 million for the quarter. But analysts said McDonnell Douglas it is assuming the Pentagon will cough up the extra cost. For Grumman, an important Pentagon supplier based in Bethpage, Long Island, the trouble this past week stemmed from a broad investigation by the Justice Department into defense-contracting corruption. John O'Brien, who resigned suddenly as head of the company, was reported to be under grand jury investigation for possibly accepting nearly a half million dollars in loans from James Kane, a now-deceased Grumman subcontractor who was thought to be a central figure in a Pentagon bribery scheme. By week's end, neither Grumman, O'Brien or his lawyer had commented on the reports. In other business and economic news this past week: _More troublesome economic signs emerged. Housing starts in June plunged to the worst level since the last recession, consumer prices jumped and a number of leading companies reported disappointing second-quarter earnings. _Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan suggested he won't move to ease interest rates further unless Congress and the White House move decisively toward a deficit reduction. But in one key sign that interest rates are coming down, interest on fixed-rate mortgages fell below 10 percent for the first time since the beginning of the year. _The United Auto Workers union opened contract negotiations with the Big Three automakers amid one of the deepest slumps the industry has faced in years. Health care and job security are the major issues in the talks.
